('23', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. NOTES
('23', 0, 2, 3, 49) INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('23', 0, 3, 4, 73) Despite the mission of Sir Benjamin Robertson, the South Afri can Commissions 1 has delivered an adverse finding.
('23', 0, 3, 5, 187) Commissions, Lord Morley 2 has often said, serve no useful purpose.
('23', 0, 3, 6, 255) They raise false hopes, and, for the time being, divert public attention from matters they are appointed to deal with.
('23', 0, 3, 7, 374) They give time for passions to cool down.
('23', 0, 3, 8, 416) But they rarely do justice.
('23', 0, 3, 9, 444) Indeed, it is notorious that Com missions avoid abstract justice.
('23', 0, 3, 10, 510) They offer, or effect, com promises.
('23', 0, 3, 11, 547) But the South African Commission has offered, or effected, no compromise.
('23', 0, 3, 12, 621) It has delivered the Indian in the hands of his white rival in trade.
('23', 0, 3, 13, 691) It has reaffirmed the principle of white supremacy, as Mr. Andrews so often puts it.
('23', 0, 3, 14, 776) The principle has almost become a passion and a religion.
('23', 0, 3, 15, 834) In 1901, the late Sir Pherozeshah 3 rated me for ‘wasting my time,’ as he put it, on South Africa.
('23', 0, 3, 16, 933) During the satya graha campaign, he was the last, as he said himself; to be enthused.
('23', 0, 3, 17, 1019) And when he was enthused, it was not the justice of the cause (which he never doubted) but it was the incarceration 4 of Mrs. Gandhi which roused his chivalrous spirit, and threw him into the struggle.
('23', 0, 3, 18, 1221) He used to say that I should return to India and work for the freedom of the whole of India, rather than for a handful of Indians in South Africa.
('23', 0, 3, 19, 1368) I thought then, as I think even now, that whilst the un crowned king of the Presidency of Bombay was right about concentrating on India’s freedom, he was wrong in thinking that I should have withdrawn from South Africa.
('23', 0, 3, 20, 1588) We dare not neglect our countrymen abroad.
('23', 0, 3, 21, 1631) The battle of India’s freedom involves the protection of the rights of the least of our countrymen, no matter where they might be situated.
('23', 0, 3, 22, 1771) But at the present moment, I must invite our countrymen in South Africa to carry on their battle bravely and single handed, and help us here in the best way they can.
('23', 0, 3, 23, 1938) India’s fate must be decided
('23', 0, 4, 24, 1967) 1 The Africa Enquiry Commission appointed by the Union Government of South Africa which sat from March to July 1920. It was assisted by Sir Benjamin Robertson on behalf of the Government of India.
('23', 0, 4, 25, 2164) 2 John Morley, Viscount Morley of Blackburn (1838 1923); Secretary of State for India, 1905 10 3 Sir Pherozeshah Mehta 4 In South Africa in 1913; vide “Letter to Clement Doke”, 24 9 1913.
('23', 1, 0, 1, 2352) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 1, 1, 2, 2392) one way or the other (and so far as I know only one way) during this year.
('23', 1, 1, 3, 2467) We shall be better able to protect them then, than now.
('23', 1, 1, 4, 2523) The South African problem bears the same character as the pro blem at home.
('23', 1, 1, 5, 2599) We too are fighting the religion of white supre macy.
('23', 1, 1, 6, 2653) The refusal to recognize the Muslim claim, the encircling of the Arabs, the negotiations with the Ameer 1, the refusal to stop the pensions of Sir Michael O’Dwyer and General Dyer, and frankly to dismiss men who maltreated the Punjabis in 1919, are symptoms of the same disease.
('23', 1, 1, 7, 2932) Either that supremacy must go in its entirety, or those of us who recognize the tubercular nature of the disease must perish in the attempt to combat it.
('23', 1, 1, 8, 3086) The Government of India can, if they wish, put up an energetic and open fight against the proposed breach of faith which the Commission implies.
('23', 1, 1, 9, 3231) The spirit of the settlement of 1918 was that the position of the Indian all over South Africa must be levelled up, not a single right then existing should be in any way endangered.
('23', 1, 1, 10, 3413) The Commission has not only put its impri matur on the encroachments already made on existing rights, but it has itself suggested further and egregious curtailment thereof.
('23', 1, 1, 11, 3586) Be tween free nations such an authoritative pronouncement would lead to open rupture.
('23', 1, 1, 12, 3672) The Report of the Commission can only spur my non co operation spirit to further effort.
('23', 1, 2, 13, 3761) THE MEANING OF SWARAJ
('23', 1, 3, 14, 3783) A friend from South Africa writes to say that several Europeans there are prepared to help the struggle for swaraj, but they want to be assured on certain points.
('23', 1, 3, 15, 3946) As the points raised are of general im portance, I gladly deal with them here.
('23', 1, 4, 16, 4025) 1. Does Mr. Gandhi’s swaraj mean sovereign independence, or full responsible
('23', 1, 5, 17, 4102) Government within the Empire on the Dominion lines?
('23', 1, 5, 18, 4154) I should certainly be satisfied with full responsible Government on Dominion lines if the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs are redressed.
('23', 1, 5, 19, 4290) India cannot remain within the Empire if the latter cannot redress the two wrongs; for full responsible Government will have no meaning for India, if she cannot refuse to give pensions to officers who have wronged her, or if she cannot secure a settlement of the Khilafat terms.
('23', 1, 5, 20, 4569) England then becomes an ‘enemy country’ for India.
('23', 1, 6, 21, 4620) 1 The King of Afghanistan.
('23', 1, 6, 22, 4647) The negotiations ultimately led to the signing of the Anglo Afghan Treaty on November 22, 1921.
('23', 2, 0, 1, 4743) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 3
('23', 2, 1, 2, 4783) 2. Do the Muslims claim Palestine, or will they restore it to the Jews who are the original owners?
('23', 2, 1, 3, 4883) The Muslims claim Palestine as an integral part of Jazi rat ul Arab.
('23', 2, 1, 4, 4952) They are bound to retain its custody, as an injunction of the Prophet.
('23', 2, 1, 5, 5023) But that does not mean that the Jews and the Christians cannot freely go to Palestine, or even reside there and own property.
('23', 2, 1, 6, 5149) What non Muslims cannot do is to acquire sovereign jurisdiction.
('23', 2, 1, 7, 5214) The Jews cannot receive sovereign rights in a place which has been held for centuries by Muslim powers by right of religious conquest.
('23', 2, 1, 8, 5349) The Muslim soldiers did not shed their blood in the late War for the purpose of surrendering Palestine out of Muslim control.
('23', 2, 1, 9, 5475) I would like my Jewish friends to impartially consider the position of the seventy million Muslims of India.
('23', 2, 1, 10, 5584) As a free nation, can they tolerate what they must regard as a treacherous disposal of their sacred possession?
('23', 2, 1, 11, 5696) THE NEW VICEROY I think the duty of non co operators is clear regarding Lord Reading.
('23', 2, 1, 12, 5782) Whilst we may not take part in any demonstrations of welcome, we may not also undertake, or countenance, any counter demonstration.
('23', 2, 1, 13, 5914) We have no quarrel with Englishmen, or even with officials as such.
('23', 2, 1, 14, 5982) We seek to, and we must, destroy the system they are called upon to administer, because we regard it as wholly evil in its totality.
('23', 2, 1, 15, 6115) We must dissociate ourselves from individual officials, who, like Sir Michael O’Dwyer and General Dyer, have wronged India, and have been untrue to her salt.
('23', 2, 1, 16, 6273) Lord Reading has a golden opportunity.
('23', 2, 1, 17, 6312) He belongs to a race which has a fine imagination.
('23', 2, 1, 18, 6363) He knows what a ‘pariah’ means and how he feels If he examines the non co ope rators’ case with impartiality, and if he fails in his advocacy of her claims, he must himself become a non co operator.
('23', 2, 1, 19, 6562) He may not ask them to forgive, where there is no frank and full repentance.
('23', 2, 1, 20, 6639) Nor must he ask the Muslims to give up their just claims or the Hindus to sell their fellow country men.
('23', 2, 1, 21, 6744) Lastly, His Excellency may not ask India to postpone the attainment of her birthright, whether for the sake of Lancashire or any other consideration.
('23', 2, 1, 22, 6894) His Lordship therefore will have [to] have an exceptionally strong will to resist an environment which is almost wholly antagonistic to the Indian case.
('23', 2, 1, 23, 7047) Non co ope rators must do nothing to add to his diffi culties.
('23', 2, 1, 24, 7110) We must give His Excellency the fullest credit for meaning to do well.
('23', 2, 1, 25, 7181) But I would also warn them against building hopes on Lord Reading doing anything.
('23', 2, 1, 26, 7263) This is a battle of self help and self reliance.
('23', 2, 1, 27, 7312) We must create the envi 
('23', 3, 0, 1, 7337) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 3, 1, 2, 7377) ronment we need for our free nourishment.
('23', 3, 1, 3, 7419) And, among the things we must do, one is to secure the goodwill of true men and women by our exemplary behaviour.
('23', 3, 2, 4, 7533) SOME TESTS
('23', 3, 3, 5, 7544) Mr. T. B. Purohit asks several pertinent questions about non co operation.
('23', 3, 3, 6, 7619) Before answering, it will be, perhaps, better to lay down some general tests.
('23', 3, 3, 7, 7697) The primary motive of non cooperation is self purification by withdrawing co operation from an unrighteous and unrepentant Government.
('23', 3, 3, 8, 7832) The secondary object is to rid ourselves of the feeling of helplessness by being independent of all Government control or supervision, i.e., to govern ourselves in all possible affairs; and, in fulfilling both the objects, to refrain from doing or promoting injury, or violence, to any individual or property.
('23', 3, 3, 9, 8142) Let us apply the tests to Mr. Purohit’s questions which are as follows:
('23', 3, 4, 10, 8214) 1. Whether a non co operator can remain a member of a registered library or reading room?
('23', 3, 4, 11, 8304) If I were a member, I would first move my fellow members to disregister the library, and if I cannot, I would resign my membership and agitate for its disregistration, so as to make the people feel self reliant and independent.
('23', 3, 5, 12, 8532) 2. Whether a non co operator can remain a member of existing registered co operative credit societies or banks which are solely managed by the public for the general public interest?
('23', 3, 5, 13, 8715) I have some experience of these societies.
('23', 3, 5, 14, 8758) And I have no hesitation in saying that registration interferes with their free growth and increases people’s dependence upon the Government.
('23', 3, 5, 15, 8900) The idea of such societies is excellent and should be nursed, but we need not think that we cannot promote such societies without Government aid or inspection.
('23', 3, 5, 16, 9060) I know the usual arguments in favour of registration.
('23', 3, 5, 17, 9114) But on an analysis, they will all be found to betray want of faith in ourselves.
('23', 3, 5, 18, 9195) I would, therefore, in this instance, too, first try to convince my fellow members of the inutility of registration, and, on failure, secede from the society or bank, and educate the public to boycott such societies or banks.
('23', 3, 5, 19, 9421) I know that, at least in one instance, regis tration has been removed, and everyone knows that India has thou sands of unregistered flourishing banks whose honesty and busi ness like methods are still among the wonders of the world.
('23', 3, 5, 20, 9654) Young India, 6 4 1921
('23', 4, 0, 1, 9676) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 5
('23', 4, 1, 2, 9716) 2. A TAXING EXAMINER
('23', 4, 2, 3, 9737) I would love to feel that I was an M. A. of the University of Non co operation.
('23', 4, 2, 4, 9817) But my examiners show me that, whilst I have matriculated in that University, I have yet to fill many a term in the college course.
('23', 4, 2, 5, 9949) Of all my many correspondents, the Sindhi friends are the most searching and, even, provoking.
('23', 4, 2, 6, 10044) What I present to the readers of Young India is but a sample of examination papers set to me.
('23', 4, 2, 7, 10138) Here is one such from Sind:
('23', 4, 3, 8, 10166) 1. Do you expect that violence will ensue from your movement of non co operation ?
('23', 4, 3, 9, 10249) If I did, I would not have advised it.
('23', 4, 4, 10, 10288) 2. Explain fully the doctrine of non violence.
('23', 4, 4, 11, 10335) Non violence is not doing, voluntarily, any injury to person or property.
('23', 4, 4, 12, 10409) Thus, I would not punish or procure punishment even of General Dyer for his massacre, but I would not call it voluntarily doing injury to him to refuse to give him pension, or to condemn his action in fitting language.
('23', 4, 4, 13, 10628) It is no part of my duty to protect a murderer even though he may be my son or father.
('23', 4, 4, 14, 10715) I hold it to be my duty to withdraw my support from him.
('23', 4, 4, 15, 10772) I will not kill a snake, neither may I harbour it.
('23', 4, 5, 16, 10823) 3. If violence ensues from your movement, will you retire to the moun tains ?
('23', 4, 5, 17, 10901) If violence results from non co operation,or if non co operators resort to violence, i.e., if India makes violence her creed, and I have survived, I would not care to live in India.
('23', 4, 5, 18, 11083) She will cease to evoke any pride in me.
('23', 4, 5, 19, 11124) My patriotism is subservient to my religion.
('23', 4, 5, 20, 11169) I cling to India like a child to its mother’s breast, because I feel that she gives me the spiritual nourishment I need, she has the environment that responds to my highest aspirations.
('23', 4, 5, 21, 11355) When that faith is gone, I shall feel like an orphan without hope of ever finding a guardian.
('23', 4, 5, 22, 11449) Then the snowy solitude of the Himalayas must give what rest it can to my bleeding soul.
('23', 4, 5, 23, 11538) Needless to say, the violence that would drive me to the Himalayas is not the violence of language or rowdyism which my critics often fling in my face whilst reminding me of the Himalayas.
('23', 4, 5, 24, 11727) It is violence not due to non co operation, nor is it violence of the real non co operators.
('23', 4, 5, 25, 11820) These outbursts are a legacy of our undisciplined past.
('23', 4, 5, 26, 11876) It is being brought under check day by day.
('23', 4, 5, 27, 11920) It is so insignificant as to be itself a mighty demonstrationof the peace that reigns supreme in India today.
('23', 4, 5, 28, 12030) This peace, in the face of provocation attempted by
('23', 5, 0, 1, 12082) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 5, 1, 2, 12122) officials, knowingly or unknowingly, in the shape of their vexations and often illegal notices must, if continued, in itself ensure swaraj within the year.
('23', 5, 1, 3, 12278) For it shows unity of purpose and determination among the people.
('23', 5, 2, 4, 12344) 4. What should other non co operators do, if such violence breaks out?
('23', 5, 2, 5, 12415) Should they stop the preaching of non co operation?
('23', 5, 2, 6, 12467) When (if ever) that tempestuous violence breaks out, true non co ope rators would have died in the attempt to prevent violence Question 3 presupposes my sole survivorship.
('23', 5, 2, 7, 12639) But assume, that I have scuttled to the Himalayas, (as it would then be to escape death), the remaining non co operators would certainly be expected to remain true to their faith in spite of my cowardly retreat and be living witnesses to their faith till the flames overwhelm them.
('23', 5, 2, 8, 12921) The voice of the preacher will then be drowned in the onrushing torrent of blood.
('23', 5, 3, 9, 13003) 5. If you retire to the mountains, what will be the fate of the poor students who have boycotted aided or Government institutions?
('23', 5, 3, 10, 13134) The questioner forgets that when violence reigns supreme in India there will be no schools, aided or unaided, for students to attend.
('23', 5, 3, 11, 13268) Only those students are called upon to leave Government schools who consider it to be sinful to remain in them.
('23', 5, 3, 12, 13380) The question of returning to such schools does not arise in their case.
('23', 5, 3, 13, 13452) And what has my retirement to the mountains to do with the students’ withdrawal?
('23', 5, 3, 14, 13533) Every student is expected to judge for himself what is best for him and his country.
('23', 5, 3, 15, 13618) The movement of self government cannot—must not—be made to depend upon one man.
('23', 5, 3, 16, 13698) I have but presented India with a new and matchless weapon, or rather an extended application of an ancient and tried weapon.
('23', 5, 3, 17, 13824) She must reject or accept it for her own use.
('23', 5, 3, 18, 13870) I cannot use it for her.
('23', 5, 3, 19, 13895) I can use, have used, it for myself and feel free.
('23', 5, 3, 20, 13946) Others have done, and feel, likewise.
('23', 5, 3, 21, 13984) If the nation uses the weapon she becomes free.
('23', 5, 4, 22, 14032) 6. How far has your movement of non co operation progressed?
('23', 5, 4, 23, 14093) So far that I feel swaraj running to us.
('23', 5, 4, 24, 14134) If we keep up the same velocity, we shall be a free nation within this year.
('23', 5, 5, 25, 14211) 7. Are you aware that most of the non co operating workers are irresponsible?
('23', 5, 5, 26, 14289) Have you ever condemned them?
('23', 5, 5, 27, 14319) I am not.
('23', 5, 5, 28, 14329) On the contrary, I am aware that most of them are res ponsible, sober, honest and brave workers.
('23', 5, 5, 29, 14426) I hope I have condemned irresponsibility wherever I have found it.
('23', 5, 6, 30, 14493) 8. Under what circumstances do you expect to get swaraj in October?
('23', 6, 0, 1, 14561) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 7
('23', 6, 1, 2, 14601) I have often mentioned the conditions in these columns.
('23', 6, 1, 3, 14657) The correspondent must look up the back numbers.
('23', 6, 2, 4, 14706) 9. Will the spinning wheel solve the problem of India’s poverty ?
('23', 6, 2, 5, 14772) If it will, how ?
('23', 6, 2, 6, 14790) I am more than ever convinced that without the spinning wheel the problem of India’s poverty cannot be solved.
('23', 6, 2, 7, 14901) Millions of India’s peasants starve for want of supplementary occupation.
('23', 6, 2, 8, 14975) If they have spinning to add to their slender resources they can fight successfully against pauperism and famine.
('23', 6, 2, 9, 15089) Mills cannot solve the problem.
('23', 6, 2, 10, 15121) Only hand spinning—and nothing else—can.
('23', 6, 2, 11, 15162) When India was forced to give up hand spinning, she had no other occupation in return.
('23', 6, 2, 12, 15249) Imagine what would happen to a man who found himself suddenly deprived of a quarter of his bare livelihood.
('23', 6, 2, 13, 15357) Over eighty five per cent of her population have more than a quarter of their time lying idle.
('23', 6, 2, 14, 15452) And, therefore, even apart from the terrible drain rightly pointed out by the G. O. M. 1 of India, she has steadily grown poorer because of this enforced idleness.
('23', 6, 2, 15, 15616) The problem is how to utilize these billions of hours of the nation without disturbing the rest.
('23', 6, 2, 16, 15713) Restoration of the spinning wheel is the only possible answer.
('23', 6, 2, 17, 15776) This has nothing to do with my special views on machinery or with the boycott of foreign goods in general.
('23', 6, 2, 18, 15883) India is likely to accept the answer in full during this year.
('23', 6, 2, 19, 15946) It is madness to tinker with the problem.
('23', 6, 2, 20, 15988) I am writing this in Puri 2 in front of the murmuring waves.
('23', 6, 2, 21, 16049) The picture of the crowd of men, women and children with their fleshless ribs, under the very shadow of Jagannath, haunts me.
('23', 6, 2, 22, 16175) If I had the power, I would suspend every other activity in schools and colleges, and everywhere else, and popularize spinning; prepare out of these lads and lasses spinning teachers; inspire every carpenter to prepare spinning wheels; and ask the teachers to take these life giving machines to every home, and teach them spinning.
('23', 6, 2, 23, 16507) If I had the power, I would stop an ounce of cotton from being exported and would have it turned into yarn in these homes.
('23', 6, 2, 24, 16630) I would dot India with depots for receiving this yarn and distributing it among weavers.
('23', 6, 2, 25, 16719) Given sufficient steady and trained workers, I would undertake to drive pauperism out of India during this year.
('23', 6, 2, 26, 16832) This undoubtedly requires a change in the angle of vision and in the national taste.
('23', 6, 2, 27, 16917) I regard the Reforms 3 and everything else in
('23', 6, 3, 28, 16963) 1 Grand Old Man, i.e.
('23', 6, 3, 29, 16985) Dadabhai Naoroji 2 On the coast of Orissa, which Gandhiji visited on March 28, 1921 3 Montagu Chelmsford Reforms embodied in the Government of India Act of 1919
('23', 7, 0, 1, 17146) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 7, 1, 2, 17186) the nature of opiates to deaden our conscience.
('23', 7, 1, 3, 17234) We must refuse to wait for generations to furnish us with a patent solution of a problem which is ever growing in seriousness.
('23', 7, 1, 4, 17361) Nature knows, no mercy in dealing stern justice.
('23', 7, 1, 5, 17410) If we do not wake up before long, we shall be wiped out of existence.
('23', 7, 1, 6, 17480) I invite the sceptics to visit Orissa, penetrate its villages, and find out for themselves where India stands.
('23', 7, 1, 7, 17591) They will then believe with me that to possess, or to wear, an ounce of foreign cloth is a crime against India and humanity.
('23', 7, 1, 8, 17716) I am able to restrain myself from committing suicide by starvation only because I have faith in India’s awakening, and her ability to put herself on the way to freedom from this desolating pauperism.
('23', 7, 1, 9, 17916) Without faith in such a possibility I should cease to take interest in living.
('23', 7, 1, 10, 17995) I invite the ques tioner, and every other intelligent lover of his country, to take part in this privileged national service in making spinning universal by introducing it in every home, and make it profitable for the nation by helping to bring about a complete boycott of foreign cloth during this year.
('23', 7, 1, 11, 18300) I have finished the questions and endeavoured to answer them.
('23', 7, 1, 12, 18362) The most important from the practical stand point was the one regarding spinning.
('23', 7, 1, 13, 18444) I hope I have demonstrated the necessity of home spinning as the only means of dealing with India’s poverty.
('23', 7, 1, 14, 18553) I know, however, that innumerable difficulties face a worker in putting the doctrine into execution.
('23', 7, 1, 15, 18654) The most difficult, perhaps, is that of getting a proper wheel.
('23', 7, 1, 16, 18718) Save in the Punjab where the art is still alive, the difficulty is very real.
('23', 7, 1, 17, 18796) The carpenters have forgotten the cons truction and the innocent workers are at their wit’s end.
('23', 7, 1, 18, 18893) The chief thing undoubtedly, therefore, is for the worker to make himself acquainted with the art and the handling of spinning wheels.
('23', 7, 1, 19, 19028) I lay down some simple tests for testing them.
('23', 7, 1, 20, 19075) No machine that fails to satisfy the tests should be accepted or distributed.
('23', 7, 1, 21, 19153) 1. The wheel must turn easily, freely, and noiselessly.
('23', 7, 1, 22, 19209) 2. The turning handle must be rigidly fixed to the axle.
('23', 7, 1, 23, 19266) 3. The posts must be properly driven home and joints well fixed.
('23', 7, 1, 24, 19331) 4. The spindle must turn noiselessly and without a throb in its holders.
('23', 7, 1, 25, 19404) Jarring sound cannot be avoided unless the holdersare made of knit straw as in the Punjab, or of tough leather.
('23', 7, 1, 26, 19516) 5. No machine is properly made unless it manufactures in the hands of a practised spinner at least 2_ tolas of even and properly twisted yarn of six counts in an hour.
('23', 7, 1, 27, 19684) I know a youngster, who has not had more than perhaps three months’ practice having been able to
('23', 8, 0, 1, 19781) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 9
('23', 8, 1, 2, 19821) spin 2_ tolas of the above quality of yarn in 35 minutes.
('23', 8, 1, 3, 19879) No machine should be given out until it has been worked for at least full one hour in the manner suggested, and found satisfactory.

('23', 8, 3, 5, 20033) 3. SPEECH AT CHIRALA
('23', 8, 4, 6, 20054) April 6, 1921
('23', 8, 5, 7, 20068) He said he was overwhelmed with joy for the unique kindness shown him throughout the Andhra Desh.
('23', 8, 5, 8, 20166) He said he himself had gone to jail a number of times in South Africa and each time he was discharged he felt sorry.
('23', 8, 5, 9, 20283) He was jealous of those who had the privilege of going to jail because he found greater freedom within the prison walls than under a system of Government which destroyed the spirit and manhood of man and denied him the ordinary nights.
('23', 8, 5, 10, 20519) He hoped that those who had gone to jail deserved the distinction.
('23', 8, 5, 11, 20586) He congratulated the women of Chirala on producing one lady at least who could go to jails.
('23', 8, 5, 12, 20678) 1 He congratulated them on the spirit of non violence that had marked their struggle.
('23', 8, 5, 13, 20764) His reading of the papers of the case—he had read every line of it led him to the conclusion that it was a good case.
('23', 8, 5, 14, 20882) In his opinion the Government grievously erred in imposing a municipality against the unanimous opinion of the people.
('23', 8, 5, 15, 21001) He knew their difficulties had just begun.
('23', 8, 5, 16, 21044) Only two courses were open to them as honourable men and women either to offer non co ope ration with civil disobedience or to perform hijrat as the Mussulmans would say, or Tulsidas would say desatyag 2. Both weapons were in his opinion equally powerful and
('23', 8, 6, 17, 21303) equally effective.
('23', 8, 6, 18, 21322) He asked them not to depend upon the support of the Congress, but rely on their own strong arm, that is, self suffering.
('23', 8, 6, 19, 21443) After paying a glowing tribute to their trusted leader, Mr. Dugirala Gopalakrishnayya 3, he exhorted them to realize the matchless beauty of non violence.
('23', 8, 6, 20, 21598) After referring to the spinning wheel as the life giver of India, he said: I shall follow the career of the men and women of Chirala with reverence.
('23', 8, 6, 21, 21747) You are on the threshold of a new age in the history of India.
('23', 8, 6, 22, 21810) The whole of India is looking on you.
('23', 8, 6, 23, 21848) It will be a shame if you go back on your word, if you make a single, vital blunder.
('23', 8, 6, 24, 21933) Observe non violence and with God as your witness defy the whole world.

('23', 9, 3, 4, 22382) While declaring the institution open, Mahatmaji exhorted the trustees of the institution that they should concentrate their attention and energy on the one important issue of the day, the attainment of swaraj, and said that spinning and weaving were the central factors of the Congress resolution.
('23', 9, 3, 5, 22680) He did not like the idea of the trustees raising subscriptions for this institution separately inasmuch as it would affect the important Tilak Swaraj Fund, which was recently started and which required a crore of rupees.
('23', 9, 3, 6, 22901) There should be only one activity for which there should be begging.
('23', 9, 3, 7, 22970) Therefore he advised the trustees to consult the president of the Provincial Congress Committee before embarking on any scheme.
('23', 9, 3, 8, 23098) Swaraj was not to be attained by any heroism but by disciplined thought and disciplined action.
('23', 9, 3, 9, 23194) He warned the trustees against the danger of putting fantastic educational schemes before the country.
('23', 9, 3, 10, 23297) There was no educational scheme before the country exept one and that was the attainment of swaraj.
('23', 9, 3, 11, 23397) He wished prosperity to the new institution.

('23', 9, 6, 16, 23624) I have also to ask for your forgiveness as I have not been able to come here in time; but I do not feel guilty about it.
('23', 9, 6, 17, 23745) Our sisters detained me longer than I had expected.
('23', 9, 6, 18, 23797) 3 It was quite possible for me to have come here directly from the ladies’ meeting, omitting my evening meal.
('23', 9, 6, 19, 23907) But I flattered myself with the belief that you would not have me to make such an indifferent choice.
('23', 9, 6, 20, 24009) I ask also for your forgiveness that I have not been able to visit Nellore earlier than now.
('23', 9, 6, 21, 24102) As soon as I heard that the Hindus and Mussulmans of Nellore were at sixes and sevens, I thought of coming and remaining in your midst for some time.
('23', 9, 6, 22, 24252) I wanted to know who those Hindus and who those

('23', 10, 1, 2, 24808) Mussulmans were who would rather quarrel amongst themselves and retard the attainment of swaraj and the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs.
('23', 10, 1, 3, 24959) You claim to have an ancient town, and I hope that you will not lag behind other parts of India and have it said of you and against you that the Hindus and Mussulmans of Nellore cannot live together as brothers.
('23', 10, 1, 4, 25171) But many things interfered with my desire to come here earlier than now.
('23', 10, 1, 5, 25244) I have endeavoured to ascertain the cause of the quarrel and you will forgive me for saying that the causes were not worse than rupture between the two great communities.
('23', 10, 1, 6, 25415) I understand that the Mussulmans of Nellore, or let me put it, the majority of the Mussulmans of Nellore, would not allow the Hindus to perform musical functions, to have musical processions passing by their mosques.
('23', 10, 1, 7, 25632) The Mohammedans contend that but a few years ago there was no such demand made by the Hindu population.
('23', 10, 1, 8, 25736) I have not known the Hindu case.
('23', 10, 1, 9, 25769) I have not come here to judge between my Hindu and Mussulman brethren.
('23', 10, 1, 10, 25840) But as an expert on Hindu and Muslim unity, I propose in all humility to place, for your conside ration and acceptance, certain fundamental principles on which, and on which alone, such a unity can remain everlasting.
('23', 10, 1, 11, 26058) As a Sanatana Dharma Hindu, feeling for my own faith, hoping that if the Faith was on its trial, I would be found in the front rank to give my life for its sake as a Sanatani Hindu, I wish first of all to address myself to my Hindu brethren, and would say: ‘If you would live in amity and friendship with the Mohammedan countrymen, the only way you can do so is never on any account to put a strain upon their religious fervour and always yield to them even though you may consider that their demands are unreasonable and unjust.
('23', 10, 1, 12, 26588) But there is a condition attached to that submission even to unreasonable demands and that condition is that their demands do not encroach upon the vital part of your religious tenets.’ I will take a homely illustration.
('23', 10, 1, 13, 26809) If my Moham medan countrymen demanded that I should cease to go to my temple, I would rather perish than concede that demand in order to buy that friendship.
('23', 10, 1, 14, 26967) Protection of the cow, I hold as dear as life itself and if my Mussulman brother asked me to waive protection of the cow, I again would perish rather than buy his friendship with the blood of my cow.
('23', 10, 1, 15, 27167) But when he tells me not to play music past his mosque within a few yards, I would not condescend to argue with him but immediately yield to him.
('23', 10, 1, 16, 27313) Hindus may take it from me that it is no part, no essential part, of Hinduism that we should play music at any time.
('23', 10, 1, 17, 27430) It is much less an essential part of my religion that I should play music,

('23', 11, 1, 2, 27546) instrumental or vocal, passing by a mosque.
('23', 11, 1, 3, 27590) I would not hesitate to agree to every such demand, to every such sentiment, to every such prejudice of my Mohammedan brethren.
('23', 11, 1, 4, 27718) And so, if I were a Hindu living in Nellore, I would not even allow a case of this character to go to arbitration; and only by agreeing with our Mussulman brethren on all non essentials and ceasing to subject them to pinpricks, we will be able to keep their friendship for ever.
('23', 11, 1, 5, 27997) And there can be no bargaining in friendship.
('23', 11, 1, 6, 28043) I yield to my Mussulman brethren in every non essen tial, because it is natural for me to do so, because my religion demands that I should live at peace with the whole world even at the sacrifice of my life.
('23', 11, 1, 7, 28251) And therefore, if the Hindus of Nellore were to ask me what they should do because they consider that the demand of the Mussulman brethren is unreasonable and unjust, I would say: ‘Do not argue but yield to that unreasonable and unjust demand.’ For if we were to engage in a discussion of such trivial quarrels, the world will set us down as children unfit to govern themselves, and you will, therefore, see quite clearly that it would be relevant for the Hindus to tell me that such a thing is really the case, that I have been misinformed, that only a few years ago the Hindus never claimed to play music, passing by mosques.
('23', 11, 1, 8, 28879) Such pleasures of religious life— because I call these things pleasures, agreeable pleasures—such pleasures of religious life I would hold at the mercy, at the grace of my Mohammedan brethren.
('23', 11, 1, 9, 29072) What is more, you Hindus are probably 42 to 45 thousand in Nellore.
('23', 11, 1, 10, 29140) Mussulmans are but seven thousand.
('23', 11, 1, 11, 29175) Hindus therefore as the elder brother are bound to hold the Mussul man interests as trustees.
('23', 11, 1, 12, 29269) Your nobility or title to swaraj demands that, as the stronger party, you should assume the privilege of protecting the weak.
('23', 11, 1, 13, 29395) To my Mohammedan brethren I would urge: ‘Never think of making any unreasonable demands.
('23', 11, 1, 14, 29484) Make it your business to study the prejudices and sentiments of your Hindu brethren.
('23', 11, 1, 15, 29569) Make allowances for what you may consider to be their weaknesses.
('23', 11, 1, 16, 29635) God will not hold you answerable on the Judgment Day if He finds that you allowed yourself in your prayers in the mosque to be interrupted by some music that you heard.
('23', 11, 1, 17, 29804) I have not the shadow of a doubt that God Almighty whom you call also Rahim 1, will understand your humble and gentle plea when you tell Him on the Judgment Day that you could not help it, because you wanted to respect your Hindu brothers’ prejudices.
('23', 11, 1, 18, 30056) The test for friendship, the test for brotherhood

('23', 12, 1, 2, 30171) is that each party always makes allowances for the weaknesses of the other and I know that on the Judgment Day that party will win the day which will be able to show that it has always surrendered on non essentials.
('23', 12, 1, 3, 30387) The life of the great Prophet is for you as a living example of a perpetual surrender of non essentials.’ But I say to the Hindu and Mussulman brethren of Nellore, whether they can agree about their differences or not, whether they can make concessions to one another or not, whether they can come to an agreement on essentials and non essentials or not, it is not given to them, not to a Jingle Hindu or to a single Mussulman to fly at each other’s throats, to throw stones at one another, and to inflict violence on one another.
('23', 12, 1, 4, 30918) They must have trusted, chosen leaders of each community to form a Board of Arbitration to settle all religious disputes between the two, and if they are not satisfied, they can either go to the Congress or to the Khilafat Committee for a settlement.
('23', 12, 1, 5, 31169) And finally I would repeat the advice that Maulana Shaukat Ali has been giving times without number both to the Mussulmans and Hindus.
('23', 12, 1, 6, 31304) When a Mohammedan feels irritated and angry with his Hindu neighbours and when he cannot restrain himself and feels that he must inflict condign punish ment on his Hindu brethren, then he must go to Mahatma Gandhi and cut off his head.
('23', 12, 1, 7, 31540) Similarly he advised the Hindus that if the Hindus felt irritated against the Mussulman neighbours and wanted to pick a quarrel with them, they should not lay their hands upon the Mussulman neighbours but they should go to Shaukat Ali himself; although he is strong and burly, he makes that definite promise that even a Hindu child may take his head from his shoulders.
('23', 12, 1, 8, 31910) Let Hindus and Mussulmans understand firmly that the cornerstone of swaraj, the cornerstone of the freedom of India is Hindu and Muslim unity.
('23', 12, 1, 9, 32053) Let both understand that the defence of Islam with reference to the Khilafat through the power of India is only possible if Hindu Muslim unity becomes a living factor in their life.
('23', 12, 1, 10, 32235) Let Hindus understand that their full contribution, their unconditional hearty contribution to the defence of Islam automatically carries with it the defence of Hinduism itself.

('23', 13, 1, 2, 32823) firm determination to use all that united, matchless power for the freedom of India, for the freedom of Islam, for retrieving the honour of the Punjab.
('23', 13, 1, 3, 32975) Both Hindus and Mussulmans have told me in the course of the day that this wretched petty quarrel has resulted in all non cooperation activity and Khilafat activity not being conducted and carried through to the extent that it was possible for Nellore to do.
('23', 13, 1, 4, 33234) I hope, therefore, that you will not allow the sun to rise upon you before you have settled your differences and I hope that from tomorrow morning you will set about as thinking, wise business men to work out the programme that has been sketched for you by the All India Congress Committee, that you will continue to contribute to the Tilak Swaraj Fund that you have commenced today; that you will not rest satisfied until you have placed on the Congress register every adult male and female, Hindu or Mussulman.

('23', 13, 1, 7, 34045) I would ask you not to fall back upon Ahmedabad or Bombay for your clothes, but make it a point of honour to become self sustained by manufacturing all the cloth for your local needs.
('23', 13, 1, 8, 34229) Take it again from me, as an experienced spinner and weaver, that it is entirely possible for the 52,000 men and women of Nellore to produce all your cloth in the course of a month.
('23', 13, 1, 9, 34411) Within one night one weaver was able to produce sufficient cloth for me to last for one year and that sacred cloth produced last night is in my possession and I am proud of it.
('23', 13, 1, 10, 34588) 1 And so I ask you to divert your attention from your internal Hindu and Muslim dissensions or any other dissension and concentrate that attention on the main issue before the whole nation.
('23', 13, 1, 11, 34778) Banish all drink, gambling and falsehoods and all vices in your midst and live up to the profession made in your name and my name in that, this battle of non co operation is a battle of self purification.

('23', 13, 1, 14, 35100) There are full five precious days in store for us.
('23', 13, 1, 15, 35151) Let us make the best use of these five days.
('23', 13, 1, 16, 35196) I would ask you during these five days specially to cultivate friendship between yourselves, Hindus and Mussulmans.

('23', 15, 1, 3, 37710) The more I think of the salvation of India—economic, political, moral, religious—the more I think of the Khilafat question, the more I am convinced that if the Khilafat wrong is to be redressed through India, through the Hindus and Mussulmans of India, if India is to gain swaraj during this year, at least we owe it to the motherland that we discard the use of foreign cloth, no matter at what cost.
('23', 15, 1, 4, 38111) As Maulana Mahomed Ali in one of his recent speeches in Calcutta remarked: “A hundred years ago or more we sold away the spinning wheel and we purchased our slavery.” And I want therefore to invite your attention to the most potent part of the resolution arrived at by the All India Congress Committee 1 after the programme of Non co operation had worked for so many months.
('23', 15, 1, 5, 38486) If we want one crore of rupees before the 30th June, we want it not in order to promote deputations to England or America or any part of the world, not for any foreign propaganda, but we want that money and more for introducing the spinning wheel into every home in India.
('23', 15, 1, 6, 38759) We want that money in order to pay a mere livelihood to the workers who will come out throughout the length and breadth of Dravid land 2 to introduce the spinning wheel.
('23', 15, 1, 7, 38929) Only the other day I was in Masulipatam and I had the honour of visiting a few villages where even today our sisters are spinning beautiful fine yarn not for money but for love.

I therefore hope that if you are going to be instrumental in attaining swaraj during this year, in redressing the Khilafat wrong and the Punjab wrong, you will make during this sacred National Week a fixed derermination to throw away all the foreign cloth that you may possess.

('23', 20, 4, 12, 51606) GOPABANDHU DAS
('23', 20, 5, 13, 51621) At the time of the famine in Orissa, I realized the poverty of the province but my impression has been that nowhere else were the people likely to be so poor as in Champaran 2. But I am afraid Orissa beats Champaran in this respect.
('23', 20, 5, 14, 51854) The difference between the two is that in Champaran the ryots had been impoverished by the oppression of the indigo planters, whereas in Orissa the suffering is due to the wrath of Nature.
('23', 20, 5, 15, 52043) Either the crops do not grow through lack of rains or there are floods following excessive rains and the crops and houses are washed off, hence there is always a near famine in this province.
('23', 20, 5, 16, 52235) In this godforsaken region, the one real leader is Gopabandhu Das, who gave all help to Shri Amritlal Thakkar at the time of the famine.

('23', 26, 4, 16, 65913) 10. NOTES
('23', 26, 5, 17, 65923) SUSPEND NON CO OPERATION
('23', 26, 6, 18, 65948) Mr. Syed Riza Ali has addressed a public letter advising me to suspend Non co operation, so as to give Lord Reading 2 a chance of studying the situation in a calm atmosphere.
('23', 26, 6, 19, 66123) In the first place, I see there is nothing in the atmosphere to prevent a study of the situation.
('23', 26, 6, 20, 66221) In the second place, what disturbance there is, is either fomented by the authorities, or the situation is so mishandled as to give rise to bloodshed.
('23', 26, 6, 21, 66372) In the Central Provinces the Government are foisting the drink traffic on a public that is enraged against it.
('23', 26, 6, 22, 66483) Of Rae Bareilly, not having read newspapers, I have not sufficient data to be able to say anything.
('23', 26, 6, 23, 66583) In any case, Mr. Riza Ali should address his appeal to the permanent officials who are provoking the people and creating alarm in the country.
('23', 26, 6, 24, 66726) Thirdly, it is not within the power of any one man, even if he wished it, to suspend a movement adopted by the nation through its representative assemblies.

('23', 49, 3, 4, 120067) For me, there can be decorations, presents and medals of khadi alone.

('23', 49, 3, 9, 120477) You have given me just an empty purse; and a still greater crime is that it is all made of foreign material.
('23', 49, 3, 10, 120586) 3 Its dye is foreign, its yarn is foreign, the silk thread in it is foreign.
('23', 49, 3, 11, 120663) Then what is swadeshi in it?
('23', 49, 3, 12, 120692) I claim to be a leader of the swadeshi movement and I should know what is swadeshi and what is not swadeshi.
('23', 49, 3, 13, 120801) The beauty of my defini tion of swadeshi is that if we follow such swadeshi, nobody can prevail over us.
('23', 49, 3, 14, 120906) Swadeshi for Halol is what is made in Halol itself.
('23', 49, 3, 15, 120958) Anything made anywhere else in India must be unacceptable to it.
('23', 49, 3, 16, 121023) We, all of us, should be self sufficient and should compete for the first place.
('23', 49, 3, 17, 121104) We shall get swaraj when we vie with one another with ever greater vigour in this matter.
('23', 49, 3, 18, 121194) This is the key to swaraj.
('23', 49, 3, 19, 121221) I cannot bear to see the decorations here in the town.

('23', 49, 3, 21, 121334) Instead, such cloth is hung up all round.

('23', 49, 3, 25, 121668) We shall make progress towards swaraj only if we do everything thoughtfully and with understanding.

('23', 49, 3, 28, 121941) If you cannot afford to buy new khadi, I am ready to give you khadi to replace your duck cloth.

('23', 52, 1, 2, 126967) 20. NOTES
('23', 52, 2, 3, 126977) LANGUAGE AND THOUGHT It is rarely that language succeeds as a vehicle of thought.
('23', 52, 2, 4, 127059) More of ten than not it conceals thought.
('23', 52, 2, 5, 127101) Always language circumscribes thought.When, especially, a person translates from another’s language, what difficulties are experienced and howlers perpetrated only trans lators and journa lists know.
('23', 52, 2, 6, 127301) We have been in such difficulties time and again.
('23', 52, 2, 7, 127351) We publi shed Shri Vamanrao Joshi’s statement 1 in bold type on the front page.
('23', 52, 2, 8, 127431) When we read the printed translation, we our selves felt ashamed.
('23', 52, 2, 9, 127497) We felt we had done an injustice to this brave man, or, rather, to readers.
('23', 52, 2, 10, 127573) The message seemed to go against the ideas and methods which we wish to see prevail.
('23', 52, 2, 11, 127658) The translation we printed was from English.
('23', 52, 2, 12, 127703) Shri Vaman rao’s original message was of course in Marathi.
('23', 52, 2, 13, 127763) The objectionable element we find in our translation is not present in the original at all.
('23', 52, 2, 14, 127855) “It is not our business to reveal our own shame in public”—is the view we have attributed to Shri Vaman rao.
('23', 52, 2, 15, 127964) 2 Our courage lies in being ever ready to expose our shame.
('23', 52, 2, 16, 128024) Shri Vamanrao wishes to cloak the people’s shame by himself displaying courage and not by leaving that shame unexposed.
('23', 52, 2, 17, 128144) By hiding their shame the people become emasculated, just as a disease grows by being concealed.
('23', 52, 2, 18, 128241) If one Indian apprehends another and a third punishes the latter, there is no shame in this at all.
('23', 52, 2, 19, 128341) There may be some thing to be ashamed of in the occasion itself.
('23', 52, 2, 20, 128406) When, however, swaraj is established, an Indian policeman will arrest an Indian who has committed a crime and the latter will be punished by an Indian judge.
('23', 52, 2, 21, 128564) That will not seem shameful; in fact, it will be normal and accepted as such.
('23', 52, 2, 22, 128642) Shri Vamanrao has made his remarks with reference to the present situation.
('23', 52, 2, 23, 128718) He has pointed to and exposed our shame in an Indian serving [the Gove rnment] for the sake of the belly, ever the cause of so many sins, arresting another innocent Indian, and in a judge, in the same position as the first Indian, sentencing the latter.
('23', 52, 2, 24, 128972) But it pains us that we could not bring out in our translation all this

('23', 54, 1, 2, 131187) 22. SPEECH AT MEETING IN GODHRA April 18, 1921 The main reason why we have become the Bhangis of this Empire, this Government, is that our Vaishnavas 1 and Shaivas 2 who call themselves orthodox sanatanis 3 behave like beasts towards the Bhangis and oppress them.
('23', 54, 1, 3, 131451) The Bhangis are our kith and kin, our blood brothers.
('23', 54, 1, 4, 131505) We accept their service and do not even pay them adequate wages, so that they are obliged to live on the remains on our plates which we offer them and are driven to eat carrion.
('23', 54, 1, 5, 131683) As for service, I do not think that a lawyer, a doctor or a collector serves soceity a whit more than a Bhangi.
('23', 54, 1, 6, 131795) The Bhangis’ services surely rank much higher than the services of these.
('23', 54, 1, 7, 131869) If the former were to stop serving, what would be the plight of society?
('23', 54, 1, 8, 131942) The calamity taht has befallen us is the reward of the sin we have committed against the Antyajas 4. The punishment for our sin has to be shared by the Muslims because they are our neighbours.
('23', 54, 1, 9, 132135) Many Hindus cite Shastras for avoiding contact with the Bhangis.
('23', 54, 1, 10, 132200) I tell you, however, if there is any Shastra which says that it is sin to touch a Bhangi, it is no Shastra.
('23', 54, 1, 11, 132308) A Shastra can never be beyond the power of reason to under stand, something which disregards truth.
('23', 54, 1, 12, 132408) For the rest, the Shastras may be interpreted in any way one chooses.
('23', 54, 1, 13, 132478) What do we not do in the name of the Shastras?
('23', 54, 1, 14, 132525) In their name, mendicants consume bhang and smoke ganja; in the name of the Shastras, some devotees of a goddess consume mutton and wine and numberless people indulge in immoral practices; in the name of the Shastras, in the Madras Presidency, girls of tender age are forced to become prostitutes.
('23', 54, 1, 15, 132823) What greater travesty of the Shastras can there be than this?
('23', 54, 1, 16, 132885) I regard myself an orthodox Vaishnava; I believe in the Varnashrama 5 way of life.
('23', 54, 1, 17, 132968) But I tell you, the idea that one gets polluted by touching a Bhangi is an excrescence on Hinduism, a kind of dirt which has settled on it.
('23', 54, 1, 18, 133108) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 5 1921
('23', 54, 2, 19, 133144) 1 Devotees of Vishnu, the Preserver in the Hindu Trinity, and His incarnation, Krishna 2 Devotees of Siva, the Destroyer in the Hindu Trinity 3 Hindus who accept the essentials of Hinduism as unalterable, the division of society into four castes being one of them 4 Literally “last born”, communities of untouchables in general 5 The organization of society into four castes, each with a distinctive function, and the division of life into four stages

('23', 55, 1, 2, 133637) 23. REPLY TO WELCOME ADDRESS BY SURAT MUNICIPALITY April 19, 1921 I must say that just as not every man can eat or digest a rich dish, I wonder whether I can digest the glowing praises showered on me.
('23', 55, 1, 3, 133838) Some day, perhaps, I shall deserve them.
('23', 55, 1, 4, 133879) I am doing my best in that direction.
('23', 55, 1, 5, 133917) I have been striving to be able to vanquish untruth with truth and anger by refusing to oppose it with anger, and I wish that I should lay down my life in the effort.
('23', 55, 1, 6, 134084) But, at present, the epithets you have applied to me are misplaced.
('23', 55, 1, 7, 134152) If, hearing them, I become in different or overbearing or smugly assume that I already deserve them because people have offered them to me, immediately my degradation would begin.
('23', 55, 1, 8, 134332) My effort should be, above everything else, to maintain humility and see that I do not transgress the limits of properiety.
('23', 55, 1, 9, 134456) The country’s good and mine lie in my working with this vigilance.
('23', 55, 1, 10, 134523) Your giving me a welcome address bespeaks the marvellous awa kening in the country.
('23', 55, 1, 11, 134607) It only means that the Municipality has realized its role.
('23', 55, 1, 12, 134666) I hope to get much work for the country done through munici palities.
('23', 55, 1, 13, 134736) And that is the reason why, in the resolutions adopted at the last two sessions of the Congress, 1 municipalities have not been asked to join the non co operation movement.
('23', 55, 1, 14, 134909) Being what they are, the munici palities involve some element of co operation, but then, at present, there is not a single thing of ours which is free from it.
('23', 55, 1, 15, 135069) There is co operation even in eating one single grain of wheat.
('23', 55, 1, 16, 135133) The non co operation we are employing at present is so light that even a child can shoulder its burden.
('23', 55, 1, 17, 135237) If we can carry out intensive non co operation, it has such miraculous power that we can get swaraj in a day.
('23', 55, 1, 18, 135347) But I have taken care to put before the country only a simple form of non co operation which the country will have strength enough to carry out, and every municipality can join it.
('23', 55, 1, 19, 135528) If the muni cipalities in the country understand this and organize whatever work they can do, swaraj will be easy to win.
('23', 55, 1, 20, 135650) As regards what this Municipality can do, all I have to say is, keep the promise you have given to make an effort to act upon the advice of the Congress.
('23', 55, 1, 21, 135804) Gird up your loins for the removal of untouchability.
('23', 55, 1, 22, 135858) I have mentioned this first, leaving aside the spinning wheel.
('23', 55, 1, 23, 135921) The latter represents the supreme task to which we should bend all our efforts, but there is a still more important task for the Hindus,

('23', 56, 1, 4, 136341) Last night I went to the Bhangi quarters in Godhra.

('23', 61, 1, 2, 146628) 25. THE MISTS
('23', 61, 2, 3, 146642) Whenever I find my friends misunderstanding the movement, I mutter to myself the words of a celebrated hymn: “We shall know each other better when the mists have rolled away.” A friend has just sent me the paragraphs on non co operation in the Servant of India of the 14th instant.
('23', 61, 2, 4, 146924) It is such a fruitless task explaining resolutions and motives.
('23', 61, 2, 5, 146988) The year will soon pass away and our actions, more than words, will demonstrate the meaning of non co operation.
('23', 61, 2, 6, 147101) For me non co operation is not suspended, and never will be, so long as the Government has not purged itself of the crimes against India—the Mussulmans and the Punjabis, and so long as the system is not changed to respond to the will of the nation.
('23', 61, 2, 7, 147350) Surely it was necessary to remove the hallucination about titles, law courts, schools and Councils.
('23', 61, 2, 8, 147450) I venture to think that, on the whole, the nationalists have responded nobly in regard to these items.
('23', 61, 2, 9, 147553) There are no titled men among them, no nationalist lawyer who has not supended practice has any public status among non co operators, schools and colleges have furnished boys and girls who are now giving a good account of themselves and who, I make bold so say, will stagger humanity by their sacrifice when the time of their trial has arrived.
('23', 61, 2, 10, 147898) Those who have refrained from entering the Councils are rendering, as all who care may see, a service which they could not have rendered in the Council halls.
('23', 61, 2, 11, 148057) The few who have given up their titles have shown the way to the others.
('23', 61, 2, 12, 148130) All these are acting as leaven in the community.
('23', 61, 2, 13, 148179) Now, there is little need for verbal propaganda among these special classes.
('23', 61, 2, 14, 148256) The action and character of those who have renounced titles, schools, courts or Councils constitute a propaganda more telling and effective than speeches.
('23', 61, 2, 15, 148411) National schools are multi plying themselves, boys are still leaving schools and colleges.
('23', 61, 2, 16, 148502) The Government statistics are hopelessly wrong.
('23', 61, 2, 17, 148550) I remember having seen a councillor quoting that less than 3,000 students had left educational institutions.
('23', 61, 2, 18, 148659) This takes no count of thousands who are studying in nationalized schools.
('23', 61, 2, 19, 148734) The number of suspensions of practice is steadily growing—see the list of suspensions in Dharwar and Guntur given in another column.
('23', 61, 2, 20, 148867) Even titles are still being surrendered.
('23', 61, 2, 21, 148908) And as the timid or the cautious realized that the movement is a serious and a religious effort, that it has taken permanent hold of the people, they too will renounce.

('23', 64, 1, 2, 154281) 26. DIVIDE AND RULE
('23', 64, 2, 3, 154301) Sir William Vincent’s 1 speech before the Legislative Assembly makes painful reading.
('23', 64, 2, 4, 154387) I shall hope that he has been kept in utter darkness by his informants and that the speech is ignorant, not unscrupulous.
('23', 64, 2, 5, 154509) It is a plausible defence of the Government’s policy of repre ssion.
('23', 64, 2, 6, 154578) It is a distortion or concoction of facts.
('23', 64, 2, 7, 154621) It is an appeal to our cupidity and a misinterpretation of the motives of non co opera tionists.
('23', 64, 2, 8, 154718) He says that the declared object of non co operationists is paralysis of the Government and that “in their effort to achieve the object there is no source of discontent which they have not used”.
('23', 64, 2, 9, 154914) Now both these statements are half truths.
('23', 64, 2, 10, 154957) The primary object of non co operation is nowhere stated to be paralysis of the Government.
('23', 64, 2, 11, 155049) The primary object is self purification.
('23', 64, 2, 12, 155090) Its direct result must be paralysis of a Government which lives on our vices and weaknesses.
('23', 64, 2, 13, 155183) Similarly, it is a dangerous half truth to say that we have left no source of discontent unused.
('23', 64, 2, 14, 155280) We could not help using sources of legitimate discontent.
('23', 64, 2, 15, 155338) But non co operationists have rigidly refrained from using any and every discontent, if only because we would weaken our cause if we did.
('23', 64, 2, 16, 155476) The illustration of what I mean will be best seen from the refutation of the very next sentence which Sir William has spoken in support of his contention: “Wherever they find discord between employer and employee, there some agent of emissary of non co operation party proceeds at once to foster discontent and promote ill feeling.” This is not only untrue, but it is an incitement to the two to oppose non co operation.
('23', 64, 2, 17, 155897) The avowed policy of non co operation has been not to make political use of disputes between labour and capital.
('23', 64, 2, 18, 156010) They have endeavoured to hold the balance evenly between the two—we would be fools if we wantonly set labour against capital.
('23', 64, 2, 19, 156136) It would be just the way to play into the hands of a Government which would greatly strengthen its hold on the country by setting capitalists against labourers and vice versa.
('23', 64, 2, 20, 156312) In Jharia, for instance, it was a non co operator who prevented an extending strike.
('23', 64, 2, 21, 156397) The moderating influence in Calcutta was that of non co operators.
('23', 64, 2, 22, 156464) The latter will not hesitate to advance the cause of strikers where they have a just

('23', 80, 1, 2, 189667) 34. SOME DOUBTS
('23', 80, 2, 3, 189683) My letter about the Parsis had led of quite a lot of controversy.
('23', 80, 2, 4, 189749) Mr. G. K. Nariman has written an open letter which has appeared in other papers.
('23', 80, 2, 5, 189830) Those who have been taking interest in the discussion must have read it and hence I do not publish it in Navajivan.
('23', 80, 2, 6, 189946) The views expressed by Mr. Nariman deserve respectful consideration and the doubts raised in his letter probably occur to other Parsis too.
('23', 80, 2, 7, 190086) Hence, I shall try to answer them.
('23', 80, 2, 8, 190121) Mr. Nariman has given the following reasons or the Parsis not joining non co operation.
('23', 80, 2, 9, 190209) 1. We cannot do without the services of Englishmen for several years more.
('23', 80, 2, 10, 190284) 2. I should try to get many more Hindus to join the movement before wanting Parsis to do so.
('23', 80, 2, 11, 190377) 3. To hope to win swaraj through the spinning wheel is like running after a mirage.
('23', 80, 2, 12, 190461) 4. When men like Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, Shastriar 1, and Sir Dinshaw Wachha 2 oppose the non co operation movement, what can the ordinary Parsi do ?

('23', 81, 1, 2, 191675) REPLY TO FIRST DOUBT Our degradation consists in this very idea that we cannot do without Englishmen for some time yet to come, and swaraj lies in getting rid of it.
('23', 81, 1, 3, 191841) In what sense were we in a miserable stage before the coming of the British?
('23', 81, 1, 4, 191918) To think, besides, that the moment they leave we shall fight among ourselves is a humiliating idea.
('23', 81, 1, 5, 192018) Suppose, how ever, that the fear is justified; we still ought to free ourselves from British tutelage even at the risk of civil war.
('23', 81, 2, 6, 192151) REPLY TO SECOND DOUBT The statement that I should first induce many more Hindus to join the movement before expecting the Parsis to do so bespeaks our weakness.
('23', 81, 2, 7, 192312) Both Parsis and Hindus are Indians.
('23', 81, 2, 8, 192348) The thoughtful among both these communities owe the same duty to India.
('23', 81, 2, 9, 192420) Moreover, many Hindus have already joined the movement and efforts to persuade others to join it are certainly continuing.
('23', 81, 2, 10, 192543) Parsis should join the movement even if not a single Hindu were to join it or if they themselves should be convinced of its need, before others are.
('23', 81, 2, 11, 192692) A person who is himself convinced should not wait for others [to join].
('23', 81, 3, 12, 192764) REPLY TO THIRD DOUBT I admit that anyone who thinks that to hope for swaraj through the spinning wheel is to run after a mirage can never approve of the non co operation movement.
('23', 81, 3, 13, 192944) Gradually, India has begun to under stand the truth and it is my faith that it will understand it better still.
('23', 81, 3, 14, 193056) I certainly do not think that it is running after a mirage to believe that we shall be prosperous only if we return to the dharma which we have forsaken and by forsaking which we have been impoverished.
('23', 81, 3, 15, 193259) It is being daily confirmed by experience that the spinning wheel is our natural dharma.
('23', 81, 3, 16, 193348) I consider it no sin to go back to the condition which existed two hundred or even two thousand years ago.
('23', 81, 3, 17, 193455) It is evidence of our having exercised our judgment if we adopt again the wholesome practices which we may have given up either through ignorance or under compulsion or through sheer passage of time.
('23', 81, 4, 18, 193655) REPLY TO FOURTH DOUBT It is indeed sad that Panditji and other big leaders have not joined this movement.
('23', 81, 4, 19, 193761) When, however, leaders differ among them selves, the people must make their choice.
('23', 81, 4, 20, 193845) If they believe that nothing should be done until all are of the same view, they can never make progress.
('23', 81, 4, 21, 193951) Under swaraj, everyone will have to make a choice.

('23', 82, 1, 2, 194043) REPLY TO FIFTH DOUBT It is possible that I may not understand the Khilafat issue, though I have certainly studied it to the best of my ability.
('23', 82, 1, 3, 194187) I do not believe that there is an irreconcilable conflict between Islam and Hinduism.
('23', 82, 1, 4, 194273) If there is, it means that Hindus and Muslims must remain enemies for ever.
('23', 82, 1, 5, 194349) I do not believe that it is right for any two groups of human beings to remain mutually hostile for ever.

('23', 82, 1, 7, 194581) I do not know that any religious was has taken place after the Crusades.
('23', 82, 1, 8, 194654) I have seen nothing in Africa to suggest to me that the Muslims should have no control over Jazirat ul Arab 1.
('23', 82, 2, 9, 194765) REPLY TO SIXTH DOUBT I know that there is no exaggeration in my views about the Punjab.

('23', 82, 2, 15, 195346) There is religion only to the extent that there is compassion.
('23', 82, 2, 16, 195409) There can be no limit to compassion and it is not for me to lay down any.
('23', 82, 2, 17, 195483) Everyone fixes a limit for himself .
('23', 82, 2, 18, 195520) In Vaishnavism, non violence reigns supreme.
('23', 82, 2, 19, 195565) I concede that the idea is elaborated with special emphasis in Jain works, but neither the Jain nor any other docrine has a monopoly of non violence.
('23', 82, 2, 20, 195715) It is a universal, immutable law.

('23', 82, 2, 22, 195890) But there is certainly no need to discuss here the extreme implications of non violence.
('23', 82, 2, 23, 195979) Even if non violence in such form is not accepted , it cannot be gainsaid that our duty in the present circumstances is to fight peacefully—through voluntary suffering.

('23', 83, 1, 2, 196377) non violence and, at the same time, characterized my activity as conductive to violence shows that he has not understood the principle of non violence.
('23', 83, 1, 3, 196529) He seems to suggest that the preaching of non co operation spreads hatred and that the loss which people suffer through strikes is a form of violence.
('23', 83, 1, 4, 196680) The essential point of non violence is to bear no hatred towards the man who has perpetrated violence, though we know what he has done.
('23', 83, 1, 5, 196816) I cannot purge the people of the violence in their hearts by hiding from them the Punjab outrages or the Khilafat wrong.
('23', 83, 1, 6, 196937) My duty is, while telling them of the massacre, to teach them to be peaceful.
('23', 83, 1, 7, 197015) The suffering which strikes cause to some is not violence.
('23', 83, 1, 8, 197074) One is not responsible for the suffering one may cause to others while doing one's duty.

('23', 83, 1, 10, 197272) He, too, benefits through the suffering caused to him.
('23', 83, 1, 11, 197327) Non co operation means refusal both to help the sinner in his sin and to accept any help or gift from him till he has repented.
('23', 83, 2, 12, 197455) REPLY TO EIGHTH DOUBT Mr. Nariman seems to believe that no propaganda is being done against the use of opium, etc.

('23', 84, 2, 19, 200307) 35. EXPERIENCES IN GUJARAT
('23', 84, 3, 20, 200334) I have been having so many experiences that I do not have time enough to set them all down and have to omit a good many of them.
('23', 84, 3, 21, 200463) The workers, being eager to get the utmost out of me during the short time [I am with them], allow me no solitude or quiet for writing.
('23', 84, 3, 22, 200599) There is no limit to their greed.
('23', 84, 3, 23, 200633) I, too, am over eager to render service.
('23', 84, 3, 24, 200674) I want to do as much as possible, explain things as much as I can ; hence I am not able to place all my experiences before the reader.
('23', 84, 3, 25, 200809) Till the time of writing, I have visited Anand, Ras, Borsad, Halol, Kalol, Vejalpur, Godhra, Surat, Olpad and Rander.
('23', 84, 3, 26, 200927) There is no end to the enthusiasm of the people everywhere.
('23', 84, 3, 27, 200987) At every place, the meetings were attended by large numbers of men and women.
('23', 84, 3, 28, 201065) I saw increased spinning wheel activity in all the places.
('23', 84, 3, 29, 201124) In almost every town or village, people contributed to the Tilak Swaraj Fund.

('23', 85, 1, 2, 201243) A WIDOW'S GIFT
('23', 85, 2, 3, 201258) A widow in Anand gave away a bar of gold, weighing about 25 tolas, which she had with her.
('23', 85, 2, 4, 201349) This, from a widow, is a gift indeed.
('23', 85, 2, 5, 201387) I asked the lady her name.
('23', 85, 2, 6, 201414) She refused to give it.
('23', 85, 2, 7, 201438) What need to give one's name and address for money donated for a holy cause ?
('23', 85, 2, 8, 201516) I did not have the courage to ask any more questions.
('23', 85, 2, 9, 201570) A CONDITIONAL DONATION According to her wont, Mrs. Kothawala attended the meeting at Godhra.
('23', 85, 2, 10, 201663) She told me that she liked all my activities except non co operation and asked me to give a chance to Lord Reading.
('23', 85, 2, 11, 201779) I said: “I certainly desire to give a chance to everyone.
('23', 85, 2, 12, 201837) Lord Reading has only to do justice to get co operation.
('23', 85, 2, 13, 201894) Persuade him yourself that he should repent, apologize to the country for the crimes committed and do justice.
('23', 85, 2, 14, 202005) No dispute will remain then.” “Tell me that you will give him a chance.
('23', 85, 2, 15, 202077) Will you write to him and tell him that you will withdraw non co operation if he does justice?” I said: “I shall certainly do so when an opportunity offers itself.
('23', 85, 2, 16, 202241) But Lord Reading knows as much.” On this condition, this good lady gave me Rs. 50. If only, on that condition, all women give as much, I think a crore of rupees will be collected immediately.
('23', 85, 2, 17, 202433) ORDERLINESS I have been noticing increasing orderliness at all places, but I found it most in Surat.
('23', 85, 2, 18, 202534) Wherever we went, we found that the programme could be carried out with the least noise and hustle, as the people had been instructed beforehand.
('23', 85, 2, 19, 202680) The people having been told in advance, contributions were also collected [before the meeting started].
('23', 85, 2, 20, 202784) Women in Surat donated even their diamond rings.
('23', 85, 2, 21, 202833) EXPERIENCE AT RANDER While the Surat Municipality gave me an address of welcome, I came to know that the Rander Municipality had not agreed to give one.
('23', 85, 2, 22, 202986) All the same, Hindu and Muslim youths took courage and presented addresses, one on behalf of the citizens and another on behalf of the Khilafat [Committee] .
('23', 85, 2, 23, 203144) The streets, too, were decorated.
('23', 85, 2, 24, 203178) Still, I could see that the leaders there had kept away.
('23', 85, 2, 25, 203235) They showed only as much interest as one would expect children to do.
('23', 85, 2, 26, 203305) I tried hard, but in such an atmosphere I could collect very little at Rander.

('23', 87, 3, 16, 207501) I wish to assure these critics that there is no deliberate attempt to make the language difficult.

('23', 87, 3, 21, 207890) I consider it my duty to make Navajivan easy for them to read.

('23', 89, 5, 10, 210284) 40. NOTES
('23', 89, 6, 11, 210294) SATYAGRAHA IN MULSHI My heart goes out to these poor people.
('23', 89, 6, 12, 210355) 2 I wish the great house of the Tatas, instead of standing on their legal rights, will reason with the people themselves, and do whatever they wish in consultation with them.
('23', 89, 6, 13, 210530) I have some experience of Land Acquisition Acts.
('23', 89, 6, 14, 210579) I had nearly eighty cases to deal with.
('23', 89, 6, 15, 210619) Here the reason for the acquisition was not industrial development but insanitation.

('23', 96, 3, 18, 227463) TO THE EDITOR Young India
('23', 96, 5, 19, 227489) Mr. Gandhi made some remarks regarding Brahmins and non Brahmins in the course of his lecture at the Beach in Madras last Friday.
('23', 96, 5, 20, 227619) His speech has caused great pain to the non Brahmin nationalists of Madras.
('23', 96, 5, 21, 227695) It would have been highly preferable if Mr. Gandhi had not at all touched on this point; for from his speech it was evident that he was completely ignorant of Dravidian civilization, religion, culture, and the inner meaning and causes of the present non Brahmin movement.
('23', 96, 5, 22, 227967) He does not seem to have recognized the special features of Dravidian civilization which marks off South India from the rest of India.
('23', 96, 5, 23, 228102) In praising the Brahmins for their contribution to the religion and civilization of India (probably he means North India), he has involuntarily cast a slur on the non Brahmins whose ancestors have also contributed as much as, if not more than, the Brahmins to the glory of South India as seen in their literature, religion, and philosophy.
('23', 96, 6, 24, 228442) It need hardly be pointed out that nothing can offend a whole community like a slur of the above kind, even though it may be done unwittingly by one whose heart is overflowing with love, and for whom the community has the highest regard.
('23', 96, 6, 25, 228680) Further,
('23', 97, 0, 1, 228689) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 97, 1, 2, 228730) the object of Mr. Gandhi's recent visit and proposed long tour in the South in the middle of the next month is, we may take it, to strengthen the cause, and propagate the movement of non co operation.
('23', 97, 2, 3, 228931) Surely, making hasty and flippant remarks about a highly vexed question is likely to weaken the cause he advocates and estrange the sympathies of a vast majority of the masses who feel strongly on the movematter.
('23', 97, 3, 4, 229144) If he really wants to bridge the gulf unhappily widening between the Brahmins and non Brahmins of South India, let Mr. Gandhi take up the question in right earnest with an entirely blank and open mind, and then he may in all probability be in a position, after careful study, to find out a solution for the problem.
('23', 97, 3, 5, 229460) Otherwise he will do well in the interest of the great non co operation movement to leave severely alone the Brahmin and non Brahmin controversy in the course of his forthcoming long tour in South India.

('23', 101, 1, 2, 237507) 44. MY NOTES
('23', 101, 2, 3, 237520) MAKING HARTALS CHEAP There seems to be an epidemic of hartals.
('23', 101, 2, 4, 237583) Karachi, especially, has crossed the limit.
('23', 101, 2, 5, 237627) Five hartals in a month!
('23', 101, 2, 6, 237652) It is a hartal if someone is arrested, a hartal if someone is released and a hartal again if the Governor pays a visit.
('23', 101, 2, 7, 237772) Resorting to hartals in this manner deprives them of all value.
('23', 101, 2, 8, 237836) To me a hartal is a sacred and powerful weapon.
('23', 101, 2, 9, 237884) A hartal is in place on an occasion of great religious significance, or it may be resorted to for giving expression to people's feelings when they are very strong.
('23', 101, 2, 10, 238048) If we look upon any and every occasion as of religious significance or let ourselves be moved by strong feelings whenever something happens and so call for a hartal, we shall have made our measure of what constitutes religious significance or strength of feelings cheap indeed.
('23', 101, 2, 11, 238326) Had I not felt that we could not do without a hartal during the Satyagraha Week, I would certainly not have been instrumental in further lowering the value of hartals in this season of cheap hartals.
('23', 101, 2, 12, 238526) I hope that henceforth a hartal will be called for at any place only on rare occasions.
('23', 101, 2, 13, 238614) The best course is not to have a hartal unless the Congress and the Khilafat Committee have discussed the matter and issued a statement calling for one.
('23', 101, 3, 14, 238767) PRISON PALACE

('23', 101, 4, 16, 238875) Actually, we want to fill the jails.
('23', 101, 4, 17, 238912) Our delive rance will be possible only when people in their thousands go to jail.
('23', 101, 4, 18, 238994) Under an oppressive Government, generally the prison is the only sacred place for a good man.
('23', 101, 4, 19, 239088) Jail is the dwelling place of our freedom.
('23', 101, 4, 20, 239131) When large numbers of wholly innocent men are in jail, we may take it that swaraj is at hand.
('23', 101, 4, 21, 239225) If we wish to make the jail our natural home under this Government, there is no sense in our declaring a hartal when someone goes to jail.
('23', 101, 4, 22, 239364) When we have really shed the fear of jail, the Government will not care to imprison us.
