('23', 111, 1, 2, 260895) 49. GANDHI OLD AND NEW
('23', 111, 2, 3, 260918) The Times of India has returned to the charge of insincerity which was to be inferred from its previous article which I dealt with recently in these columns.
('23', 111, 2, 4, 261076) It is a sober article to which no exception could be taken.
('23', 111, 2, 5, 261136) I am certainly anxious to retain the reputation for sincerity which has been credited to me and which I certainly claim.
('23', 111, 2, 6, 261257) My article, “The Mists” 1 should generally be regarded as my last word to my critics.
('23', 111, 2, 7, 261343) I must rely upon my actions for final explanation.
('23', 111, 2, 8, 261394) No man can be called just, sincere, or good before his death.
('23', 111, 2, 9, 261456) But I would like to correct some of the misstatements of The Times of India writer.
('23', 111, 2, 10, 261540) Even when I declared satyagraha, I was charged with having fallen from my original non political state and the state of isolation.
('23', 111, 2, 11, 261671) Even in South Africa, I was referred by my critics to my past.
('23', 111, 2, 12, 261734) Every campaign that I have been connected with had its critics who praised my past at the expense of the then present.
('23', 111, 2, 13, 261853) I state this fact not to disprove the present charge, but to steel my heart against believing in the charge of unconscious insincerity and self deception.
('23', 111, 2, 14, 262008) I never suspended satyagraha, I certainly never retired into private life.
('23', 111, 2, 15, 262083) I suspended civil disobedience, and it remains still suspended, because I believed, as I still believe, the country not to be ripe for it.
('23', 111, 2, 16, 262222) My Himalayan mistake was my miscalculation of the preparedness of the country.
('23', 111, 2, 17, 262301) Non co operation of the type undertaken is not attended with any danger such as is attendant on civil disobedience.
('23', 111, 2, 18, 262417) The latter is not always a duty as non co operation is.
('23', 111, 2, 19, 262473) Hence it is that I have said that I must continue to advise non co operation even though it may result in anarchy.
('23', 111, 2, 20, 262588) Am I to recall my medals, or advise friends to recall theirs, or advise lawyers to resume practice because, supposing, anarchists have gained the upper hand?
('23', 111, 2, 21, 262746) Am I to associate myself for fear of anarchy with a dishonest Government which believes in Dyerism as a faith?
('23', 111, 2, 22, 262857) I know that anarchy as a creed is devilish, but Dyerism is still more so for it is anarchy wearing the mask of constituted authority.
('23', 111, 2, 23, 262991) Ordered anarchy is infinitely worse than avowed anarchy.
('23', 111, 2, 24, 263048) Only, in the latter event, I should dissociate myself from the anarchy of the mob as I have dissociated myself from the anarchy of the Government.
('23', 111, 2, 25, 263195) For me both are evils to be shunned.
('23', 111, 2, 26, 263232) I have not asked for reprisals against the author of the Jallianwala Massacre.
('23', 111, 2, 27, 263311) I have asked for nothing more than the stopping of the pensions to the culprits and the dismissal of those who are yet holding office.
('23', 111, 3, 28, 263446) 1 Vide “The Mists”, 20 4 1921.
('23', 112, 0, 1, 263477) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 113
('23', 112, 1, 2, 263519) not advised the Sikhs to give any pension to Mahant Naraindas or to keep him in office.
('23', 112, 1, 3, 263607) I have ventured to advise the Sikhs to waive the prosecution of the murderers as I have advised the nation to waive the prosecution of the official murderers in the Punjab.
('23', 112, 1, 4, 263780) I claim consistency of conduct about Amritsar and Nankana.
('23', 112, 1, 5, 263839) I have said repeatedly that I am acting towards the Government as I have acted towards my own dearest relatives.
('23', 112, 1, 6, 263952) Non co operation on the political field is an extension of the doctrine as it is practised on the domestic field.

('23', 112, 1, 17, 265120) Nor, I promise The Times of India writer, is there any self deception in this belief.

('23', 112, 1, 19, 265239) Precedent is on my side.

('23', 115, 2, 19, 271708) 53. OFFER OF PRIZE BY A PARSI SISTER
('23', 115, 3, 20, 271745) A Sister named Meherbai Bhesania has written a very loving letter from Yokohama, the capital of Japan, It has lain with me unanswered for some time, and I apologize to her for this.
('23', 115, 3, 21, 271927) I read it again after a lapse of some days.
('23', 115, 3, 22, 271971) I kept wondering whether or not I should publish it and I was also busy with other things and so could not decide what to do.
('23', 115, 3, 23, 272097) It seemed to me doubtful whether, by offering a prize, we could have good national songs.
('23', 115, 3, 24, 272187) Finally, however, I came to the conclusion that it would not be proper for me not to publish a sister's letter written with the utmost sincerity or not to announce the prize offered by her.
('23', 115, 3, 25, 272377) I therefore give the letter below.
('23', 115, 3, 26, 272412) I have omitted a part of it which concerned me alone.
('23', 115, 3, 27, 272466) Just a few words here and there have been corrected and paragraphs in English have been translated [into Gujarati].
('23', 115, 3, 28, 272582) The rest of the letter I give as it is.
('23', 115, 3, 29, 272622) It is a matter of joy that a sister living so far away takes such interest in this holy fight.
('23', 116, 0, 1, 272717) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 117
('23', 116, 1, 2, 272759) If Goddess Saraswati inspires any poets of Gujarat and they try their hand, not tempted by the prize but to respect a sister's wish conveyed from so far away, I shall be obliged.
('23', 116, 1, 3, 272938) All entries should be received by June 30 at the latest.

('23', 134, 1, 2, 317614) 58. REPLY TO ADDRESS AT ALLAHABAD CONFERENCE 1
('23', 134, 2, 3, 317661) May 10, 1921
('23', 134, 3, 4, 317674) Mahatmaji in a short speech thanked the people of Allahabad for their enthusiastic welcome and said that he had visited Allahabad so many times before that he felt quiet at home there.
('23', 134, 3, 5, 317859) It had become customary in his recent tours that addresses of welcome were presented to him by various municipalities.
('23', 134, 3, 6, 317978) The presentation of all address was only an expression of their agreement with the non co operation programme and that those who presented the address were with them in their present struggle for freedom.
('23', 134, 3, 7, 318183) At Allahabad their municipal commissioners thought that as he was a politician, it was no proper for them to present to him a welcome address.
('23', 134, 3, 8, 318326) They were right from one point of view, but this attitude required a radical change.
('23', 134, 3, 9, 318411) He wanted the municipalities to realize their own strength and not to remain tame instruments of a routine of work.
('23', 134, 3, 10, 318527) they should not however think that the address was withheld for some enmity with him.
('23', 134, 3, 11, 318613) The address presented to him and his brother Maulna Shaukat Ali so far were from smaller municipalities.
('23', 134, 3, 12, 318718) As for the bigger municipalities, it was difficult to change their course so abruptly.
('23', 134, 3, 13, 318805) They should, however, forget this episode and go on with their work as enjoined by the Congress.
('23', 134, 3, 14, 318902) They had to take swaraj within that year and to right the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs.
('23', 134, 3, 15, 318992) This could not be attained by mere conferences and lectures and poems and welcome addresses.
('23', 134, 3, 16, 319085) If it were possible to attain their object in that manner, they could have easily done it through their congress.
('23', 134, 3, 17, 319199) There was a time when The Congress and other conferences asked something from the Government, and when they met next year and their demands were not met by the Government, they passed a resolution of protest and there the matter ended.
('23', 134, 3, 18, 319435) That time had changed now and they had to take their object by their own efforts.
('23', 134, 3, 19, 319517) The Congress had placed a practical scheme before them and they had to work it in order to achieve what they wanted.
('23', 134, 3, 20, 319634) If they gave up conferences and poems and welcome addresses, etc., no harm could be done, but if they refrained from doing what the Congress asked them to do they could never attain swaraj.
('23', 134, 3, 21, 319824) In their welcome address they referred to the fact that there was another name of the city of Allahabad, viz., Fakirabad, and he wished that the city were worthy of that name in the fullest sense of he word.
('23', 134, 3, 22, 320032) For their present movement they required the services of fakirs or siritual being and he hoped that the city would give a lead to India in that respect.
('23', 134, 4, 23, 320185) 1 An address of welcome on behalf of the citizens was read out by Motilal Nehru at the Allahabad District Conference.

('23', 135, 1, 2, 320604) The Congress wanted them to do three things, viz., to enlist 1 crore members

('23', 135, 3, 4, 320761) introduce 20 lakhs charkhas in Indian homes.

('23', 135, 7, 11, 321155) If Allahabad was poor, he did not want them to contribute in rupees, but even if every man in the province could pay two piece each, they could contribute substantially towards their share.
('23', 135, 7, 12, 321345) Allahabad was a place of pilgrimage and they could form Seva Samitis to help the pilgrims and then ask them to contribute for the Fund and he was sure that, if they worked hard in this way, they could easily collect an amount which would be equal to, if not more than, the share allotted to them.
('23', 135, 8, 13, 321642) Then there was the introduction of 20 lakh charkhas.He did not want them to possess these charkhas and to worship them but to take the same work from them which, as Mr. Mohamed Ali said in one of his speeches, the British Government took from machine guns.
('23', 135, 8, 14, 321899) If 20 lakh charkhas were working at least 4 hours daily, he felt sure that in a very short time no Indian will feel ashamed of putting on the cloth made in his own country.
('23', 135, 9, 15, 322072) In his recent tours in India, he speaker as well as Mauna Shaukat Ali had shown to the country the absolute necessity of Hindu Muslim unity and, if the country did not still realize the fact, no amount of propaganda could bring it home to them.
('23', 135, 9, 16, 322317) They had also demonstrated that they were absolutely non violent.

('23', 135, 10, 19, 322528) They should fully understand that they should not use violent language even for their enemies; instead of being violent, they should create a spirit o suffering and sacrifice, and even in some of them were sent to jail, they should not give vent to angry demonstrations.
('23', 135, 10, 20, 322799) For it is only by their readiness to go to jail that they could hasten their way towards swaraj.
('23', 135, 10, 21, 322896) He deprecated the action of the people of Malegaon and asked them of take a lesson from the episode and never allow its repetition.
('23', 135, 10, 22, 323028) If the speaker of Maulna Shaukat Ali—or Mohamed Ali or any other worker in the cause—was sent to jail they should not kill any sub inspector even if their men are killed by him.
('23', 135, 10, 23, 323206) When they had created that spirit in them and when they had lost all fear of jail, which to a worker like himself was a place of rest and comfort, swaraj would not remain at a distance.

('23', 136, 3, 13, 325275) SWAMI GOVINDANAND So, Swami Govindanand has got five years’ transportation.

('23', 137, 1, 5, 326551) But the worst of this Government is that it has no consistent policy.
('23', 137, 1, 6, 326621) The late Mr. Chamberlain 1 used to pride himself on reiterating his belief that a British official’s word was as good as a bond.
('23', 137, 1, 7, 326750) We know by painful experience that, to day, a British Government’s bond is worth no more than waste paper.
('23', 137, 1, 8, 326857) Happily, India was under no delusion when Sir William Vincent pompously pronounced the sentences conveying to the Indian ear the assurance that non co operators were to be left undisturbed so long as there was no incitement to violence.
('23', 137, 1, 9, 327094) The assurance only meant that non co operators were to be left undisturbed so long as their propaganda did not result in effective action.
('23', 137, 1, 10, 327233) Now that we have gone far beyond the stage of mere demonstration, we need or expect freedom from imprisonment or worse.

('23', 137, 1, 15, 327720) But whether that event is far or near, our duty is clear.

('23', 142, 0, 1, 338318) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 143
('23', 142, 1, 2, 338360) India from imported yarn (chiefly fine), however comfortable wearing these clothes may be.
('23', 142, 1, 3, 338451) A little explanation is necessary.
('23', 142, 1, 4, 338486) One of the cardinal facts to remember in this connection is that, if the total amount of twist and yarn that is now produced in India without the use of charkha were converted into cloth, it would practically suffice to clothe India from her own produce, supposing the country were prepared to wear coarse cloths only.
('23', 142, 1, 5, 338805) As a matter of fact, about 143 million pounds of twist and yarn made in India are exported
('23', 142, 2, 6, 338896) every year from India.
('23', 142, 2, 7, 338919) Convert, i.e., weave this stuff into cloth in India and prepare the country for making the small sacrifice involved in being content for the present with the coarse cloth thus produced, and the great problem of making India self clothing within a very short time is solved.
('23', 142, 2, 8, 339193) Here the first question that crosses one’s mind is whether the existing power looms and handlooms of India would be able to weave the above huge quantity of yarn into cloth.
('23', 142, 2, 9, 339367) The answer must be in the negative.
('23', 142, 2, 10, 339403) What then is to be done?
('23', 142, 2, 11, 339428) The obvious answer is: increase the number of looms.
('23', 142, 2, 12, 339481) It would be difficult to increase the number of power looms at once.
('23', 142, 2, 13, 339550) A large quantity of machinery (weaving) would have to be imported from foreign lands.
('23', 142, 2, 14, 339636) That means a delay of two or three years, leaving aside for the nonce the difficulties arising from the unfavourable rate of exchange and the recently imposed high import duty on this kind of machinery.
('23', 142, 2, 15, 339839) To increase the number of handlooms is not difficult.
('23', 142, 2, 16, 339893) They can be manufactured here in India within a very short time and at a very small cost.
('23', 142, 2, 17, 339983) From a calculation based on statistics for the year 1919 published by the Director General of Satistics, which however I do not wish to inflict on your readers, it can be easily shown that it would be practically sufficient for our present purposes, if we multiply our handlooms to twice their existing number.
('23', 142, 2, 18, 340294) And I appeal to the readers to consider the matter with all the earnest care that the importance of the question demands, and put their powerful shoulders to the wheel.
('23', 142, 3, 19, 340463) Yours faithfully,

('23', 151, 6, 7, 359776) go to him in order to bring him up to Simla.
('23', 151, 6, 8, 359821) Soon after the telegram, he received a
('23', 151, 7, 9, 359860) letter from the Pundit saying that Lord Reading would like to see him if he (Mr.
('23', 151, 8, 10, 359941) Gandhi) wanted to see H.E. the Viceroy with a view to put the case of the non co 
('23', 151, 9, 11, 360023) operation party before him.
('23', 151, 9, 12, 360051) Mr. Gandhi saw nothing wrong in putting his case before
('23', 151, 10, 13, 360107) an official.
('23', 151, 11, 14, 360120) Accordingly, on reaching Simla, he sent a letter to the Viceroy asking for an
('23', 151, 12, 15, 360198) interview which was at once granted.
('23', 151, 12, 16, 360235) He acknowledged that the Viceroy gave him a
('23', 151, 13, 17, 360279) long, patient and kind hearing.
('23', 151, 13, 18, 360311) But he could not say either one way or the other about
('23', 151, 14, 19, 360366) the success of this interview.
('23', 151, 14, 20, 360397) 3 He placed before the Viceroy what his party stood for
('23', 151, 15, 21, 360453) and the Viceroy, in his turn, dilated on the difficulties confronting the
('23', 151, 16, 22, 360527) administration.
('23', 151, 16, 23, 360543) The interview might both be called successful and unsuccessful.
('23', 151, 17, 24, 360607) ...[He] said that everything would depend on the people carrying out what they
('23', 151, 18, 25, 360686) had solemnly resolved upon at the Congress and the Sikh League and Khilafat
('23', 151, 19, 26, 360762) Conference.
('23', 151, 20, 27, 360774) At this moment he could only say that, as long as they stood by non violence
('23', 151, 21, 28, 360851) and the spirit of sacrifice for the cause of justice to their country, no power on earth
('23', 151, 22, 29, 360940) could check them from the attainment of swaraj within this year.
('23', 151, 22, 30, 361005) They wanted to
('23', 151, 23, 31, 361020) show to the world that they stood for justice, and nothing but justice to India would
('23', 151, 24, 32, 361106) solve their problem .
('23', 151, 24, 33, 361128) He wanted all to behave like those who died at Nankana , freely
('23', 151, 25, 34, 361192) giving their blood for the sake of their sacred cause and not like Mahant Naraindas
('23', 151, 26, 35, 361276) bent upon taking others, blood.
('23', 151, 26, 36, 361308) When this spirit of non violence and sacrifice came
('23', 151, 27, 37, 361360) to them , no modern implements of warfare could stay in the way of their liberty .
('23', 151, 28, 38, 361443) 1 Gandhiji addressed a meeting of about fifteen thousand people at Idgah ground.
('23', 151, 28, 39, 361524) He was requested to speak on the purpose of his visit to Simla and the result of his meeting with the Viceroy.
('23', 151, 28, 40, 361635) Gandhiji’s speech was reported in The Bombay Chronicle dated May 17 and 19. In the text given here both these reports have been collated.

('23', 152, 0, 1, 361930) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 153
('23', 152, 1, 2, 361972) Referring to the oft repeated threat of an Afghan invasion, in case the British left this country, Mr. Gandhi said as long as he lived he could not telerate any part of his country under foreign domination.
('23', 152, 1, 3, 362179) He believed this was also the view of every Mohammedan in India.
('23', 152, 1, 4, 362244) He asked Hindus to have no suspicion about Mohammedans’ feelings on this point.
('23', 152, 1, 5, 362324) He wanted every man belonging to any religion to make common cause with them in this fight for liberty.
('23', 152, 2, 6, 362428) He spoke at great length on three essentials o success.
('23', 152, 2, 7, 362484) The first was getting rid of fear, the fear on the part of Hindus of Mohammedans and Pathans and on the part of Mohammedans of the fear and distrust of Hindus.
('23', 152, 2, 8, 362644) He said the Afghan danger was nothing but a bogey.
('23', 152, 2, 9, 362695) He had long known the Afghan character.
('23', 152, 2, 10, 362735) Whatever their weaknesses, he was sure they were godfearing.
('23', 152, 2, 11, 362796) He was confident that they would never think of a war of aggression.
('23', 152, 2, 12, 362865) On the other hand, we would never invite the Afghans to help them in their struggle for freedom.
('23', 152, 2, 13, 362962) On the contrary, if the Afghans came on an aggressive mission, he would undertake stubborn non co operation against them, and would lay down his life before parting with an inch of his Motherland.
('23', 152, 3, 14, 363159) He again reverted to the essential necessity of casting off distrust from their hearts by the Hindus and Mohammedans and spoke on the second essential, Hindu Muslim unity.
('23', 152, 3, 15, 363331) The entente between them was never entered into in a bargaining spirit.
('23', 152, 3, 16, 363403) The Hindus espoused the Muslims’ cause, because they knew it was their duty and because they knew that nobility could only be answered by nobility.
('23', 152, 3, 17, 363551) It was fatal, therefore, to compel the Mussulmans to give up cow killing.
('23', 152, 3, 18, 363625) They were not the only culprits in the matter and the question of cow protection was never going to be decided by the arbitrament of force.
('23', 152, 3, 19, 363765) Implicit trust of and hearty co operation with the Mussalmans would gain in the end everything.
('23', 152, 3, 20, 363861) Islam was broad based on nobility, and it would not endure if it gave up its nobility.
('23', 152, 4, 21, 363948) The third essential and the greatest one was of non violence.
('23', 152, 4, 22, 364010) In this connection, he made a stirring appeal to the Sikhs to emulate the example of Lachh man Singh and Dulip Singh, who had strength enough to fight Mahant Naraindas but who refused to use any violence.
('23', 152, 5, 23, 364215) Lastly, he referred to swadeshi and said that though he would never cease to appeal to the vakils and the students to give up the law courts and schools, their failure to respond was not going to affect the question, if they carried out the boycott of foreign goods.
('23', 152, 5, 24, 364482) Complete swadeshi meant swaraj.
('23', 152, 6, 25, 364514) Concluding, Mr. Gandhi said the attainment of swaraj depended upon the spirit of fearlessness, sacrifice, non violence, Hindu Muslim unity and the use of charkha.

('23', 153, 0, 1, 364916) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 153, 1, 2, 364958) Will our talks yield any result ?
('23', 153, 1, 3, 364992) They may or they may not, the chances are even.
('23', 153, 1, 4, 365040) We have to pray for God’s help to achieve what we wish to.
('23', 153, 1, 5, 365099) I explained our case to the Viceroy and he listened to me for many hours with great patience and affection.
('23', 153, 1, 6, 365207) I, too, listened to what he had to say.
('23', 153, 1, 7, 365247) I heard him explain the difficulties of the British Government.
('23', 153, 1, 8, 365311) I can only say this—if we adhere to the solemn decla ration made, with God as witness at the Congress session, the Sikh League and the Khilafat conferences, we shall certainly achieve our cherished goal during this year.
('23', 153, 1, 9, 365532) Nothing is in the hands of the Viceroy.
('23', 153, 1, 10, 365572) Don’t keep on asking what news cables from England bring.
('23', 153, 1, 11, 365630) Our fight is for honour and justice, and we have to show to the world that we are ready to die for winning justice.
('23', 153, 1, 12, 365746) God grants nothing without testing us and, before we can get anything, we must emerge successful from the test.
('23', 153, 1, 13, 365858) Even the worst scoundrel is ready to do anything to get what he wants; you six foot tall Punjabis, then, if you do not want to crawl again on your stomachs, if not even one amongst you desired to rub his nose on the ground, learn the lesson which our Sikh brethren have taught.
('23', 153, 1, 14, 366136) Be ready, like them, to stake your head in a righteous cause.
('23', 153, 1, 15, 366198) Do not be murderers, like Mahant Naraindas.
('23', 153, 1, 16, 366242) You cannot win swaraj by killing anyone; you cannot solve the Punjab and the Khilafat questions that way.
('23', 153, 1, 17, 366348) Not by taking anyone’s blood but only by giving your own, by acquiring the strength of Lachhman Singh can you succeed in these things.
('23', 153, 1, 18, 366483) * * * I tell you, as long as you are scared of your holy places being polluted or dishonoured by Pathans, you had better bury your Hardwar and immolate your womenfolk on the funeral pyre.
('23', 153, 1, 19, 366671) You may not be able to fight the Pathans, but, instead of running away, you ought to have in you the strength to stand up against them and die.
('23', 153, 1, 20, 366815) Have no fear of the Afghans, nor of the Muslims; fear God alone.
('23', 153, 1, 21, 366880) Even in the days of the Prophet, some timid people, seeing the oncoming hordes, told him that they were only a few and asked him in fear how they could fight.
('23', 153, 1, 22, 367039) The Prophet’s reply was, ‘‘No, you are not alone; God is with you.’’ I, too, say to you, do not think your selves weak.
('23', 153, 1, 23, 367159) If you are brave, the Afghans also will behave well towards you.
('23', 153, 1, 24, 367224) I know the Afghans.
('23', 153, 1, 25, 367244) In South Africa, I had many of them as my clients.
('23', 153, 1, 26, 367295) I have had experience of their sense of honour.
('23', 153, 1, 27, 367343) I think even bad ones among them fear God.
('23', 153, 1, 28, 367386) If you regard the Muslims as your brethren, if you trust them, have no fear of the pathans at all.
('23', 153, 1, 29, 367485) If they come to attack us, I shall be with you to employ non co 
('23', 154, 0, 1, 367550) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 155
('23', 154, 1, 2, 367592) operation against them too.
('23', 154, 1, 3, 367620) I shall not let even a little bit of India be seized by them.
('23', 154, 1, 4, 367682) God will give me strength at that time to offer up my life before they seize any bit.
('23', 154, 1, 5, 367768) We have become slaves because of our mutual distrust.
('23', 154, 1, 6, 367822) If the Muslims tarnish Islam, if the crores of them play foul, Islam will disappear.
('23', 154, 1, 7, 367907) Theirs and ours is a relation based not on self interest but on honour.
('23', 154, 1, 8, 367979) I tell men of all religions that we wish to be bound in a unity of hearts.
('23', 154, 1, 9, 368054) Are we not so bound to the Christians ?
('23', 154, 1, 10, 368094) Do we not accept the help that men like Andrews and Stokes 1 offer us ?
('23', 154, 1, 11, 368166) We do not desire to make anyone our enemy.
('23', 154, 1, 12, 368209) We wish rather to give our own blood.
('23', 154, 1, 13, 368247) If the British remain as servants, as brothers, if they agree to give up their domination and stay on, they are welcome; otherwise they should quit.
('23', 154, 1, 14, 368396) In any case, we can get nothing unless we remain peaceful.
('23', 154, 1, 15, 368455) If you allow yourselves to be provoked, you will lose the game.
('23', 154, 1, 16, 368519) I have no desire to see General Dyer or Michael O’Dwyer punished, and here, today, on this sacred spot near a holy man’s grave, I pray to God that He make their hearts pure.

('23', 155, 14, 20, 370275) 70. NOTES
('23', 155, 15, 21, 370285) HORNIMAN AND COMPANY Friends have accused me of indifference about Mr. Horniman, and some have also wondered why I rarely write about the Savarkar
('23', 156, 0, 1, 370432) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 157
('23', 156, 1, 2, 370474) Brothers 1. There is a favourite saying among lawyers, almost enjoying the dignity of a maxim, that hard cases make a bad law.
('23', 156, 1, 3, 370601) I know to my cost how true the saying is.
('23', 156, 1, 4, 370643) Many a judge has been obliged to give a decision apparently unjust but perfectly sound in law.
('23', 156, 1, 5, 370738) Similarly, one may say that hard cases make bad non co operation.
('23', 156, 1, 6, 370804) My business as an economical journalist is to deal with such matters only as have bearing on the one issue before the country.
('23', 156, 1, 7, 370931) If I mention Mr. Horniman’s case or that of the Savarkar Brothers, I can mention it not to influence the Government's decision, but to stimulate the public in favour of non co operation.
('23', 156, 1, 8, 371118) I would be delighted to have Mr.Horni man back as an able and brave comrade.
('23', 156, 1, 9, 371195) I know that he was unjustly deported.
('23', 156, 1, 10, 371233) The Savarkar Brothers' talent should be utilized for public welfare.
('23', 156, 1, 11, 371302) As it is, India is in danger of losing her two faithful sons, unless she wakes up in time.
('23', 156, 1, 12, 371393) One of the brothers I know well.
('23', 156, 1, 13, 371426) I had the pleasure of meeting him in London.
('23', 156, 1, 14, 371471) 2 He is brave.
('23', 156, 1, 15, 371486) He is clever.
('23', 156, 1, 16, 371500) He is a patriot.
('23', 156, 1, 17, 371517) He was frankly a revolutionary.
('23', 156, 1, 18, 371549) The evil, in its hideous form, of the present system of Government, he saw much earlier than I did, He is in the Andamans for his having loved India too well.
('23', 156, 1, 19, 371708) Under a just Government, he would be occupying a high office.
('23', 156, 1, 20, 371770) I there fore feel for him and his brother.
('23', 156, 1, 21, 371813) Had it not been for non co operation.
('23', 156, 1, 22, 371851) Mr. Horniman would have returned and the brothers would have been discharged long ago.
('23', 156, 1, 23, 371938) Now non co operation blocks the way.
('23', 156, 1, 24, 371975) Those who are really interested in the release of the brothers and such others as are suffering imprisonment and in the return of Mr. Horniman, must hasten the fulfilment of the non co operation programme and therefore the advent of swaraj.
('23', 156, 1, 25, 372216) Meanwhile, we must not only put up with the existing incarcerations, but we must seek imprisonment ourselves, by offending the Government in all just, lawful and peace ful ways.
('23', 156, 2, 26, 372394) WHAT ARE THEY ?
('23', 156, 3, 27, 372410) I am writing these notes in Anand Bhavan.

('23', 157, 1, 4, 373140) The leaflets are held by he Magistrate to be seditious, and the young men called upon to furnish security that they will not distribute them.

('23', 157, 1, 10, 373854) If a spinning wheel can by any possibility be turned into a seditious article, its possession will be another honourable method of seeking imprison ment.
('23', 157, 2, 11, 374008) THE ZEMINDARS AND THE RYOTS
('23', 157, 3, 12, 374036) Whilst the U.P. Government is crossing the bounds of pro priety, and intimidating people, there is little doubt that the kisans too are not making wise use of their newly found power, In several zemindaris, they are said to have overstepped the mark, taken the law into their own hands and to have become impatient of anybody who would not do as they wish.
('23', 157, 3, 13, 374393) They are abusing social boycott and are turning it into an instrument of violence.
('23', 157, 3, 14, 374476) They are reported to have stopped the supply of water, barber, and other paid services to their zemindars in some instances and even suspended payment to the rent due to them.
('23', 157, 3, 15, 374652) The kisan movement has received an impetus from non co operation, but it is anterior to and independent to it.
('23', 157, 3, 16, 374763) Whilst we will not hesitate to advise the kisans when the moment comes to suspend payment of taxes to the Government, it is not contemplated that at any stage of non co operation we would seek to deprive the zemindars of their rent.
('23', 157, 3, 17, 374996) The kisan movement must be confined to the improvement to the status of the kisans and the betterment of the relations between the zemindars and them.
('23', 157, 3, 18, 375147) The kisans must be advised scrupulously to abide by the terms of their agreement with the zemindars, whether such agreement is written or inferred from custom.
('23', 157, 3, 19, 375307) Where a custom or even a written contract is bad, they may not try to uproot it by vio lence or without previous reference to the zemindars.
('23', 157, 3, 20, 375448) In every case there should be a friendly discussion with the zemindars and an
('23', 158, 0, 1, 375526) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 159
('23', 158, 1, 2, 375568) attempt made to arrive at a settlement.
('23', 158, 1, 3, 375608) Our capacity for swaraj depends upon our capacity for solving without reference to, or inter vention of, the Government, all the varied and complex problems that must arise in the affairs of one of the biggest and most ancient nations like ours.
('23', 158, 2, 4, 375854) DISCIPLINE It is high time that we disciplined ourselves.
('23', 158, 2, 5, 375912) The demonstrations at railway stations are becoming a menace to the comfort of the travelling public.
('23', 158, 2, 6, 376014) I am old that some railway passengers who, only a short time before a station demonstration, were praising me, were, after one or two demonstrations any intermediate stations, heard to curse me.
('23', 158, 2, 7, 376209) I sympathize with them.
('23', 158, 2, 8, 376233) I had a fellow passenger with me during the Allahabad journey.
('23', 158, 2, 9, 376296) Owing to the pressure of the crowds that besiged the station, he was unable to get a cut of tea for go out or his refreshments.
('23', 158, 2, 10, 376424) I should not at all be surprised if he considered me to be a plague.
('23', 158, 2, 11, 376493) On my way back from Allahabad, there was an un manageable crowd on the kanpur platform, yelling the national cries, pressing towards my compartment and making everybody uncom fortable.
('23', 158, 2, 12, 376678) The noise continued the whole time.
('23', 158, 2, 13, 376714) The leaders were with difficulty able to make the crowd sit, but it could not be made to stop shouting and yelling.
('23', 158, 2, 14, 376830) I was asked to stand near the door to give dar shan 1. Much to the disappointment of the friends who urged me, I resolutely refused to stir out of my seat unless there was perfect silence.
('23', 158, 2, 15, 377019) This din, noise and bustle was due purely to want of fore thought, management and organization.
('23', 158, 2, 16, 377115) It is best now to avoid all demonstrations a stations.
('23', 158, 2, 17, 377170) We must consult the convenience of the passengers.
('23', 158, 2, 18, 377221) If there must be a demonstration, national cries must be regulated every facility must be provided for the easy movement of passengers.
('23', 158, 2, 19, 377357) The nation must be disciplined to handle mass movements in a sober and methodical manner.
('23', 158, 2, 20, 377447) This means previous training of volunteers and previous discipline of the masses.
('23', 158, 2, 21, 377529) It is not impossible to give an elementary training in a few days.
('23', 158, 2, 22, 377596) Wherever the people have been previously instructed, they have responded wonderfully well.
('23', 158, 2, 23, 377687) Without this training, we never know when there might be an accident.
('23', 158, 2, 24, 377757) It is the innate good nature of the people that has saved us hitherto from mishaps.
('23', 158, 2, 25, 377841) But under proper training, we should be able to feel absolutely safe and comfortable in the midst of the biggest
('23', 158, 3, 26, 377954) 1 Sight of a person, place or thing considered holy
('23', 159, 0, 1, 378006) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 159, 1, 2, 378048) demonstrations.
('23', 159, 1, 3, 378064) We cannot afford to be hysterical of mad.
('23', 159, 2, 4, 378106) SIKH COLOUR A friend has just drawn my attention to a resolution passed by the Sikh League inviting me to include the Sikh black colour in the national flag.
('23', 159, 2, 5, 378264) These friends forget that all other colours are repre sented on the white strip.
('23', 159, 2, 6, 378345) We must not be parochial, provincial or clannish.
('23', 159, 2, 7, 378395) Hindu and Mussulman colours are specially represented, not so much for the numbers they represent, as for the fact that they have remained apart for so long and that their mutual distrust has been an effectual bar against the realization of national aspirations.
('23', 159, 2, 8, 378658) The Sikhs have never had any quarrel with Hindus.
('23', 159, 2, 9, 378708) And if one has the Sikh colour separately represented, why not the Parsi, the Christian and the Jewish?
('23', 159, 2, 10, 378812) I hope the Sikh Leaguers will see the unpractical nature of their suggestion.
('23', 159, 2, 11, 378890) I have been flooded with letters suggesting changes in the pro posed national flag.
('23', 159, 2, 12, 378974) I am unable to publish the voluminous corres pondence.
('23', 159, 2, 13, 379029) There is nothing striking in any of the letters.
('23', 159, 2, 14, 379078) Some deplore the want of artistic beauty about the flag, others would make additions representing Hindu and Mohammedan symbols.
('23', 159, 2, 15, 379206) The critics have missed the central idea.
('23', 159, 2, 16, 379248) We must not have any religious symbols and we must find a clear and permanant rallying object.
('23', 159, 2, 17, 379343) That is the spinning wheel, according to the vast majority who believe with me that we lost our liberty with the loss of the spinning wheel, and we can only regain it when we have revived the spinning wheel and rejected foreign cloth.
('23', 159, 3, 18, 379578) TO CORRESPONDENTS Many friends who send me urgent wires may consider me to be discourteous in that they get no replies to their wires.
('23', 159, 3, 19, 379713) The fact is that the telegraph department at Ahmedabad seems to have received ins tructions to delay delivery of my telegrams.
('23', 159, 3, 20, 379840) The authorities have the right, if they choose, to put such obstacles in my way.
('23', 159, 3, 21, 379921) And our move ment must be capable of being carried on independently of the use of public departments controlled by the Government.
('23', 159, 3, 22, 380052) I would advise correspondents not to waste money in sending wires, but tran sact all their business with me through the post, so long as the regular delivery to me of the post is continued by the Government.
('23', 159, 4, 23, 380260) Young India, 18 5 1921
('23', 160, 0, 1, 380283) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 161
('23', 160, 1, 2, 380325) 71. OUR NEIGHBOURS
('23', 160, 2, 3, 380344) Is not my article on the Afghan Bogey 1 an invitation to the Afghans to invade the Indian border, and thus do I not become a direct party to violence?
('23', 160, 2, 4, 380495) Thus asks Mr. Andrews.
('23', 160, 2, 5, 380518) My article was written or Indians and for the Government.
('23', 160, 2, 6, 380576) I do not believe the Afghans to be so foolish as to invade India on the strength of my article.
('23', 160, 2, 7, 380672) But I see that it is capable to bearing the interpretation put upon it by Mr. Andrews.
('23', 160, 2, 8, 380759) I therefore hasten to inform all whom it may concern that not only do I not want to invite the Afghans or anybody to come to our assistance, but am anxious for them not to come to our assistance.
('23', 160, 2, 9, 380955) I am quite confident of India's ability to settle with the Government without extraneous help.
('23', 160, 2, 10, 381050) Moreover, I am interested in demonstrating the perfect possibility o attaining our end only by non violent means.
('23', 160, 2, 11, 381164) I would therefore strain every nerve to keep the Afghans out of the Indian border, but my anxiety to keep them off the Indian border will not go so far as to assist the Government with men or money.
('23', 160, 2, 12, 381363) In my article I have put my position as clearly as possible.
('23', 160, 2, 13, 381424) For me the existing Government is the most intolerable of all, it is the greatest danger to the manhood of India and I would welcome its re formation at any cost.
('23', 160, 2, 14, 381587) It is my settled conviction that it is a godless Government.
('23', 160, 2, 15, 381648) That there are good Englishmen and good Indians connected with it makes it all the more dangerous for India.
('23', 160, 2, 16, 381757) It keeps the nation's eyes off the inherent evil of it.
('23', 160, 2, 17, 381813) My attack is not against individuals, it is directed against the system, against the aggregate called the Government.
('23', 160, 2, 18, 381931) The best of viceroys have been powerless to cradicate the poison of the system.
('23', 160, 2, 19, 382011) The poison is its foundation.
('23', 160, 2, 20, 382041) Therefore, I can reconcile myself to all the worst that can happen to India in the place of the present system.
('23', 160, 2, 21, 382153) What however I would do is totally different from what I can do.
('23', 160, 2, 22, 382218) I am sorry to have to confess that the movement has not yet acquired such hold on the soldier class as to embolden them to refuse assistance to the government in time of need.
('23', 160, 2, 23, 382394) When the soldier class has realized that it lives for he nation, and that it is a travesty if a soldier's calling when he undertakes to kill to order, the battle of India's worldly freedom is won without more.
('23', 160, 2, 24, 382604) As it is, the Indian soldier is as much subject to fear as the layman.
('23', 160, 2, 25, 382675) He fills the recruiting ranks because he
('23', 160, 3, 26, 382716) 1 Vide “The Afghan Bogey”, 4 5 1921.
('23', 161, 0, 1, 382753) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 161, 1, 2, 382795) believes that there is no other means of livelihood .
('23', 161, 1, 3, 382849) The Government has made the profession of killing attractive by a system of special rewards, and, by a system of skilfully devised punishments, has made it well nigh impossible for the soldier, once he is in, to get out without difficulty.
('23', 161, 1, 4, 383089) In these circumstances I do not delude myself with the belief that the British Government will be without Indian help in the event of an immediate Afghan invasion.
('23', 161, 1, 5, 383253) But it was my duty, especially when challenged, to put before the nation the position logically aris ing from non co operation.
('23', 161, 1, 6, 383381) It was necessary, too, to warn the nation against being frightened by the Afghan bogey.
('23', 161, 1, 7, 383469) The second part of the question contains, in my opinion, a misconception of non violence.
('23', 161, 1, 8, 383559) It is no part of the duty of a non violent non co operator to assist the Government against war made upon it by others.
('23', 161, 1, 9, 383679) A non violent non co operator may not secretly or openly encourage or assist any such war.
('23', 161, 1, 10, 383770) He may not take part directly or indirectly in it.
('23', 161, 1, 11, 383821) But it is no part of his duty to help the Government to end the war.
('23', 161, 1, 12, 383890) On the contrary his prayer would be, as it must be, for the defeat of at power which he seeks to destroy.
('23', 161, 1, 13, 383996) I, therefore, so are as my creed of non violence is concerned, can con template an Afghan invasion with perfect equanimity, and equally so far as India's safety is concerned.
('23', 161, 1, 14, 384171) The Afghans have no quarrel with India.
('23', 161, 1, 15, 384211) They are a godfearing people.
('23', 161, 1, 16, 384241) I warn non co operators against judging the Afghans by the few savage specimens we see in Bombay or Calcutta.
('23', 161, 1, 17, 384351) It is a superstition to suppose that they will overrun India if the British post at the frontier was withdrawn.
('23', 161, 1, 18, 384463) Let us remember that there is nothing to prevent them from overrunning India today, if they wished to.
('23', 161, 1, 19, 384566) But they are as fond of their country as we claim to be fond of ours.
('23', 161, 1, 20, 384636) I must devote a separate article to an examina tion of the difficult problem that faces the residents near the frontier.
('23', 161, 1, 21, 384757) Young India, 18 5 1921
('23', 161, 2, 22, 384780) 72. LET HINDUS BEWARE
('23', 161, 3, 23, 384802) Bihar is the land of promise for non co operation.
('23', 161, 3, 24, 384853) For the Hindu Muslim unity of Bihar is proverbial.
('23', 161, 3, 25, 384904) I was therefore distressed to find that the unity was suffering a strain which might almost prove unbearable.
('23', 161, 3, 26, 385014) I was told by all responsible leaders—both Hindu and Mohammedan—who are not given to be panicky, that it was taxing their resources to the utmost to avoid a Hindu Mussulman disturbance.
('23', 161, 3, 27, 385200) They informed me that certain Hindus, by name
('23', 162, 0, 1, 385246) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 163
('23', 162, 1, 2, 385288) Gangaram Sharma, Bhutanath and Vidyanand, for instance, had told the people that I had prohibited the use of meat to any Hindus or Mussulmans and that meat and fish were even forcibly taken away from people by over zealous vegetarians.
('23', 162, 1, 3, 385524) I know that unlawful use is being made of my name in many places, but this is the most novel method of misusing it.
('23', 162, 1, 4, 385640) It is generally known that I am a staunch vegetarian and food reformer.
('23', 162, 1, 5, 385712) But it is not equally generally known that ahimsa extends as much to human beings as to lower animals and that I freely associate with meat eaters.
('23', 162, 1, 6, 385860) I would not kill a human being for protecting a cow, as I will not kill a cow for saving a human life, be it ever so precious.
('23', 162, 1, 7, 385987) Needless to say I have authorized no one to preach vegetarianism as part of non co operation.
('23', 162, 1, 8, 386081) I do not know the persons named above.
('23', 162, 1, 9, 386120) I am sure that our purpose will be defeated if propaganda of any kind is accompanied by violence.
('23', 162, 1, 10, 386218) Hindus may not compel Mussulmans to abstain from meat or even beef eating.
('23', 162, 1, 11, 386293) Vegetarian Hindus may not compel other Hindus to abstain from fish, flesh for fowl.
('23', 162, 1, 12, 386377) I would not make India sober at the point of the sword.
('23', 162, 1, 13, 386433) Nothing has lowered the morale of the nation so much as violence.
('23', 162, 1, 14, 386499) Fear has become the part of the national character.
('23', 162, 1, 15, 386551) Non co operators will make a serious mistake if they seek to convert people to their creed by violence.
('23', 162, 1, 16, 386655) They will play into the hands of the Government if they use the slightest coercion towards anybody in the the course of their propaganda.
('23', 162, 1, 17, 386793) The cow question is a big question.
('23', 162, 1, 18, 386829) The greatest for a Hindu.
('23', 162, 1, 19, 386855) I yield to no one in my regard for the cow.
('23', 162, 1, 20, 386899) Hindus do not fulfill their trust so long as they do not possess the ability to protect the cow.
('23', 162, 1, 21, 386996) That ability can be derived either from body force or soul force.
('23', 162, 1, 22, 387062) To attempt cow protection by violence is to reduce Hinduism to Satanism and to prostitute to a base end the grand significance of cow protec tion.
('23', 162, 1, 23, 387209) As a Mussulman friend writes, beef eating, which is merely permissible in Islam, will become a duty if compulsion is resorted to by Hindus.
('23', 162, 1, 24, 387349) The latter can protect the cow only by developing the faculty for dying, for suffering.
('23', 162, 1, 25, 387437) The only chance Hindus have, of saving the cow in India from the butcher's knife, is by trying to save Islam from the impending peril and trusting their Mussulman countrymen to return nobility, i.e., voluntarily to protect the cow out of regard for their Hindu countrymen.
('23', 162, 1, 26, 387710) The Hindus must scrupulously refrain from using any violence against Mussulmans.
('23', 162, 1, 27, 387791) Suffering and trust are attributes of soul force.
('23', 162, 1, 28, 387841) I have heard that, at big fairs, if a Mussulman is found in possession of cows or even goats, he is at time
('23', 163, 0, 1, 387949) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 163, 1, 2, 387991) forcibly dispossessed.
('23', 163, 1, 3, 388014) Those, who, claiming to be Hindus, thus resort to violence are enemies of the cow and of Hinduism.
('23', 163, 1, 4, 388113) The best and the only way to save the cow is to save the Khilafat.
('23', 163, 1, 5, 388180) I hope therefore that every non co operator will strain himself to the utmost to prevent the slightest tendency to violence in any shape or form, whether to protect the cow or any other animal or to effect any other purpose.

('23', 168, 2, 13, 398191) 79. FIVE HUNDREDTH STOREY
('23', 168, 3, 14, 398217) I had heard of Simla.
('23', 168, 3, 15, 398239) I had not seen the place.
('23', 168, 3, 16, 398265) I often wished to see it but was always afraid to go there.
('23', 168, 3, 17, 398325) I felt that I would be lost there, that I would be a barbarian among the others.
('23', 168, 3, 18, 398406) I have seen the place now.
('23', 168, 3, 19, 398433) I have come here to see Bharat bhushan Pandit Malaviya, who has taken me under his wing.
('23', 168, 3, 20, 398522) The house is named "Shantkuti" and I am in the midst of coworkers here.
('23', 168, 3, 21, 398594) The climate is lovely.
('23', 168, 3, 22, 398617) Nature has withheld nothing of her riches.
('23', 168, 3, 23, 398660) These hills are a apart of the Himalayas, but I get no peace whatever from outside of me.
('23', 168, 3, 24, 398750) In fact, if my having peace depended entirely on external surroundings, I would have to run away from this place or else I would go mad.
('23', 168, 3, 25, 398887) Simla is named after Mother Shimala, as Mumbai [Bombay] is named after Mumbadevi and Calcutta after Kali.
('23', 168, 3, 26, 398993) All the three goddesses have proved faithless or, maybe, the devotees have forgotten them.
('23', 168, 3, 27, 399084) The mere thought of the Kali temple fills me with horror.
('23', 168, 3, 28, 399142) How can the place be called a temple at all?

('23', 170, 1, 5, 402259) Simla is at an altitude of 7,500 feet.

('23', 172, 1, 2, 405715) 80. MY NOTES
('23', 172, 2, 3, 405728) NEW VICEROY At Panditji's request , I went to see him at Simla.
('23', 172, 2, 4, 405792) His health being indifferent, he asked me to go to him instead of himself coming over to see me where I was.
('23', 172, 2, 5, 405901) How could I permit him to do so ?
('23', 172, 2, 6, 405935) I myself went to Simla.
('23', 172, 2, 7, 405959) Panditji told me there that the Viceroy would like to see me.
('23', 172, 2, 8, 406021) I wrote to His Excellency and told him that, if he wished to see me, I would gladly call on him and tell him all that I had to say.
('23', 172, 2, 9, 406153) He gave me an appointment .
('23', 172, 2, 10, 406181) We were together for a long time.
('23', 172, 2, 11, 406215) He listened, with great patience, courtesy and attention to everything I said.
('23', 172, 2, 12, 406294) I, too, on my part, listened to him respectfully.
('23', 172, 2, 13, 406344) The result was that we came to understand each other to some extent.
('23', 172, 2, 14, 406413) What the outcome will be, partly I know and partly I do not.
('23', 172, 2, 15, 406474) It is not in the Viceroy's hands to give us what we want.
('23', 172, 2, 16, 406532) If he is a good and sincere man and is convinced of what we say, he can help us as a friend.
('23', 172, 2, 17, 406625) But, otherwise, it is for us to secure what we want.
('23', 172, 2, 18, 406678) We should have the strength to get it.
('23', 172, 2, 19, 406717) If a man knows how to take what he desires, the man who will give it to him will not be wanting.
('23', 172, 2, 20, 406814) Is there any sense in a man carrying with him only a bowl and then complaining against the sea for not giving him a pitcherful ?
('23', 172, 2, 21, 406943) We should, therefore, acquire the strength to win swaraj, and secure justice on the Punjab and Khilafat issue.
('23', 172, 2, 22, 407054) We have not gained this strength yet, but we are acquiring it.
('23', 172, 2, 23, 407117) There are obstacles, like the incident at Malegaon, which lie in our way.
('23', 172, 2, 24, 407191) Though our failure to win our goal is due solely to our lethargy, we vent our irritation on others.
('23', 172, 2, 25, 407291) One essential characteristic of non co operation is that one should direct one's anger against oneself.
('23', 172, 2, 26, 407395) TO CO WORKERS As a result of my interview with H.E. The Viceroy, I can say this, at any rate, to my co workers, that they should shake off their lethargy and give up empty talk, demonstrations and speeches and go on working all the time.
('23', 172, 2, 27, 407633) We have five tasks before us : (1) eradicating untouchability; (2) stopping consumption of liquor; (3) enrolling Congress members; (4) collecting contributions for the Tilak Swaraj Fund; and (5) intro ducing the spinning wheel [into every home].
('23', 172, 2, 28, 407879) None of these tasks calls for speeches.
('23', 172, 2, 29, 407919) For eradicating untouchability, we should serve Bhangis and others like them, go to their homes and improve their conditions.
('23', 173, 0, 1, 408045) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 173, 1, 2, 408087) For stopping consumption of liquor, we should stand near liquor booths and try politely to enlighten intending customers, though, if they insist on doing so, they should be allowed to go in.
('23', 173, 1, 3, 408278) Every community should pass a resolution forbidding consumption of liquor and boycott those who violate it.
('23', 173, 1, 4, 408386) Boycotting does not mean stopping the services of washermen, barbers, etc.
('23', 173, 1, 5, 408461) It means refusing to accept water or food at such person's place and entering into no marriage connection with his family.
('23', 173, 1, 6, 408584) Boycott is of two kinds, civil and uncivil.
('23', 173, 1, 7, 408628) The former has its roots in love, the latter in hatred.
('23', 173, 1, 8, 408684) In fact , hatred is another name for uncivil boycott.
('23', 173, 1, 9, 408738) Such boycott has no place in peaceful non co operation and must be altogether eschewed.
('23', 173, 1, 10, 408826) The underlying idea in civil boycott is that of refraining from accepting any services from or having any social association with the person concerned.
('23', 173, 1, 11, 408978) The idea behind the other form is to inflict punishment and pain.
('23', 173, 1, 12, 409044) We do not want to punish the drink addict; we want, rather, to express our own grief by refusing to associate with him.
('23', 173, 1, 13, 409164) This means not to drink water or eat in company with him and not to have any marriage connection with his family.
('23', 173, 1, 14, 409278) But to prevent people from rendering any services to such a person is sheer heartlessness.
('23', 173, 1, 15, 409369) Wells and ponds are for the use of all.
('23', 173, 1, 16, 409409) Services of barbers and washermen and public services like transport should be available to all people, whether good or bad.
('23', 173, 1, 17, 409534) The barber, the washerman and the water carrier do not concern themselves with the circumstances of any family before serving it.
('23', 173, 1, 18, 409664) Even a murderer has a right to be allowed to drink water.
('23', 173, 1, 19, 409722) In the measure that we thus learn to distinguish between right and wrong, the advent of swaraj will be hastened.
('23', 173, 1, 20, 409835) I feel the necessity for resorting to boycott or discourag ing the consumption of liquor and that is why I have gone into the subject at such length.
('23', 173, 1, 21, 409985) Uncivil boycott has yielded bitter fruits at many places.

('23', 173, 1, 24, 410286) We should not hate even the proprietor of a liquor booth.

('23', 174, 1, 12, 411729) MEANING OF SPINNING WHEEL Introducing spinning wheels does not mean our providing every family with one and then doing no more.

('23', 181, 2, 3, 426319) MAULANA MAHOMED ALI I observe that the Indian Social Reformer rates me for not having said anything about Maulana Mahomed Ali’s speech at Madras, and not having criticized Lala Lajpat Rai’s at Bombay.
('23', 181, 2, 4, 426520) I must not answer the inferencea and the innuendoes contained in the paragraph .
('23', 181, 2, 5, 426601) Critics do not know under what difficulties I edit Young India.
('23', 181, 2, 6, 426665) I rarely read newspapers.
('23', 181, 2, 7, 426691) I cannot even get them during my incessant travelling.
('23', 181, 2, 8, 426746) But having read this criticism, I purposely procured at Simla a copy of the Maulana’s speech.
('23', 181, 2, 9, 426840) I have only just read it.
('23', 181, 2, 10, 426866) I have twice read the paragraph criticized, and I am of opinion that it contains nothing in it that is objectionable.
('23', 181, 2, 11, 426984) The speech is certainly not inconsistent with his interview at Allahabad.
('23', 181, 2, 12, 427058) In the Madras speech, he simply states the Muslim position.
('23', 181, 2, 13, 427118) In the Allahabad interview, he has accepted my application and restriction of the ideal Muslim conduct.
('23', 181, 2, 14, 427222) There is no doubt that if the Mussulmans could take up arms, they would do so in defence of Islam.
('23', 181, 2, 15, 427321) The difficulty arises because of our belief in the impossibility of the Afghans invading to defeat the British without wishing at the same time to occupy India.
('23', 181, 2, 16, 427482) That may be and will be a good reason for Mussulmans, if they are true to India, not joining the Afghans even if they were able.
('23', 181, 2, 17, 427611) But we may not dispute the theoretical religious right of Mussulmans to state their correct position.
('23', 181, 2, 18, 427713) We can only honour them for it.
('23', 181, 2, 19, 427745) The two great qualities of the brothers are their bravery and sincerity.
('23', 181, 2, 20, 427818) And I can read nothing but these two qualities in the Madras speech.
('23', 181, 3, 21, 427887) LALA LAJPAT RAI
('23', 181, 4, 22, 427903) Let me take the Indian Social Reformer into the secret of my methods.
('23', 181, 4, 23, 427973) My assistant drew my attention to the hostile criticism of Lalaji's speech and asked me whether I wished to say anything upon it.
('23', 181, 4, 24, 428103) I had not the text of his speech before me, nor had I seen any criticism.
('23', 181, 4, 25, 428177) I therefore wrote to Lalaji, asking him to enlighten me on the matter, and suggesting that he should apologize, if a single hasty word was uttered.
('23', 181, 4, 26, 428325) It has been my privilege on close acquaintance to find him generous, for giving and frank.

('23', 183, 1, 9, 431830) I must herefore try patiently to answer Mr. Jethamal’s open letter, especially as I claim him to be one of my earliest comrades in satyagraha and know him to be a leader of forlorn causes.

('23', 185, 1, 11, 437429) DOUBTING NATIONAL CAPACITY The third question is, ‘‘Do you believe that the constructive part of the non co operation programme can attain success without our having a national Government?’’ This question betrays helplessness.
('23', 185, 1, 12, 437656) We are delayed in the attainment of our goal only because of this feeling of help lessness.
('23', 185, 1, 13, 437748) We shall attain swaraj only when we feel self reliant.

('23', 185, 1, 16, 438045) Non co operation enables us to show that, in everything that matters, we can be indepen dent of the Government.

('23', 185, 1, 19, 438292) When, on the contrary, the principal feels helpless, he becomes his agent’s slave.

('23', 186, 2, 4, 439003) THE CURSE OF BETTING
('23', 186, 3, 5, 439024) Babu Bhagwandas, the learned Chancellor of the National University, Kashi, has sent me extracts from Manusmriti on the sin of betting.
('23', 186, 3, 6, 439159) I reproduce them below :
('23', 186, 4, 7, 439184) The King should diligently keep gambling (dyuta) and betting (sama 
('23', 186, 5, 8, 439252) hvaya) away from the State; for these two vices destroy the State and the
('23', 186, 6, 9, 439326) sovereign themselves.
('23', 186, 7, 10, 439348) Gambling and betting are indeed as daylight robbery; and the ruler
('23', 186, 8, 11, 439415) should endeavour diligently to eradicate them.
('23', 186, 9, 12, 439462) That wherein inanimate things are used, that is dyuta, gambling; that

('23', 189, 1, 7, 444793) Gladstone1 used to draw a sharp distinction between bad actions and bad men.
('23', 189, 1, 8, 444870) He was accused of discourtesy for using some very strong expressions about the acts 1 of his opponents.
('23', 189, 1, 9, 444974) He put up the defence that he would have failed in his duty if he had not characterizes their actions as they deserved to be, but he did not therefore mean to convey that his opponents deserved the epithets he had used about their acts.

('23', 191, 2, 8, 450168) 87. THE FRONTIER FRIEND
('23', 191, 3, 9, 450192) The punjabis living on the Frontier1 deserve the sympathy of the whole of India.
('23', 191, 3, 10, 450273) They are exposed to attacks from the neighboring tribes, they are defenceless, and from all the accounts received by me, the Government seem to give them little or no protection, and now a days the rule for the officers, if anyone complains, is to refer the complaint to the Ali Brothers and to me.
('23', 191, 3, 11, 450572) If we had charge of the Frontier, I know what we would have done.
('23', 191, 3, 12, 450638) We would certainly have died in the attempt to defend the unarmed population of the districts.
('23', 191, 3, 13, 450733) We would have, if necessary, armed the population for self defence.
('23', 191, 3, 14, 450801) But what is more, we would have won over the tribesmen and turned them from marauding bands into trustworthy neighbours.
('23', 191, 3, 15, 450922) But we have to take things as they are.
('23', 191, 3, 16, 450962) I assume that the Hindus and the Mussul mans are friendly to one another, and that no Mussulman traitorously helps the tribesmen against his Hindu brother.
('23', 191, 3, 17, 451118) The Mussulman popu lation this side of the Frontier is in an exceptionally strong position to help.
('23', 191, 3, 18, 451218) We must not despair of the tribesmen.
('23', 191, 3, 19, 451256) We have too often considered them to be hopeless.
('23', 191, 3, 20, 451306) In my opinion, they are amenable to reason.
('23', 191, 3, 21, 451350) They are godfearing.
('23', 191, 3, 22, 451371) They do not loot merely for pleasure.
('23', 191, 3, 23, 451409) I believe that they are themselves coming under the influence of the
('23', 192, 0, 1, 451478) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 193
('23', 192, 1, 2, 451520) wave of self purification that is spreading.
('23', 192, 1, 3, 451565) I know that the process of reforming the tribesmen is slow and tedious.
('23', 192, 1, 4, 451637) It provides poor comfort to those that are robbed of their possessions or their dear ones.
('23', 192, 1, 5, 451728) The difficulty is to be traced to the same cause—we fear Englishmen, and we have becomes slaves.
('23', 192, 1, 6, 451825) We fear the tribesmen and we are satisfied with our slavery, we are thankful that we are protected by the former against the latter.
('23', 192, 1, 7, 451958) I cannot imagine a greater humiliation for a self respecting man [than] to be dependent, for the safety of himself or his family, on those who he thinks prey upon him.
('23', 192, 1, 8, 452126) I would prefer total destruction of myself and my all to purcha sing safety at the cost of my manhood.
('23', 192, 1, 9, 452229) This feeling of helplessness in us has really arisen from our deliberate dismissal of God from our common affairs.
('23', 192, 1, 10, 452344) We have become atheists for all practical purposes.
('23', 192, 1, 11, 452396) And therefore, we believe that in the long run we must rely upon physical form physical danger, we cast all our philosophy to the winds.
('23', 192, 1, 12, 452533) Our daily life is a negation of God.
('23', 192, 1, 13, 452570) If then we would but have a little trust in God, i.e., ourselves, we shall find no difficulty with the tribesmen.
('23', 192, 1, 14, 452684) Only in that case, we will have to be prepared at times to surrender our possessions and, under certain circumstances , our lives rather than our honour.
('23', 192, 1, 15, 452838) We must refuse to believe that our neighbours are savages incapable of responding to the finer instincts in man.
('23', 192, 1, 16, 452951) Thus, consistently with our self respect, there are but two courses open to us, to prepare in so far as we wish to defend ourselves however weakly against robbery and plunder, or to believe in the capacity of our neighbours to respond to the nobler instinct in man and to endeavour to reform the tribesmen.
('23', 192, 1, 17, 453258) I apprehend that the who pro cesses will go hand in hand.
('23', 192, 1, 18, 453316) We must avoid the third at any cost, that is, reliance on the British bullet to protect us from harm.
('23', 192, 1, 19, 453418) It is the surest way to national suicide.
('23', 192, 1, 20, 453460) If my writings can reach the tribesmen, I would certainly urge them to leave their predatory habits.
('23', 192, 1, 21, 453561) In as much as they loot a single man or woman, they belie the teaching of the prophet whose name they prize above all others and whom they believe to be the messenger of the God of mercy and justice.
('23', 192, 1, 22, 453761) It is the duty of every Mussulman and Ulema who has any influence with these simple men to tell them that, if they will play their part in defending Islam from impending danger, the least they can do is to refrain from molesting their neigh bours, who have done not only no harm to them but who, whether
('23', 193, 0, 1, 454065) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 193, 1, 2, 454107) they are Hindus or Mussulmans, are doing their best to safeguard the honour of Islam.

('23', 193, 3, 5, 454245) In each province repression is taking its own special turn.

('23', 193, 3, 8, 454649) The latest instance is that of Mr. Sundarlal.
('23', 193, 3, 9, 454695) He has undoubtedly a hold on the student world which few possess in the C.P. His is the restraining hand, so far as violence is concerned .
('23', 193, 3, 10, 454835) But he is a courageous and effective speaker.
('23', 193, 3, 11, 454881) And therefore, in the opinion of the C.P. Government, he must be put out of harm's way.

('23', 193, 4, 15, 456251) It is not for violence done or intended.

('23', 201, 6, 9, 472322) 95. ADVICE TO PEOPLE OF GAYA 3
('23', 201, 7, 10, 472353) I have heard reports that many Hindus use my name in trying to prevent Muslims from eating meat and fish.
('23', 201, 7, 11, 472459) In the fight of non co operation there is not so much as a suggestion about persuading people to take only vegetarian food, to say nothing of using compul sion for this purpose.
('23', 201, 7, 12, 472637) It is violence, not non violence, forcibly to prevent someone from eating the kind of food he likes to eat.
('23', 201, 7, 13, 472745) I do not wish even to compel people to desist from drinking.
('23', 201, 7, 14, 472806) In peaceful non co operation compulsion is forbidden.
('23', 201, 7, 15, 472860) One who interferes with people eating what they choose to eat commits a crime before all men.
('23', 201, 7, 16, 472954) This kind of coercion will do great harm to our cause.
('23', 201, 7, 17, 473009) I hope, therefore, that no one will, in my name or in the name of ahimsa, cause obstruction to people eating and drinking as they want or will advocate taking away from people their meat and fish.
('23', 201, 7, 18, 473206) Seizing of animals by force in a fair is forbidden.

('23', 202, 1, 2, 473626) 96. TO THE WEALTHY CLASS IN GUJARAT
('23', 202, 2, 3, 473662) The 30th of June is fast approaching.
('23', 202, 2, 4, 473700) In Gujarat, we have not reached even the figure of two lakhs for the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('23', 202, 2, 5, 473788) Even in this, the contribution of the really wealthy class is very small indeed.
('23', 202, 2, 6, 473869) Do not the wealthy people love doing their duty.
('23', 202, 2, 7, 473918) And do they not wish to see India able to stand up and face the world?
('23', 202, 2, 8, 473989) Do they not wish to make their contribution to filling the hungry stomachs of over three crores of men in the country?
('23', 202, 2, 9, 474108) Is not the good name of India dear to them?
('23', 202, 2, 10, 474152) Do they not like that India should throw off her slavery?
('23', 202, 2, 11, 474210) Ary they not in a position , if they so will, to take up Gujara's burden in a day?
('23', 202, 2, 12, 474293) Is it not possible for the mill owners of Ahmedabad, by themselves, to raise a contribution of Rs 10 lakhs in a day, if they so decide?
('23', 202, 2, 13, 474429) If they choose, they can do a lot.
('23', 202, 2, 14, 474464) I hope they will make their contribution to the movement which is progressing apace in the country.
('23', 202, 2, 15, 474564) “If we help, the government will make things difficult for us.” I wish that the wealthy classes would shed this fear from their hearts.
('23', 202, 2, 16, 474700) The days for such fear are gone.
('23', 202, 2, 17, 474733) And, again, if only one rich man had to give, he could be intimidated; when, however, all agree to give, how can any of them be intimidated?
('23', 202, 2, 18, 474874) However, fear is such a thing that, despite one's desire to give, one cannot take courage to be the first to do so.
('23', 202, 2, 19, 474990) Shedding fears of this nature should also be one of the important results of this big fight.
('23', 202, 2, 20, 475083) It is my hope that the wealthy classes will be brave and take their full share in the work of national regeneration.
('23', 202, 2, 21, 475200) Even if, however, some among the wealthy classes find it diffi cult to follow the dharma of fearlessness, I hope that they will not give up the dharma of compassion.
('23', 202, 2, 22, 475366) They will certainly extend what ever help is possible to the famine stricken.
('23', 202, 2, 23, 475444) At the time of the viru lent outbreak of the plague an d when there was a famine some time ago, the wealthy classes were not found wanting.
('23', 202, 2, 24, 475584) If they do or can do nothing else, I pray that they will, at any rate, take up the burden of famine relief.
('23', 202, 2, 25, 475692) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 29 5 1921

('23', 203, 1, 2, 475771) 97. TO GUJARATIS LIVING OUTSIDE GUJARAT
('23', 203, 2, 3, 475811) Gujarat has not only to meet its share of the demand made at Bezwada, but also to go to the help of the weaker Provinces, and it is for this reason that I have put down Rs. 10 lakhs as its quota.
('23', 203, 2, 4, 476007) If Gujarat does not take up this burden, I am afraid we shall positively fail to collect one crore of rupees before June 30. Gujarat, however, has a third burden to bear.
('23', 203, 2, 5, 476178) There is drought in some parts of it and help is needed there too.
('23', 203, 2, 6, 476245) I wish to draw the attention of Gujaratis living outside Gujarat to all these three matters.
('23', 203, 2, 7, 476338) Wherever they are settled, they must do their duty by those regions— about this there can be no argument.
('23', 203, 2, 8, 476444) But they owe a like duty to Gujarat.
('23', 203, 2, 9, 476481) If Gujarat is to contribute 10 lakhs, it can do so only if all Gujaratis living elsewhere too keep Gujarat in mind.
('23', 203, 2, 10, 476597) If they do, Gujarat can contribute not only the full amount of 10 lakhs but even more.
('23', 203, 2, 11, 476684) Parsi and Muslim Gujaratis, if I can persuade them to do their duty, can by themselves make up the amount of one crore.
('23', 203, 3, 12, 476804) I wish to lay greater stress on the drought in Gujarat.
('23', 203, 3, 13, 476860) At the time of the Orissa famine, Gujaratis had made an excellent conri bution.
('23', 203, 3, 14, 476940) It will not be wrong, in fact, if we say that it was Gujarat which met the needs of famine relief then.
('23', 203, 3, 15, 477044) If so, will Gujarat be doing anything special if it meets such needs nearer home?
('23', 203, 3, 16, 477126) My appeal is also addressed to those who do not approve of the prevailing wind in other matters.
('23', 203, 3, 17, 477223) They can contribute to the famine relief fund in two ways: by contribution to the Tilak Swaraj Fund or, if they object to doing this, by remitting contributions exclusively for the Relief Fund.
('23', 203, 3, 18, 477417) In fact they can adopt any one of three different modes of contribution: (1) The money may be offered uncon ditionally—all such amounts will be credited to the Tilak Swaraj Fund; (2) it may be offered to the Tilak Swaraj Fund, but earmarked for famine relief—such amounts will be included in the Tilak Swaraj Fund but will be used entirely for famine relief; and (3) it may be offered exclusively for famine relief with the express condition that the amount is not to be included in the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('23', 203, 3, 19, 477923) Even Government servants and others who oppose non co ope ration can, and I hope will, contribute freely with the proviso men tioned in the third alternative.
('23', 203, 3, 20, 478082) Accounts for all amounts received are published.
('23', 203, 3, 21, 478131) All work is entrusted to vigilant secretaries and treasurers.
('23', 204, 0, 1, 478193) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 205
('23', 204, 1, 2, 478235) I, therefore, earnestly entreat Gujaratis to banish every fear and send in their contributions.
('23', 204, 1, 3, 478331) It will be some time before this letter is in the hands of Indians living in East Africa, Japan, England and other places.
('23', 204, 1, 4, 478454) Hence I appeal to persons living in Gujarat and having relations residing in other countries to send cables to those of them as reside in the countries mentioned above.

('23', 204, 2, 6, 478660) 98. MY NOTES
('23', 204, 3, 7, 478673) PILGRIMAGE TO MAHARASHTRA A visit to the province in which Lokamanya Tilak Maharaj was born, the province which has produced heroes in the modern age, which gave Shivaji and in which Ramdas and Tukaram flourished, is for me nothing less than a pilgrimage.
('23', 204, 3, 8, 478929) I have always believed that Maharashtra, if it wills, can do anything.
('23', 204, 3, 9, 479000) Its scepticism, however, is every a cause of grief to me.
('23', 204, 3, 10, 479058) I always feel that he province in which the best work can be done has done the least.
('23', 204, 3, 11, 479144) I gather that the workers in Maharashtra hold the same view.
('23', 204, 3, 12, 479205) After leaving simla, I went to Kalka and then to Ambala.
('23', 204, 3, 13, 479262) From there I proceeded to Khandwa in the Central Provinces and thence to Bhusaval, Sangamner and Yeola.
('23', 204, 3, 14, 479366) I am writing these notes on my way to Kurduwadi.
('23', 204, 3, 15, 479415) For going there, one has to go from Yeola to Dhond and change trains there.
('23', 204, 3, 16, 479491) As our train arrived late at Dhond and the connecting train had already left, I got some experience of Dhond as well.
('23', 204, 3, 17, 479609) I felt that the masses everywhere had the same faith but there were not enough workers.
('23', 204, 3, 18, 479697) people lack capacity for organization, there is no end to noise and bustle and they get crowds of people to fill station platforms.
('23', 204, 3, 19, 479829) As for the result, however, I found it poor in Bhusaval, Sangamner and Yeola at any rate, though he people who had invited me to these places were capable workers.
('23', 204, 3, 20, 479993) Where have we now the time for all this fuss and shouts of victory and bending to touch my feet in reverence?
('23', 204, 3, 21, 480103) If we can spare time to go to station platforms, why not spend it in plying the spinning wheet?
('23', 204, 3, 22, 480199) Why not use it in collecting contributions to the National Fund?
('23', 204, 3, 23, 480264) Do we not have to enrol a large number of Congress members?
('23', 204, 3, 24, 480324) The position now is that we shall be able to complete the programme before the end of June, as decided, only if we work round the clock.
('23', 204, 3, 25, 480461) Though two months have elapsed, we have not done even
