('23', 210, 9, 19, 495250) 101. NOTES
('23', 210, 10, 20, 495261) THE AFGHAN ALARM
('23', 210, 11, 21, 495278) It must be a matter of surprise to many people, as it is to me, that Mr. Bipin Chandra Pal 2 should be alarmed at the Afghan cry raised in interested quarters.
('23', 210, 11, 22, 495438) He is a believer in full swaraj, and I venture to suggest to Mr. Pal that we cannot establish swaraj in India, till we rid ourselves of the feeling of helplessness Swaraj means our prepared ness to deal with the Afghan and every other menace in our country.
('23', 210, 11, 23, 495696) The whole scheme of non co operation is based on trusting other people, and if they prove untrustworthy, on our being prepared to meet their deceit by self suffering.
('23', 210, 11, 24, 495863) I remind Mr. Pal of what he truly said at Allahabad at the Hindu Mohammedan Conference in reply to Dr. Sapru 3 that the same power of combination, resourcefulness and
('23', 210, 12, 25, 496030) 1 From the reference to the Tilak Swaraj Fund, collections for which ended on June 30, 1921 2 1858 1932; educationist, journalist orator and political leader of Bengal .
('23', 210, 12, 26, 496200) 3 Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru (1875 1949); jurist and Liberal leader; represented the Government of India at the Round Table Conferences in 1930, 1931 and 1932
('23', 211, 0, 1, 496354) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 211, 1, 2, 496396) suffering that would end the present system of slavery would enable us to deal with every other system of a similar nature.
('23', 211, 2, 3, 496520) Pan Islamism, which Mr. Pal fears, is an admirable doctrine in so far as a Mussulman wishes the solidarity of all Muslim states.
('23', 211, 2, 4, 496649) It would be a dangerous doctrine.
('23', 211, 2, 5, 496683) If it were to mean a combination of Islamic powers for the purpose of exploiting the world or converting it to Islam by force.
('23', 211, 2, 6, 496810) No sane Mussulman of my acquaintance has ever entertained the latter idea.
('23', 211, 2, 7, 496885) The world is growing sick of the domi nation of brute force.
('23', 211, 3, 8, 496946) I assure Mr. Pal that I do not believe in flirtation with any senti ment.
('23', 211, 3, 9, 497020) I reject those that are bad, and hug those that are good.
('23', 211, 3, 10, 497078) I do not believe that serious Mussulmans will welcome Afghan rule any more than serious Hindus would.
('23', 211, 3, 11, 497180) In writing my article on “The Afghan Bogey”, I was minded only to defend the correct position of a com rade, and to warn India against being frightened by the interested cry.
('23', 211, 4, 12, 497355) I totally dissent from Mr. Pal's view that the event of an Afghan invasion, or even the mere circulation of a rumour of such invasion will incite a very large part of our Muslim population to lawlessness, if not to open “revolt”.
('23', 211, 4, 13, 497585) On the contrary it is my firm belief that the Mussulmans hav too much at stake today—the honour of their religion—to do any such foolish act.
('23', 211, 4, 14, 497727) As Maulana Shaukat Ali has said so often, the Mussulmans are too shrewd to mix up violence wih non violence.
('23', 211, 4, 15, 497836) Mr. Pal has done a grave injustice to the Hindus by attribu ting to a “very large proportion” of Hindus “a desire to settle their own account with the Mohammedans”.
('23', 211, 4, 16, 498001) He has, I venture to assure him, entirely misread the Hindu mind.
('23', 211, 4, 17, 498067) The Hindus are as much in earnest about the cow, as the Mussulmans about the Khilafat.
('23', 211, 4, 18, 498154) And the former know that they cannot save the cow—the cherished dream of every Hindu—without the goodwill of the latter.
('23', 211, 4, 19, 498275) I promise that the Hindus will forget every wrong done in the past by every Mussulman when the latter helps them to save the cow as I know every Mussulman will feel eternally grateful to the Hindus if he finds that he has retrieved the honour of Islam by thier voluntary aid.
('23', 211, 4, 20, 498551) I deny in toto he truth of the proposition laid down by Mr. Pal: that Muslims and Hindus would welcome an Afghan invasion.
('23', 211, 4, 21, 498674) The protests that have been made against the supposed intentions of
('23', 212, 0, 1, 498742) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 213
('23', 212, 1, 2, 498784) Maulana Mahomed Ali are surely enough to convince anybody that India will not tolerate an Afghan invasion.
('23', 212, 1, 3, 498891) Mr. Pal suggest that if the Amir invades and if we do not aid the Government, there can only be a revolution.
('23', 212, 1, 4, 499001) I venture to suggest another alternative.
('23', 212, 1, 5, 499043) If India, as a non co operating, India does not assist, the Government will make terms with the people.
('23', 212, 1, 6, 499147) I do not consider the British people to be so utterly devoid of common sense or resourcefulness as to leave India, rather than come to terms with her and heal the Khilafat and the Punjab wounds.
('23', 212, 1, 7, 499342) That India does not yet possess the power to command attention I know only too well.
('23', 212, 1, 8, 499427) I have simply suggested a contingent alternative.
('23', 212, 1, 9, 499477) Mr. Pal sees a difference between Lalaji's 1 and my declaration at Simla and our previous declarations.
('23', 212, 1, 10, 499581) I know, none—neither Lalaji nor I—has ever welcomed an Afghan invasion.
('23', 212, 1, 11, 499653) But I gladly lay down my own position in categorical terms.
('23', 212, 1, 12, 499713) (1) I do not believe that the Afghans want to invade India.
('23', 212, 1, 13, 499773) (2) I believe that the Government is fully prepared to meet an Afghan invasion.
('23', 212, 1, 14, 499853) (3) I am sorry to confess that if there was an Afghan invasion, every Raja and Maharaja will render unconditional assistance to the Government.
('23', 212, 1, 15, 499997) (4) I believe, too, that we as a people are still so demoralized , diffident and distrustful of Afghan intentions, and Hindus and Mussalmans of one another, that many would in mere panic rush to the help of the Government and thus still further strengthen the chain that binds India.

('23', 217, 1, 2, 511260) 102. THE POET’S ANXIETY
('23', 217, 2, 3, 511284) The poet of Asia, as Lord Hardinge called Dr.Tagore, is fast becoming, if he has not already become, the Poet of the world.
('23', 217, 2, 4, 511408) Increasing prestige has brought to him increasing responsibility.
('23', 217, 2, 5, 511474) His greatest service to India must be his poetic interpretation of India’s message to the world.
('23', 217, 2, 6, 511571) The Poet is therefore sincerely anxious that India should deliver no false or feeble message in her name.
('23', 217, 2, 7, 511677) He is naturally jealous of his country’s reputation.
('23', 217, 2, 8, 511730) He says he has striven hard to find himself in tune with the present movement.
('23', 217, 2, 9, 511809) He confesses that he is baffled.
('23', 217, 2, 10, 511842) He can find nothing for his lyre in the din and the bustle of non co operation.
('23', 217, 2, 11, 511922) In three forceful letters 1 he has endea voured to give expression to his misgivings, and he has come to the conclusion that non co operation is not dignified enough for the India of his vision, that it is a doctrine of negation and despair.
('23', 217, 2, 12, 512164) He fears that it is a doctrine of separation, exclusiveness, narrowness and negation.
('23', 217, 2, 13, 512250) No Indian can feel anything but pride in the Poet’s exquisite jealousy of India’s honour.
('23', 217, 2, 14, 512340) It is good the he should have sent to us his misgivings in language at once beautiful and clear.

('23', 217, 2, 17, 512789) If in actual application, it appears in the end to have failed, it will be no more the fault of the doctrine than it would be of Truth if those who claim to apply it in practice do not appear to succeed.
('23', 217, 2, 18, 512993) Non co operation may have come in advance of its time.

('23', 220, 2, 6, 519140) 103. KHILAFAT AND NON VIOLENCE
('23', 220, 3, 7, 519171) Mr. Vaze of the Servant of India has referred me to the article of Mr.Zacharias in his weekly of 5th May last, and asked me to consider the Khilafat from the point of view suggested by the writer.
('23', 220, 3, 8, 519368) Mr. Zacharias thus puts the question in his elaborate article:
('23', 220, 4, 9, 519431) How could one find an apostle of the principle of ahimsa upholding its very contradiction,—the principle of the Khilafat ?
('23', 220, 4, 10, 519554) I am not concerned with the truth value of either the khilafat or the ahimsa principle .
('23', 220, 4, 11, 519643) But I do say that the one excludes the others; the one thing I do plead for and most earnestly is clear thinking on the part of either side to this problem.
('23', 220, 4, 12, 519800) It is muddled thinking and the consequent slide into compromise that is responsible for disaster in the recent history of mankind more than any other factor.
('23', 220, 4, 13, 519958) After instancing ex President Wilson's fall, the writer goes on :
('23', 220, 5, 14, 520024) Will the great satyagrahi of the East heed the warning?
('23', 220, 5, 15, 520080) Will he be faithful to his whole life?
('23', 220, 5, 16, 520119) Will he not remain true to himself rather than compromise himself, for the sake even of so precious a thing as Hindu Muslim friendship is, with this antithesis of his, the principle of Khilafat ?
('23', 220, 5, 17, 520315) This fervent appeal requires a restatement of my position regar ding the Khilafat.
('23', 220, 5, 18, 520398) I would be false to my whole life if, even for securing Hindu Muslim unity, I compromised the Principle of non violence for which I do claim to stand.
('23', 220, 5, 19, 520549) It was only when I found that the Mussulman claim was just from every point of view that I plunged myself into it.
('23', 220, 5, 20, 520664) For me it was a chance of a life time.
('23', 220, 5, 21, 520703) I felt that if I could but show my loyalty to my Mussulman countrymen in the hour of their trial I would be able to secure everlasting friendship between the two great communities.
('23', 220, 5, 22, 520884) Any way I felt that the attempt was worth making.
('23', 220, 5, 23, 520934) I could not conceive the possibility of having a free India without a real friendship between the two.
('23', 220, 5, 24, 521037) But argues Mr.Zacharias, the Khilafat is based on force.
('23', 220, 5, 25, 521094) The Khilafat is the earthly representative of Islam pledged o defend it even with the sword.
('23', 220, 5, 26, 521187) And how can I, a believer in non violence, fight to sustain an institution that is permitted to resort to physical force for its
('23', 221, 0, 1, 521316) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 221, 1, 2, 521358) defense?
('23', 221, 1, 3, 521367) Mr.Zacharias is right in his description of the Khilafat.
('23', 221, 1, 4, 521425) He is wrong in his estimate of the function of a votary of non violence.
('23', 221, 1, 5, 521498) A beli ever in non violence is pledged not to resort to violence or physical force either directly or indirectly in defense of anything, but he is not precluded from helping men or institutions that are themselves not based on non violence.
('23', 221, 1, 6, 521739) If the reverse were the case I would, for instance, be precluded from helping India to attain swaraj because the future Parliament of India under swaraj, I know for certain, will be having some military and police forces, or to take a domestic illustration, I may not help a son to secure justice, because forsooth he is not a believer in non violence.
('23', 221, 1, 7, 522092) Mr. Zacharias's proposition will reduce all commerce by a believer in non violence to an impossibility.
('23', 221, 1, 8, 522196) And there are not want ing men who do believe that complete non violence means complete cessation of all activity.
('23', 221, 1, 9, 522311) Not such, however, is my doctrine of non violence.
('23', 221, 1, 10, 522362) My business is to refrain from doing any violence myself, and to induce by persua sion and service as many of God’s creatures as I can to join me in the belief and practice.
('23', 221, 1, 11, 522536) But I would be undrue to my faith if I refused to assist in a just cause any men or measures that did not entirely coin cide with the principle of non violence.
('23', 221, 1, 12, 522697) I would be promoting vio lence, if finding the Mussulmans to be in the right, I did not assist them by means strictly non violent against those who had treache rously plotted the destruction of the dignity of Islam.
('23', 221, 1, 13, 522913) Even when both parties believe in violence, there is often such a thing as justice on one side or the other.

('23', 226, 3, 10, 534764) June 1, 1921 As we go ahead, we shall not need to address our petitions to the Government; we shall do that to ourselves.

('23', 226, 3, 15, 535304) We have no use for the non violence of the stone, of one who would not be disturbed even when kicked; no use, either, for the non violence of the brute, of the dog, who, when someone strikes it, barks or runs to bite the person.

('23', 228, 1, 2, 538456) 106. RESOLUTIONS 1
('23', 228, 2, 3, 538475) June 1, 1921 (1) This Conference heartily supports the resolution on nonviolent non co operation adopted at the Nagpur session of the Indian National Congress and it calls upon all classes of people to work with greater vigour and in a more organized manner to fulfil the resolution, especially because this Conference believes that the rate at which it is being worked out in Gujarat is not sufficient to guarantee swaraj within the current year.
('23', 228, 2, 4, 538923) (2) This Conference deems it obligatory on Gujarat to enrol three lacs of members on the Congress Committees, to collect 10 lakhs of rupees for the Tilak Swaraj Fund and to set one lakh of spinning wheels at work according to the programme sketched out by the All India Congress Committee at Bezwada and calls upon all workers in villages talakus and districts to contribute their mite before 30th of June.
('23', 228, 2, 5, 539330) (3) Non violence in thought, speech and action is an essential ingredient of the scheme of non co operation and its fulfilment largely depends upon the observance of the creed of non violence, and therefore this Conference urges all to preserve perfect peace even in spite of any persecution or provocation offered by Government officials, to avoid the use of malevolent speech and to concentrate entirely on the work suggested by the I.N.Congress and to cease observing hartals without the special mandate of the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee and to avoid all hostile demonstrations in case of leaders being arrested by Government.
('23', 228, 2, 6, 539971) (a) This Conference expresses its sense of satisfaction at the peace observed throughout the country in spite of the repressive policy of the Government and expresses its emphatic regret and dis appointment at the acts of violence committed on Government officers and leading co operators at Malegaon.

('23', 234, 2, 3, 550447) THE NEED OF THE HOUR It will be nothing short of a tragedy if we do not fulfil the Bezwada programme before the end of the month.
('23', 234, 2, 4, 550577) Seven days of the month will have gone before these notes are out.
('23', 234, 2, 5, 550644) We have not a moment to spare.
('23', 234, 2, 6, 550675) We have hardly collected twenty lakhs of rupees as yet.
('23', 234, 2, 7, 550731) To collect eighty lakhs during the next three weeks may seem an impossibility.
('23', 234, 2, 8, 550810) But the seeming impossibility can be easily turned into a possibility if we were ceaselessly to work for the collection.
('23', 234, 2, 9, 550931) Twenty one provinces, if they will respond according to their ability, can easily furnish the balance.
('23', 234, 2, 10, 551034) The Bezwada programme is the most concrete ever placed before the nation.
('23', 234, 2, 11, 551108) If the people are with us and if we have enough workers, one crore of rupees is a mere nothing for thirty crores of people to find for a cause so great as that of swaraj, and for perpetuating a memory so great as that of the Lokamanya.
('23', 234, 2, 12, 551344) If they choose, the women of India can give the money out of their jewellery, the liquor drinkers can give it out of their drinks.
('23', 234, 2, 13, 551475) The mill owners, who have derived the greatest benefit from the swadeshi movement, can find the eighty lakhs in a day.
('23', 234, 2, 14, 551594) The Marwadis can, without any strain on their resources, find the amount, and so could the Bhatias, the Memons, the Parsis or the banias.
('23', 234, 2, 15, 551732) They are all a prosperous community, and have before now more or less supported public movements.
('23', 234, 2, 16, 551830) If they wish, the Sindhis can also find the amount.
('23', 234, 2, 17, 551882) The labourers of India could pay the whole amount, if they sacrificed one twelfth of their yearly earnings.
('23', 234, 2, 18, 551990) I have consulted many friends as to the amount that can be easily paid by the respective classes mentioned by me.
('23', 234, 2, 19, 552104) The following may serve as a working basis : (1) Salaried men to pay one tenth of their monthly pay.
('23', 234, 2, 20, 552205) (2) Lawyers, doctors, merchants and such others to pay one twelfth of their net annual income as at the end of May last.
('23', 234, 3, 21, 552326) (3) Propertied men to pay 2 1 2 p.c.
('23', 234, 3, 22, 552363) of the valuation of their
('23', 234, 4, 23, 552389) property.
('23', 234, 4, 24, 552399) (4) All the others to pay not less than four annas each.
('23', 234, 4, 25, 552456) If all were to pay according to this scale, there would be several crores of rupees.

('23', 236, 1, 2, 555250) GUJARAT’S RESOLVE Gujarat has held its Provincial Conference and its Khilafat Con ference at the historic town of Broach.
('23', 236, 1, 3, 555372) The Conferences met on the banks of the beautiful Narmada.
('23', 236, 1, 4, 555431) It had also a khaddar and charkha exhibition.
('23', 236, 1, 5, 555477) The great variety of charkha showed that India's inventive genius was being profitably utilized.

('23', 236, 1, 7, 555729) Addresses of the Chairman of the Reception Committee and the President of the Conference were both brief and to the point.
('23', 236, 1, 8, 555852) The Chairman, Mr.Haribhai Amin, took no more than fifteen minutes to read his simple address.
('23', 236, 1, 9, 555946) The President, Mr.Vallabhbhai Patel, took no more than thirty minutes to read the whole of his address.

('23', 236, 1, 11, 556140) It has not one bitter word for the opponents of non co operation.

('23', 250, 2, 17, 592027) 116.SPINNING v.
('23', 250, 2, 18, 592043) HAND WEAVING TO THE EDITOR Young India
('23', 250, 3, 19, 592082) I have read with great interest Dr. S.B. Mitra’s letter and your comments thereon in the issue of May 11. 1 You say, “Hand spinning includes all that the correspondent suggests, but it includes much more.” Thus you imply that hand spinning includes hand weaving and some other things.
('23', 250, 4, 20, 592367) I am afraid that to most people spinning means spinning only, and as all your force has been laid on the charkha and spinning, and not on weaving and the handloom explicitly, the latter has faded into insignificance in the public imagination.
('23', 250, 4, 21, 592610) We hear of spinning wheel classes and competitions, but nowhere of the introduction of new looms, much less of making of thousands of looms, even of the most rudimentary type.
('23', 250, 4, 22, 592786) For every ten new spinning wheels introduced, there must be one additional handloom pit or improved orfly shuttle introduced at the same time and without any loss of time.
('23', 250, 4, 23, 592958) Otherwise, there will be a great pressure on the existing handlooms, and hundreds of khandies 2 of hand spun yarn will be
('23', 250, 5, 24, 593080) heaped upon the weaver, who naturally prefers the mill made yarn, it being
('23', 250, 6, 25, 593155) 1 Vide “Greater Use of Handlooms”, 11 5 1921.
('23', 250, 7, 26, 593201) 2 A measure of weight, about 20 maunds.
('23', 251, 0, 1, 593241) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 251, 1, 2, 593283) easier to weave.
('23', 251, 1, 3, 593300) Up to last year, there was an equilibrium, so to speak, between the number of the handlooms in the counry and the yarn foreign or Indian mill made—that remains in the country.
('23', 251, 1, 4, 593476) By the production of hand spun yarn in very large quantities in the country this equilibrium is distrurbed, and this state of things can be remedied only by a proportionate increase in the number of looms—ten wheels to one loom roughly.
('23', 251, 1, 5, 593713) As a humble worker in the field of khadi production in Kathiawad, I am bound to say that while thousands of new wheels are set to work, not even a few dozen new looms are being made.
('23', 251, 1, 6, 593896) The result is that there is a keen competition between those who produce cloth from mill made yarn and hand spun yarn with consequent increase in the cost of weaving.
('23', 251, 2, 7, 594063) I take this opportunity of stating that a few months ago I was a sceptic about the possibilities of the charkha.
('23', 251, 2, 8, 594176) Being quite unacquainted with village economics, I doubted as many paper economists still do, whether two annas or even three were enough for a single person’s subsistence, and therefore whether hand spinning was a practical proposition.
('23', 251, 2, 9, 594414) Now, when I see in every khadi producing centre scores of women being daily turned back, as I have to restrict my operations for want of weavers in the areas concerned, I see all the advantages you advocate as following from the introduction of hand spinning on a large scale.
('23', 251, 2, 10, 594691) But I wish you would lay some, if not equal emphasis, on the importance of weaving, as you do on spinning by hand.
('23', 251, 2, 11, 594806) The loom is not less important than the wheel for clothing India, as for proving a supplementary industry for our semi starved peasantry.
('23', 251, 3, 12, 594944) Amreli, Kathiawad A. V. THAKKAR
('23', 251, 4, 13, 594976) 20 5 1921 I do not think there is any danger of hand weaving not keeping pace with hand spinning.
('23', 251, 4, 14, 595074) Moreover, the existing looms which are weaving foreign yarn have to be freed.
('23', 251, 4, 15, 595152) The fact is that we have not as yet been able to reach the requisite strength in our hand spun yarn.
('23', 251, 4, 16, 595253) The problem now is to improve the quality of hand spun yarn, so that it can be easily woven by the ordinary weavers.
('23', 251, 4, 17, 595370) For the surplus yarn, I suggest its use for making ropes, tape, straps and countless other things that can be easily made.
('23', 251, 4, 18, 595493) Hand weaving is not so easily learnt by all as hand spinning is.
('23', 251, 4, 19, 595558) At the same time, I do not wish to be understood to imply that no special effort needs to be made for hand weaving.
('23', 251, 4, 20, 595674) My point is that it is going on as fast as possible.
('23', 251, 4, 21, 595727) The weaver’s wage has increased because of the appreciation of swadeshi.
('23', 251, 4, 22, 595800) It ought to have increased.
('23', 251, 4, 23, 595828) A weaver is any day equal, say, to a carpenter who gets more than the former.

('23', 272, 1, 2, 642817) 126. NOTES
('23', 272, 2, 3, 642828) THAT APOLOGY
('23', 272, 3, 4, 642841) The Ali Borthers’ apology still continues to tax people’s minds.
('23', 272, 3, 5, 642906) I continue to receive letters expostulationg with me for having gone to the Viceroy at all.
('23', 272, 3, 6, 642998) Some consider that I have bungled the whole affair; others blame the Brothers for having for once weakened, and that in defernce to me.
('23', 272, 3, 7, 643134) I know that in a short while the storm will blow over.
('23', 272, 3, 8, 643189) For, in spite of all I have heard and read, I feel that I did the right thing in responding to the Viceroy’s wish to know my views.
('23', 272, 3, 9, 643321) It would have been wrong on my part to have waited for a formal written inviation from His Excellency.
('23', 272, 3, 10, 643424) I feel, too, that I gave the best advice possible in the interests of Islam and India, when I asked the Brothers to make the statement issued by them.
('23', 272, 3, 11, 643575) The Ali Brothers have showed humility and courage of a high order in making the statement.
('23', 272, 3, 12, 643666) They have shown that they are capable of sacrificing their pride and their all for the sake of their faith and country.
('23', 272, 3, 13, 643786) They have served the cause by making the statement, as they would have injured it by declining to make it.
('23', 272, 3, 14, 643893) A REMONSTRANCE In spite of all that conviction in me, I am not surprised at the remonstrances I am receiving.
('23', 272, 3, 15, 644003) They but show that the methods now being pursued are new, that the country will not surrender a little of its just demands, and for their satisfaction, it wishes to purely rely upon is own strength.
('23', 272, 3, 16, 644202) I give below the relevant parts of the strongest argument in condemnation of my advice and its acceptance by the Brothers.
('23', 272, 3, 17, 644325) The letter, moreover, is written by one of the greatest among the non co operators.
('23', 272, 3, 18, 644409) It is not written for publication at all.
('23', 272, 3, 19, 644451) But I know the writer will not mind my sharing it with the reader.
('23', 272, 3, 20, 644518) For I have no doubt that he represents the sentiments of several thoughtful non co operators.
('23', 272, 3, 21, 644612) It is my humble duty to discuss the issues arising from the incident, and the implications of non co operation.
('23', 272, 3, 22, 644724) It is only by patient reasoning that I hope to be able to demonstrate the truth, the beauty and the reasonableness of non co operation.
('23', 272, 3, 23, 644860) Here then are the extracts:
('23', 272, 4, 24, 644888) The statement of the Brothers, taken by itself and read without reference to what has preceded and followed it, is a manly enough document.
('23', 272, 4, 25, 645028) If, in the
('23', 273, 0, 1, 645039) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 273, 1, 2, 645081) heat of the moment, they have said things which, they now find may reasonably be taken to have a tendency to incite to violence, they have, in publishing their regret, taken the only honourable course open to public men of their position.
('23', 273, 1, 3, 645320) I should also have been prepared to justify the undertaking they have given for the future, had that undertaking been addressed to those of their co workers, who, unlike themselves, do not believe in the cult of violence in any circumstances whatever.
('23', 273, 1, 4, 645572) But the general words ‘public assurance and promise to all who may require it’ cannot, in the circumstances, leave anyone in doubt as to the particular party who did require such ‘assurance and promise’ and at whose bidding it was given.
('23', 273, 1, 5, 645810) The Viceroy’s speech has now made it perfectly clear, and we have the indisputable fact that the leader of the non co operation movement has been treating wih the Government, and has secured the suspension of the prosecution of the Brothers, by inducing them to give a public apology and an undertaking.
('23', 273, 2, 6, 646114) In this view of the case,—and I fail to see what other view is possible— very serious questions affecting the whole movement arise for consideration.
('23', 273, 2, 7, 646264) Indeed it seems to me that the whole principle of non co operation has been given away.
('23', 273, 3, 8, 646352) I am not one of those who fight shy of the very name of Government, nor of those who look upon an eventual settlement with the Government as the only means of obtaining redress of our wrongs and establishing swaraj.
('23', 273, 3, 9, 646568) I believe in what you have constantly taught, viz., that the achievement of swaraj rests entirely and solely with us.
('23', 273, 3, 10, 646686) At the same time, I do not, nor so far as I am aware do you, exclude the possibility of a settlement with the Government under proper conditions.
('23', 273, 3, 11, 646832) Such settlement, however, can only relate to principles, and can have nothing to do with the convenience or safety of individuals.
('23', 273, 3, 12, 646963) In a body of co workers you cannot make distinctions between man and man, and the humblest of them is entitled to the same protection at the hands of the leaders as the most prominent.
('23', 273, 3, 13, 647148) Scores, if not hundreds, of our men have willingly gone to gaol for using language far less strong than that indulged in by the Brothers.
('23', 273, 3, 14, 647286) Some at least of these could easily have been saved by giving a similar apology and undertaking, and yet it never occurred to anyone to advise them to do so.
('23', 273, 3, 15, 647444) On the contrary, their action was applauded by the leaders and the whole of the non co operationist Press.
('23', 273, 3, 16, 647551) The case which more forcibly than any other comes to my mind at the moment is that of Hamid Ahmad, who has recently been sentenced at Allahabad to tansportation for life and forfeiture of property.
('23', 273, 3, 17, 647749) Is there any reason why this man should not be saved ?
('23', 273, 3, 18, 647804) I find Maulana Mahomed Ali pays him a high tribute in his Bombay speech of the 30th May.
('23', 273, 3, 19, 647893) What consolation this tribute will bring to Hamid Ahmad from a man similarly situated who has saved himself by an apology and
('23', 274, 0, 1, 648019) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 275
('23', 274, 1, 2, 648061) an under taking, I cannot say.
('23', 274, 1, 3, 648092) Then there are so many others rotting in gaol who have committed no offence, and a great many more already picked out for the same fate.
('23', 274, 1, 4, 648229) Is it enough for us to send them our good wishes from the safe positions we ourselves enjoy ?
('23', 274, 2, 5, 648323) The Viceroy in his speech has made it clear that the only definite result of the several interviews you had with him is the apology and the undertaking from the Brothers.
('23', 274, 2, 6, 648494) You have also made it quite clear in your subsequent speeches that our campaign is to go on unabated.
('23', 274, 2, 7, 648596) It seems that no point involving any principle has been settled, except what needed no negotiating on either side, viz., that there is to be no incitement to violence I do not say that, in this state of things, there should have been no trating with the Government, though much can be said in support of that view.
('23', 274, 2, 8, 648911) When it was found that the game had to be played out, it would have been quite legitimate for two such honourable adversaries as yourself and Lord Reading to agree to the rules of the game, so as to avoid foul play on either side.
('23', 274, 2, 9, 649142) These rules would, of course, apply to all who took part in the game, and not to certain favoured individuals only.

('23', 285, 1, 2, 676924) 128. MAGISTERIAL HIGH HANDEDNESS
('23', 285, 2, 3, 676957) The District Magistrate of Lahore has been prohibiting a meeting of the Lahore City Congress Committee.
('23', 285, 2, 4, 677061) Under the Seditious Meetings Act, public meetings are understood to be meetings to which a member of the public can demand entrance on com pliance with the rules of admission.
('23', 285, 2, 5, 677237) All other meetings are private.
('23', 285, 2, 6, 677269) The Lahore Committee meeting was advertised to be only for members of the Committee.
('23', 285, 2, 7, 677354) But the Magistrate was not satisfied.
('23', 285, 2, 8, 677392) He asked the Secretary to wait on him and give him satisfaction.
('23', 285, 2, 9, 677457) Lala Amirchand naturally declined to dance attendance on the Magistrate, and politely informed him that the meeting was private and had a definite object.
('23', 285, 2, 10, 677612) The Magistrate nevertheless prohibited the meeting.
('23', 285, 2, 11, 677664) The Secretary protested that the order was illegal, but informed the Magistrate that he would for the time being obey the order.
('23', 285, 2, 12, 677793) It is quite evident that the officials are challenging and provoking non co operators to offer civil disobedience.
('23', 285, 2, 13, 677908) A few more such orders, and I promise that the challenge will be heartily taken up.
('23', 285, 2, 14, 677992) Hitherto, we have obeyed such orders out of our weakness.
('23', 285, 2, 15, 678050) Now we are obeying out of strength which is daily growing.
('23', 285, 2, 16, 678109) All over the country, wherever such orders are given, the desire is keen for civil disobedience.
('23', 285, 2, 17, 678206) It is the exemplary self restraint and self imposed discipline which are keeping those who receive such orders from civilly disobeying them.
('23', 285, 2, 18, 678347) The country will gain fro having undergone still more discipline and exercise still more self restraint.
('23', 285, 2, 19, 678452) We shall need much more of both these qualities, before we can regard ourselves as fit for the privileged exercise of civil disobedience.
('23', 285, 2, 20, 678590) Disobedience to be civil excludes all bluster, all vio lence.
('23', 285, 2, 21, 678652) It excludes lawlessness.
('23', 285, 2, 22, 678677) A civil resister courts imprisonment.
('23', 285, 2, 23, 678715) It is, therefore, wrong to demonstrate against his arrest.
('23', 285, 2, 24, 678774) There must be real rejoicing, as there is when one has one’s heart’s desire fulfilled.There could be civil disobedience tomorrow, if we could ensure its restriction strictly to approved laws and orders, if we could be sure that the people would not resort to violence on the arrest of prominent leaders.
('23', 285, 2, 25, 679078) Civility is to dis obedience what non violence is to non co operation.
('23', 285, 2, 26, 679149) Disobedience is the acutest form of non co operation—more so than non payment of taxes.
('23', 285, 2, 27, 679237) A civil resister becomes law unto himself.
('23', 285, 2, 28, 679280) Courage and discrimination of a high order are needed for the practice of the virtue of civil disobedience.
('23', 285, 2, 29, 679388) It is a total denial of the authority of the State, and is permissible only

('23', 290, 1, 2, 687326) 130. SPEECH AT GHATKOPAR 1
('23', 290, 2, 3, 687353) June 15, 1921
('23', 290, 3, 4, 687367) Mahatma Gandhi, after thanking the residents of Ghatkopar for their address, accepted the forty thousand rupees which they had collected for the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('23', 290, 3, 5, 687531) He accepted these rupees only on certain condition.
('23', 290, 3, 6, 687583) If the sum they had collected represented the best efforts of the large merchants who were trading in Bombay, but were staying at Ghatkopar then he would at once say that they would never get swaraj this year.
('23', 290, 3, 7, 687793) He would have been satisfied if they had made the slightest sacrifice, but they had not done that.
('23', 290, 3, 8, 687892) He was again going to beg of his brothers and sisters to contribute their mite towards that Fund.
('23', 290, 3, 9, 687990) He was disappointed at the smallness of the amount they had collected, after they had admitted that Ghatkopar was a place where the rich Indian merchants of Bombay were residing.
('23', 290, 3, 10, 688169) It was not himself alone who was collecting money for the Fund.
('23', 290, 3, 11, 688233) There were the Ali Brothers on the platform, who, it was stated, managed to lead the speaker by his nose.
('23', 290, 3, 12, 688339) That was not the fact.
('23', 290, 3, 13, 688362) The Ali Brothers loved their religion and he loved his own and they were not going to give up their religion.
('23', 290, 3, 14, 688472) Each had his own dharma and each had to follow it implicitly, come what might.
('23', 290, 3, 15, 688551) Then there was the great Hakim Ajmal Khan.
('23', 290, 3, 16, 688594) He was not an ordinary man to come to Ghatkopar casually; his fees were high and he charged one thousand rupees a day for such visits.
('23', 290, 3, 17, 688729) He was not a doctor versed in the Western methods of medicine; he had a few secret medicines which were very efficacious.
('23', 290, 3, 18, 688851) Then there was Dr. Ansari who was well versed in the Western system of medicine—he had gained a diploma to kill people (Laughter.) for if a doctor killed a man they could not take any action against him.
('23', 290, 3, 19, 689055) (Laughter.) Then there was the great Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, who was a great authority on Islamic religion and law.
('23', 290, 3, 20, 689172) Why had all these great people come to Ghatkopar?
('23', 290, 3, 21, 689222) Not for the purpose of making speeches to them!
('23', 290, 3, 22, 689270) For that was not the time for making speeches, but for work, solid work for the country.
('23', 290, 4, 23, 689359) The residents of Ghatkopar had given him personally Rs. 40,000 but what were they going to give to their other guests like the Hakim and Dr. Ansari ?
('23', 290, 4, 24, 689509) They had also to give something to other workers like Seth Jamnalal Bajaj, Mr. Shankarlal and others who had assembled there.
('23', 290, 4, 25, 689635) They had not fully realized that this was the time when the prestige of this country would be assessed at its true worth.

('23', 299, 2, 8, 714238) Messrs Vimadalal and Dumasia asked Mr. Gandhi what sort of swaraj he wanted and whether their present rulers would have a place in it.
('23', 299, 3, 9, 714373) Mr. Gandhi said he wanted the army, police, law and revenue to be fully controlled by the people and they should be in a position to spend their own money.
('23', 299, 3, 10, 714529) At the present time, they were not able to appoint their Commander in Chief, neither were they able to stop the sending of a single sepoy out of India.
('23', 299, 3, 11, 714681) He was not, however, going to discuss such things as votes, etc.
('23', 299, 3, 12, 714746) If they were able to control these things now, Indians would be able to move forward gradually.
('23', 299, 3, 13, 714842) If they could manufacture all requirements of cloth, India would be welf dependent country, but now they were dependent on other people.
('23', 299, 3, 14, 714979) So long as they had to thank the Government for every small thing they got from it, they would not be able to achieve much.
('23', 299, 3, 15, 715103) They should achieve such a position that they would be able to do things without the help of other people.
('23', 299, 3, 16, 715210) He thought the non co operation movement had effected a great change in the mentality of the people, for instance, in Malabar the Moplahs who
('23', 299, 4, 17, 715352) were a spirited people had now become disciplined under its influence.
('23', 299, 5, 18, 715423) In reply to another question, Mr. Gandhi said he would be content with Dominion Self Government.
('23', 299, 5, 19, 715520) They Viceroy was of the opinion that they should get it gradually, while he was of the opinion that they should get it at once.
('23', 299, 5, 20, 715648) To those who said that they were not fit to rule themselves yet, he would say that it was because they were kept apart from their legitimate rights; he did not admit that Indians were incapable of ruling themselves.
('23', 299, 5, 21, 715864) He did not care whether their ministers were Indians or Englishmen.
('23', 299, 5, 22, 715932) What he wanted was the power of appointment and dismissal at any time he liked.
('23', 299, 5, 23, 716012) He did not want to dismiss a man simply because of his colour, but for his incompetence.
('23', 299, 5, 24, 716101) Ministers should have power over the Commissioners and Collectors.
('23', 299, 5, 25, 716168) He never admitted that Indians were incapable of administering the military department.
('23', 299, 6, 26, 716256) One gentleman said they were talking of Hindu Mohammedan unity but he did not know where the Parsis came in there.
('23', 299, 6, 27, 716371) Hindus and Muslims would appoint their own men and Parsis would be nowhere.
('23', 299, 7, 28, 716447) Mr. N. M. Dumasia said Sri Krishna Gupta had told them that so long as they were not able to defend themselves it was no use getting swaraj.
('23', 299, 7, 29, 716588) They ought to be able to defend themselves against a foreign government in the
('23', 300, 0, 1, 716667) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 301
('23', 300, 1, 2, 716709) first instance.
('23', 300, 2, 3, 716725) Mr. H. P. Modi said they had been working as clerks for so many years and they were not used to do military work and deal with their foreign relations.
('23', 300, 2, 4, 716877) They had been carrying out things under British control and therefore Indians were not accustomed to do them independently.
('23', 300, 3, 5, 717001) Mr. Gandhi said his opinion was that Englishmen were not yet prepared to leave India and he wanted them to remain not on their own terms but on those of Indians.
('23', 300, 3, 6, 717163) Englishmen would feel ashamed to leave India just now.
('23', 300, 3, 7, 717218) Another thing was he did not believe that if they got swaraj the next day, they would have to fight all the foreign governments all at once.
('23', 300, 3, 8, 717359) But even if they had to fight a foreign government, Indians then would go on fighting until victory was theirs.
('23', 300, 3, 9, 717471) He wanted them to realize that Indians could only get their objectives by means of their own strength, and not with the help of others or by means of tactics or stratagems.
('23', 300, 3, 10, 717644) They could only keep their rights by their ability to defend them and not by means of parliaments or assemblies.
('23', 300, 4, 11, 717757) Mr. Dumasia said it was the rule that a smaller nation should be beaten by a bigger nation.

('23', 300, 4, 15, 718108) Parsis hated both Dyerism and O’Dwyerism, as much as anybody.

('23', 300, 4, 17, 718262) They were not prepared to ask the English to go out of this country bag and baggage, and they did not want to get out of the Empire, over which King George ruled.
('23', 300, 4, 18, 718425) Any movement which did not exclude these things would have their fullest support.

('23', 305, 7, 20, 728084) 140. NOTES
('23', 305, 8, 21, 728095) AN OUNCE OF ACTION
('23', 305, 9, 22, 728114) Remarks in the Servant of India on the apology of the Ali Brothers show me more forcibly than anything else the truth of the statement that an ounce of action is worth more than tons of speeches.
('23', 305, 9, 23, 728310) I cannot conceive the possibility of the Servant of India wilfully misunderstanding or misinterpreting the apology.
('23', 305, 9, 24, 728426) Yet it has devoted to the apology three paragraphs which betray a hopeless misunder standing of it.
('23', 305, 9, 25, 728526) For me it was, and even in the light of the fierce
('23', 305, 10, 26, 728577) 1 Form of greeting among the Vaishnavas; literally, “Victory to Lord Krishna”.
('23', 306, 0, 1, 728656) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 307
('23', 306, 1, 2, 728698) controversy that has raged round it, it remains, an object lesson in the practice of non co operation.
('23', 306, 1, 3, 728801) It is the one act which will stand as a guiding star to the straying non co operators.They must continually purify themselves even in front of their opponents, and at the risk of their action being mistaken for weakness.
('23', 306, 1, 4, 729022) In the process of putting themselves in the right, they must not count the cost.
('23', 306, 1, 5, 729103) That is the implication of following truth for truth’s sake.
('23', 306, 1, 6, 729164) The immediate prospect may appear ever so black, a seeker must relentlessly pursue what he knows to be truth.
('23', 306, 1, 7, 729274) The Prophet would have lost his hold many a time had he not thus treated truth as his absolute and final sheet anchor.
('23', 306, 1, 8, 729393) Assuming that I gave my advice to the Ali Brothers out of my strength, and they understood and accepted it in their strength, the apology will be found to have done, as I know it has done, good to the cause of Islam and the country.
('23', 306, 1, 9, 729626) If, therefore, the last issue of Young India has not answered all doubts, 1 I must leave it to time to answer them.
('23', 306, 2, 10, 729742) POVERTY OF EXPRESSION Similar, but less important, misunderstanding has arisen regarding my letter 2 to the Moderates.
('23', 306, 2, 11, 729861) I am amazed at the poverty of expression I betray so often.
('23', 306, 2, 12, 729921) I am not by any means an indifferent writer.
('23', 306, 2, 13, 729966) I take great pains to be accurate and plain.
('23', 306, 2, 14, 730011) And yet I have succeeded in leaving the impression in a critic’ in the Servant of India, that I expect the Moderates to join he non co operators in picketing.
('23', 306, 2, 15, 730170) I do nothing of the kind.
('23', 306, 2, 16, 730196) Picketing might appear to the co operators to be too clumsy and too incomplete to commend itself to them.
('23', 306, 2, 17, 730302) But I thought that they would help the temperance cause in their own way, i.e., by immediately abolishing the drink shops.
('23', 306, 2, 18, 730425) It is the least they owe to the country.
('23', 306, 2, 19, 730466) Daily, as the heat of the picketing is increasing, the pickets come in for the attentions of the keepers of liquor shops and of their customers.
('23', 306, 2, 20, 730611) I understand that two pickets were struck by some ruffians and had their heads broken in Ahmedabad.
('23', 306, 2, 21, 730711) These brave men now daily appear at their post with bandaged heads.
('23', 306, 2, 22, 730779) A volunteer was slapped in the presence of a crowd in Bombay, and he stood his ground firmly but did not retaliate.
('23', 306, 2, 23, 730895) Such instances must multiply, as the effect of picketing is felt by the sellers of spirituous liquors.
('23', 306, 2, 24, 730998) It is impossible to stop this reform, even though pickets lose their lives in the performance of their duty.
('23', 306, 2, 25, 731107) The work
('23', 306, 3, 26, 731116) 1 Vide “Notes”, 15 6 1921. 2 Vide “To the Moderates”, 8 6 1921.
('23', 307, 0, 1, 731180) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 307, 1, 2, 731222) must continue so long as there are enough young men and women found ready to take up picketing, and so long as they are ready to risk their lives without retaliating.
('23', 307, 1, 3, 731389) It was because I was aware of the danger that I appealed to the patriotism of the Moderates with a view to abolishing at a stroke all drink shops, and thus saving young men and young women from injury to limb or life.
('23', 307, 1, 4, 731607) It grieves me, therefore, to find that I failed in my letter to carry the point home.
('23', 307, 1, 5, 731693) I am aware that, at some future date, temperance reform will come.
('23', 307, 1, 6, 731760) It is small comfort to a man whose house is on fire that appliances are in course of preparation to deal with such fires.
('23', 307, 1, 7, 731882) BRITISH V. OTHER GOVERNMENTS ‘Observer’ in The Times of India asks me some questions pertaining to the movement.
('23', 307, 1, 8, 731995) I am sorry I have not been able to answer them earlier.
('23', 307, 1, 9, 732051) They would have escaped me had not a friend sent me the cutting.Observer’ asks whether the British ‘is not a better Govern ment than the Mogul and the Maratha’.
('23', 307, 1, 10, 732212) I must dare to say that the Mogul and the Maratha Governments were better than the British in that the nation as a whole was not so emasculate or so impoverished as it is today.
('23', 307, 1, 11, 732390) We were not the pariahs of the Mogul or the Maratha Empire.
('23', 307, 1, 12, 732450) We are pariahs of the British Empire.
('23', 307, 2, 13, 732488) WHAT SHOULD PARSIS DO?
('23', 307, 2, 14, 732511) ‘Observer’ next asks :
('23', 307, 3, 15, 732534) Are the Parsis to ask their children to leave Government and aided schools when no provision is made for national schools adapted to meet the special requirements of the Parsis?
('23', 307, 3, 16, 732712) Are the Parsi lawyers to boycott law courts and starve their families?
('23', 307, 3, 17, 732783) Are the Parsis to give up their lucrative vocations and devote themselves to spinning yarn for three annas a day?
('23', 307, 3, 18, 732897) The three annas per day will not suffice to pay their daily bill for soda water, let alone whisky and soda.
('23', 307, 3, 19, 733005) Or, should the Parsis give up their present dress, which is more European than Asiatic, and go back to the days of their ancestors, who used to put on pyjamas with legs wide enough to carry a dozen fowl?
('23', 307, 3, 20, 733209) Is it possible, thus, to set back the hand of time?
('23', 307, 3, 21, 733261) Will Mr. Gandhi be so good as to give a convincing reply to these queries?
('23', 307, 3, 22, 733336) Parsis are the pioneers in matters educational.
('23', 307, 3, 23, 733384) They need not withdraw a single child from the present schools.

('23', 312, 2, 4, 742904) I have received Dr. John Pollen’s open letter.

('23', 312, 2, 6, 743016) It is quite like him.

('23', 312, 2, 8, 743113) Yet he has seen no harm in condemning what he does not know.
('23', 312, 2, 9, 743174) He asks me to rely upon his own ipse dixit in preference to my own experience.
('23', 312, 2, 10, 743253) The pity of it is that Dr. Pollen’s letter represents the average English attitude—laziness to study the other side, and arrogation of omniscience and consequent self satisfaction.
('23', 312, 2, 11, 743434) With a people so constituted, either non co operation or violence is the only thing that answers.
('23', 312, 2, 12, 743532) If you murder, they are shocked into action; if you cease to speak to them, they are moved to inquire.
('23', 312, 2, 13, 743635) The shock produced by murder provokes action, but rarely enlightenment.
('23', 312, 2, 14, 743707) It creates bad blood, not excluding terrorism.
('23', 312, 2, 15, 743754) The relief is partial and often proves more dangerous than the disease itself.
('23', 312, 2, 16, 743833) Whereas the refusal to speak, to participate in the evil, to assist one’s own degradation, to co operate with the wrongdoer, gives strength to oneself, and awakens and purifies the wrongdoer.
('23', 312, 2, 17, 744025) India, I hope, has chosen the better way for all time.
('23', 312, 2, 18, 744080) Dr. Pollen is too lazy to see that non co operation, being an insurance against violence, necessarily involves the possibility of violence.
('23', 312, 2, 19, 744220) It is an attempt to supplant violence.

('23', 312, 2, 22, 744505) It heals without killing.

('23', 333, 2, 3, 795921) The 30th June, Thursday, is nearing.
('23', 333, 2, 4, 795958) Navajivan will be in readers’ hands on Sunday.
('23', 333, 2, 5, 796005) Gujarat’s and India’s test will be completed on Thursday.
('23', 333, 2, 6, 796063) 1. Gujarat should collect Rs. 10 lakhs for perpetuating the memory of Lokamanya Tilak and for winning swaraj.
('23', 333, 2, 7, 796173) 2. Three lakh members should join the Congress.
('23', 333, 2, 8, 796221) 3. Gujarat should take the number of spinning wheels put into commission to one lakh.
('23', 333, 2, 9, 796307) If we resolve, we can complete what remains undone.
('23', 333, 2, 10, 796359) Every reader of Navajivan should, without waiting for anyone to approach him, pay up what he can at the nearest collection centre and obtain a receipt for it.
('23', 333, 2, 11, 796518) Every reader should persuade his friends to contribute.
('23', 333, 2, 12, 796574) Every reader, if he is 21 years of age and is not yet a member of the Congress, should become one without delay and persuade others to do likewise.
('23', 333, 2, 13, 796722) Every reader should acquire a spinning wheel, if he has not already got one, and learn spinning.
('23', 333, 2, 14, 796819) Knowing that these four days are invaluable and will not come again, every reader should devote as much of his time as possible exclusively to these three tasks.
('23', 333, 2, 15, 796981) Every reader should look upon the nation’s work as his own and attend to it expeditiously.
('23', 333, 2, 16, 797072) No one should think that nothing can be done in the four days which remain.
('23', 333, 2, 17, 797148) During four days, thousands will be born and thousands will die.
('23', 333, 2, 18, 797213) In but one night, the future of a man like Ramachandra changed; in but one day, Harishchandra gave up everything for the sake of truth and Yudhishthira lost his kingdom in gambling.
('23', 333, 2, 19, 797395) One day can be of no little value in man’s or a nation’s life.

('23', 333, 2, 21, 797490) If Gujarat wants swaraj—the rule of dharma—to be won through its efforts, it must score full marks in this first test.

('23', 339, 8, 11, 810727) OFFICERS AND OFFICIALS The Viceroy’s reply to the Ahmadiyya community shows that he has passed into the hands of a bureaucracy that is clever, united and utterly unscrupulous.His defence of officers and officials supplies the meaning of racial equality.
('23', 339, 8, 12, 810981) The Viceroy sees no inequality in the impunity with which Europeans may commit crimes against Indian humanity.
('23', 339, 8, 13, 811092) I recall the extraordinary judgment of a Punjab magistrate, who considers that justice is satisfied when he draws upon his imagination for extenuating causes, and fines a young Irish soldier fifty rupees for interfering with the liberty of an innocent Indian woman.
('23', 339, 8, 14, 811358) His Excellency does not care to study the daily Press which is replete with instances of insults hurled against Indians by Europeans.
('23', 339, 8, 15, 811492) He seems to be unaware of the fact that British officers will not tolerate the presence of Indian judges in their railway compartment.
('23', 339, 8, 16, 811627) The Viceroy says : There is no foundation, I verily believe, for any suggestion that the British official is anxious to assert racial superi ority over the Indian with whom he comes in contact.’ I assure Lord Reading that his observation is so contrary to the everyday experience of the average Indian that it must prejudice the people against the soundness of his judgment or even the honesty of his purpose.
('23', 339, 8, 17, 812037) They will see in his certificates of character to officials and officers a studied refusal to see the truth and do justice.
('23', 339, 8, 18, 812161) They will not give him the benefit of the doubt and think, as I do, that the Viceroy is not wilfully blind but is not permitted to see things, except so much as the

('23', 341, 2, 4, 815130) In every case in which a sentence of transportation for life shall have been passed, the Government of India or the Government of the place within which the offender shall have been sentenced may, without the consent of the offender, commute the punishment for imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years.
('23', 341, 2, 5, 815467) It is clear under this section, that Mr. Ganesh Damodar Savarkar should have been discharged two months ago.
('23', 341, 2, 6, 815576) The brothers having been removed from the Andamans, the section I have quoted must operate in their favour, and they may not be detained for a period exceeding fourteen years.
('23', 341, 2, 7, 815752) All remissions already granted must count in reduction of fourteen years.
('23', 341, 2, 8, 815826) This instance brought to light by the assiduity of an affectionate brother is probably not the only one of its kind.

('23', 349, 2, 14, 836759) 159. THE WORKING COMMITTEE AND ITS FUNCTION
('23', 349, 3, 15, 836803) The resolutions of the Working Committee have come in for some hostile criticism.
('23', 349, 3, 16, 836885) Its ruling, questioning the propriety of non co operating lawyers attending law courts and non co operating defen dants entering upon their defence in law courts, has been seriously called in question, and it has even been suggested that its rulings may be disregarded.
('23', 349, 3, 17, 837155) It is, therefore, necessary to examine the function of the Working Committee.
('23', 349, 3, 18, 837233) And before we can understand this, we must understand the Congress Constitution.
('23', 349, 3, 19, 837314) The goal of the Congress is attainment of swaraj by peaceful and legitimate means.The Congress must be worked so as to hasten India’s progress towards her destined goal.
('23', 349, 3, 20, 837484) The Constitution is so
('23', 350, 0, 1, 837507) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 351
('23', 350, 1, 2, 837549) devised as to tax and prove the nation’s capacity for self government.
('23', 350, 1, 3, 837620) It undoubtedly sets up a system of voluntary government, in which the only force available is public opinion and the goodwill of the people.
('23', 350, 1, 4, 837761) And seeing that the Congress is today engaged in opposing and, if need be, destroying the existing system, it follows that the greater the authority of the Congress, the less must be that of the Government.
('23', 350, 1, 5, 837968) When the Con gress commands complete confidence and willing obedience to its instructions, there is full swaraj.
('23', 350, 1, 6, 838081) For, then the Government must respect popular opinion ex pressed through the Congress, or it must commit suicide.

('23', 350, 1, 9, 838390) The Congress meets in session only once a year.
('23', 350, 1, 10, 838438) It lays down poli cies.
('23', 350, 1, 11, 838462) The All India Congress Committee is designed to carry out the Con gress policy as embodied in its resolutions.
('23', 350, 1, 12, 838573) It must interpret all resolu tions, and attend to all new matters, with the same authority as the Con gress.
('23', 350, 1, 13, 838682) The members may debate upon different propositions and inter pretations as much as they choose, but except on matters of vital prin ciple, the dissenters must conform to, and faithfully carry out, the reso lutions of the majority.
('23', 350, 1, 14, 838913) The discussions in the Committee are not open for re discussion in public.
('23', 350, 1, 15, 838988) In order to make the All India Congress Com mittee an efficient body, the Con stitution has provided for a Working Committee of fifteen, which must meet often and must be able to deal with all the matters delegated to it by the All India Congress Committee.
('23', 350, 1, 16, 839246) It is designed to exercise all the functions of the All India Congress Committee when the latter is not sitting.
('23', 350, 1, 17, 839359) It must watch and guide public opinion, it must interpret it, it must keep all the subsidiary organizations in working order, it must attend to all India finance, it must distribute it, and whenever decision on matters of grave importance has to be taken, it must summon a meeting of the All India Congress Committee for direc tion.

('23', 351, 1, 3, 840419) Its decisions have largely to be unanimous.

('23', 351, 2, 16, 841872) 160. THE MESSAGE OF THE CHARKHA
('23', 351, 3, 17, 841904) The Indian Social Reformer has published a note from a corres pondent in praise of the spinning wheel.
('23', 351, 3, 18, 842007) The correspondent in the course of his remarks hopes that the movement will be so organized that the spinners may not weary of it.
('23', 351, 3, 19, 842138) Mr. Amritlal Thakkar, in his valuable note (published in the Servant of India) on the experiment which he is conducting in Kathiawad, says that the charkha has been taken up by the peasant women.
('23', 351, 3, 20, 842334) They are not likely to weary, for to them it is a source of livelihood to which they were used before.
('23', 351, 3, 21, 842437) It had dried up because there was no demand for their yarn.
('23', 351, 3, 22, 842497) Townspeople who have taken to spinning may weary if they have done so as a craze or a fashion.
('23', 351, 3, 23, 842592) Those only will be faithful who consider it their duty to devote their spare hours to doing what is today the most useful work for the country.The third class of spinners are the school going
('23', 352, 0, 1, 842784) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 353
('23', 352, 1, 2, 842826) children.
('23', 352, 1, 3, 842836) I expect the greatest results from the experiment of introducing the charkha in the national schools.
('23', 352, 1, 4, 842938) If it is conducted on scientifice lines by teachers who believe in the charkha as the most efficient means of making education available to the seven and a half lakhs of villages in India, there is not only no danger of weariness, but every prospect of the nation being able to solve the problem of financing mass education without any extra taxation and without having to fall back upon immoral sources of revenue.
('23', 352, 1, 5, 843354) The writer in the Indian Social Reformer suggests that an attempt should be made to produce finer counts on the spinning wheel.
('23', 352, 1, 6, 843482) I may assure him that the process has already begun, but it will be some time before we arrive at the finish of the Dacca muslin or even twenty counts.
('23', 352, 1, 7, 843634) Seeing that hand spinning was only revived last September, and India began to believe in it somewhat only in December, the progress it has made may be regarded as phenomenal.
('23', 352, 1, 8, 843809) The writer’s complaint that hand spun yarn is not being woven as fast as it is spun is partly true.
('23', 352, 1, 9, 843909) But the remedy is not so much to increase the number of looms as to persuade the existing weavers to use hand spun yarn.
('23', 352, 1, 10, 844030) Weaving is a much more complex process than spinning.
('23', 352, 1, 11, 844084) It is not, like spinning, only a supplementary industry, but a complete means of livelihood.
('23', 352, 1, 12, 844177) It therefore never died out.
('23', 352, 1, 13, 844206) There are enough weavers and enough looms in India to replace the whole of the foreign import of cloth.
('23', 352, 1, 14, 844310) It should be understood that our looms— thousands of them in Madras, Maharashtra and Bengal—are engaged in weaving the fine yarn imported from Japan and Manchester.
('23', 352, 1, 15, 844475) We must utilize these for weaving hand spun yarn.
('23', 352, 1, 16, 844525) And for that purpose, the nation has to revise its taste for the thin, tawdry and useless muslins.
('23', 352, 1, 17, 844624) I see no art in weaving muslins that do not cover but only expose the body.
('23', 352, 1, 18, 844700) Our ideas of art must undergo a change.
('23', 352, 1, 19, 844740) But even if the universal weaving of thin fabric be considered desirable in normal conditions, at the present moment whilst we are making a mighty effort to become free and self supporting, we must be content to wear the cloth that our hand spun yarn may yield.
('23', 352, 1, 20, 845002) We have therefore to ask the fashionable on the one hand to be satisfied with coarser garments; we must educate the spinners on the other hand to spin finer and more even yarn.
('23', 352, 1, 21, 845179) The writer pleads for a reduction in the prices charged by mill owners for their manufactures.
('23', 352, 1, 22, 845274) When lovers of swadeshi begin to consi der it their duty to wear khaddar, when the required number of spinning wheels are working and the weavers are weaving hand spun
('23', 353, 0, 1, 845442) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 353, 1, 2, 845484) yarn, the mill owners will be bound to reduce prices.
('23', 353, 1, 3, 845538) It seems almost hopeless merely to appeal to the patriotism of those whose chief aim is to increase their own profits.
('23', 353, 1, 4, 845657) Incongruities pointed out by the writer such as the wearing of khaddar on public occasions and at other times of the most fashionable English suits, and the smoking of most expensive cigars by wearers of khaddar must disappear in course of time, as the new fashion gains strength.
('23', 353, 1, 5, 845938) It is my claim that as soon as we have completed the boycott of foreign cloth, we shall have evolved so far that we shall necessarily give up the present absurdities and remodel national life in keeping with the ideal of simplicity and domesticity implanted in the bosom of the masses.
('23', 353, 1, 6, 846224) We will not then be dragged into an imperialism which is built upon exploitation of the weaker races of the earth, and the acceptance of a giddy materialistic civilization protected by naval and air forces that have made peaceful living almost impossible.
('23', 353, 1, 7, 846480) On the contrary, we shall then refine that imperialism into a commonwealth of nations which will combine, if they do, for the purpose of giving their best to the world and of protecting, not by brute force but by self suffering, the weaker nations or races of the earth.

('23', 357, 6, 14, 857078) 163. MY NOTES [Before June 30, 1921] 1
('23', 357, 7, 15, 857117) POT OR TUMBLER I am writing these notes on the day prior to the day of our test.
('23', 357, 7, 16, 857198) Whether the product will be a perfect, full sized pot or only a tumbler, the workers alone know, and God.
('23', 357, 7, 17, 857304) The result corresponds to the sin cerity behind the effort.
('23', 357, 7, 18, 857364) If those engaged in collection work are sincere enough, the result is bound to follow.
('23', 357, 7, 19, 857451) There is no doubt now about 10 lakhs being collected from Gujarat.
('23', 357, 7, 20, 857518) The expectation, rather, is that the actual collection will exceed this figure.
('23', 357, 7, 21, 857598) And why not?
('23', 357, 7, 22, 857611) We have plenty, relatively.
('23', 357, 7, 23, 857639) The mills in Gujarat can by themselves fulfil our expectation.
('23', 357, 7, 24, 857702) The enterprising business men engaged in trade outside Gujarat can give something.
('23', 357, 7, 25, 857785) The Princes can give if they but shed fear.
('23', 357, 7, 26, 857829) We have never, in the past, attempted such tasks as a people, never tested our strength.

('23', 365, 1, 15, 878390) The Parsis were able to compete with other communities in every department of life.
('23', 365, 1, 16, 878474) If they had done so much in this country in the past, why were they keeping themselves aloof from the movement now?
('23', 365, 1, 17, 878590) They were a rich community, possessing crores of rupees, and why had not they given any more money to the Fund?
('23', 365, 1, 18, 878702) Dadabhai had served India by leading the life of a political recluse for the purpose of making India free, not for Parsis alone, but for all com munities and races.
('23', 365, 1, 19, 878867) The speaker was going to speak to them as their friend because he was great admirer of theirs and was very intimate with them for a long time.
('23', 365, 2, 20, 879010) Continuing, the Mahatma said, if the Parsis wished it, they could easily accomp lish anything, because they were a small, compact community of eighty thousand, but that was not so with the Hindus and Muslims.
('23', 365, 2, 21, 879219) If they could remain independent even before the English came, he did not know why they could not be so when they got swaraj.
('23', 365, 2, 22, 879345) It was the first duty of Hindus and Muslims to protect the smaller communities in this land.
('23', 365, 2, 23, 879438) If the Hindus and Muslims were true to themselves, they would see that not a Parsi was starving before they took any morsel of food.
('23', 365, 2, 24, 879571) If Hindus or Muslims wished to do anything else, then they were working not for a dharmarajya.
('23', 365, 2, 25, 879666) He wanted to make India not Satanic, but he wanted to establish dharmarajya.

('23', 365, 2, 27, 879886) If they could do so, they could get swaraj this year, and they could also right the Khilafat wrong and also those of the Punjab.

('23', 365, 2, 29, 880189) Did Indians want to make slaves of Negroes, or make them prisoners, or make them work for ourselves and to keep them as beggars?

('23', 373, 2, 12, 898767) You should admire the mantra which Tilak Maharaj gave.

('23', 373, 2, 14, 898956) You should accomplish the task on which he had set his heart, for which he gave his life, for which he suffered privations.
('23', 373, 2, 15, 899080) There can be no better memorial to him than that.

('23', 375, 0, 1, 902756) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 375, 1, 2, 902798) 174. TO “VAISHNAVAS”
('23', 375, 2, 3, 902819) Many among you are my relations, many belong to the same community as I do and many of you are my friends from childhood days.
('23', 375, 2, 4, 902946) From all these I get letters.
('23', 375, 2, 5, 902976) In some of them the correspondents compli ment me on my views about Antyajas, in some others they gently remon strate with me, thinking that I am in error in holding these views, in some the correspondents treat me to harsh words in their anger and in some they actually hold out threats against me.
('23', 375, 2, 6, 903276) I regard all these things as a sign of their love for me.
('23', 375, 2, 7, 903334) There are many others, besides me, who hold the same views about Antyajas as I do and do not object to contact with them, but people are angry with me and the reason, as I understand it, is that they believe that, in all other respects, I follow the restraints of dharma to the utmost and am otherwise a good man.
('23', 375, 2, 8, 903648) They cannot reconcile themselves to what they believe to be my erroneous views about Antyajas.
('23', 375, 2, 9, 903743) They think that these views hold up our progress towards swaraj.
('23', 375, 2, 10, 903808) Some even believe that I have gone out of my way to invite trouble and have, in my obstinacy, endangered the ship of swaraj.
('23', 375, 2, 11, 903933) My own humble belief, against this, is that my concern for Antyajas is a credit to my devotion to the Vaishnava way of life, that it is an expression of pure compassion, and that it proves my scrupulous regard for the restraints of religious life.
('23', 375, 2, 12, 904181) Some Vaishnavas believe that I am destroying varnashrama.
('23', 375, 2, 13, 904239) On the contrary, I believe that I am trying to cleanse it of impurities and so reveal its true form.
('23', 375, 2, 14, 904340) I am certainly not advocating abolition of restrictions on eating and drinking in company with anyone and everyone or on intermarrying among communities.
('23', 375, 2, 15, 904494) I merely say that the idea that physi cal contact with some person is a sin is itself sinful.
('23', 375, 2, 16, 904588) The attempt to defend the practice of untouchability by citing the similar practice of avoiding contact with a woman during the period of menstruation does not convince me.
('23', 375, 2, 17, 904761) A chance contact with a woman during this time is not looked upon as a sin.
('23', 375, 2, 18, 904837) It is held to be violation of a rule of hygiene and so the person takes a bath to be clean again.
('23', 375, 2, 19, 904935) If anyone avoided contact with an Antyaj who had been engaged in sanitary work and had not bathed or otherwise cleansed himself after the work, or, in case he had contact with such an Antyaj, went and had a bath, I can understand the idea.
('23', 375, 2, 20, 905175) But my conscience
('23', 376, 0, 1, 905193) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 377
('23', 376, 1, 2, 905235) can never accept the idea that dharma requires us to keep away scrupulously from everyone born an Antyaj.
('23', 376, 1, 3, 905341) The inspiration of the Vaishnava way is compassion.
('23', 376, 1, 4, 905393) I do not see a trace of this in our treatment of the Antyajas.
('23', 376, 1, 5, 905456) Many among us never address an Antyaj except with a word of contempt.
('23', 376, 1, 6, 905526) If an Antyaj is ever found sitting in the same compartment with other Hindus, there will be a rain of abuse on him.
('23', 376, 1, 7, 905642) We offer them food left over on our plates, as we do to cattle.
('23', 376, 1, 8, 905706) If an Antyaj has fever or is bitten by a serpent, our vaids and doctors will refuse to go to his place and treat him.
('23', 376, 1, 9, 905824) If anyone should get ready to go, we would do everything in our power to stop him.
('23', 376, 1, 10, 905907) For their residence, the Antyajas get the worst localities, with no amenities like light and public streets.
('23', 376, 1, 11, 906016) They are provided with no wells for their use.
('23', 376, 1, 12, 906063) They cannot use public wells and dharmsalas and cannot attend schools.
('23', 376, 1, 13, 906134) We expect from them the most difficult of services and pay them the least.
('23', 376, 1, 14, 906209) The sky above and the earth below is all that they have by way of shelter.
('23', 376, 1, 15, 906284) Is such treatment in keeping with the Vaishnava way of life?
('23', 376, 1, 16, 906345) Is it the way inspired by compassion, is it not rather the way of cruelty?
('23', 376, 1, 17, 906420) The British Government, against which you have launched non co operation, does not treat us with such contempt.
('23', 376, 1, 18, 906532) We actually cherish our Dyerism towards Antyajas as dharma.
('23', 376, 1, 19, 906592) Speaking for myself, I believe that we are reaping as we sowed.
('23', 376, 1, 20, 906656) Treating the Antyajas with contempt, we have become objects of the entire world’s contempt.
('23', 376, 1, 21, 906748) The idea of untouchability is unacceptable to reason.
('23', 376, 1, 22, 906802) It is contrary to truth and non violence and, therefore, is certainly not dharma.
('23', 376, 1, 23, 906884) The very idea of our being high and others low is base.
('23', 376, 1, 24, 906940) He is no true Brahmin who lacks the quality of the Sudra : readiness for service.
('23', 376, 1, 25, 907022) He alone is a Brahmin who possesses the qualities of all others, the Kshatriya, the Vaisya and the Sudra and, in addition, has knowledge.
('23', 376, 1, 26, 907160) A Sudra is not altogether devoid of knowledge.
('23', 376, 1, 27, 907207) Readiness for service is predominant in him over his other qualities.
('23', 376, 1, 28, 907277) The varnashrama dharma has no room for distinctions of high and low.
('23', 376, 1, 29, 907346) The Vaishnava tradition knows of Bhangis and Chandals who attained deliverance.
('23', 376, 1, 30, 907426) How can a dharma which holds that the entire universe is permeated by Vishnu believe that He is not present in the Antyaj?
('23', 376, 1, 31, 907549) I have no desire, however, to interpret the Shastras to you.
('23', 376, 1, 32, 907610) I do not claim to be a man of learning.
('23', 376, 1, 33, 907650) Every shastri is welcome to have
('23', 377, 0, 1, 907683) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 377, 1, 2, 907725) the better of me in interpreting the Shastras.
('23', 377, 1, 3, 907772) I know with confidence that I have had some experience of what the way of compassion means.
('23', 377, 1, 4, 907864) This way can have simply no room in it for an attitude of contempt for Antyajas.
('23', 377, 1, 5, 907945) Moreover, what people will you describe as Antyajas?
('23', 377, 1, 6, 907998) Is a weaver an Antyaj?
('23', 377, 1, 7, 908021) Are wealthy dealers in leather Antyajas?
('23', 377, 1, 8, 908062) Or is it that gold cleanses everything?
('23', 377, 1, 9, 908102) A chamar who has given up his traditional work, a Bhangi who has taken to driving a car or works in a mill, who takes a bath every day and keeps himself clean, is even such a person an untou chable?
('23', 377, 1, 10, 908301) Why argue, however?
('23', 377, 1, 11, 908321) So long as you believe that physical contact with anyone whom you regard as an untouchable is a sin, you may, if you wish, take a bath after such contact, but my request to you is that just as you do not hold in disregard a mother who is in her period of menstruation, but serve her instead, so should you serve Antyajas instead of despising them.
('23', 377, 1, 12, 908669) Dig wells for them, build schools for them, arrange for vaids to visit them, make their suffering your own and so earn their heartfelt blessings.
('23', 377, 1, 13, 908815) See to it that they have their homes in good areas.
('23', 377, 1, 14, 908867) Pay them well, respect them, educate them, look upon them as your younger brothers and persuade them to give up drinking, beef eating, etc.
('23', 377, 1, 15, 909007) Reward those who do these things.
('23', 377, 1, 16, 909041) If you act in this way, you will come to see that the idea of untouchability is [as the poet says] a superfluous limb.
('23', 377, 1, 17, 909160) Some of you have refused to contribute to the Tilak Swaraj Fund simply because of my views regarding Antyajas.
('23', 377, 1, 18, 909271) This is my appeal to you, however: contribute money for the reform of untouchables; you can cert ainly do so, even if you do not abandon the practice of untoucha bility.
('23', 377, 1, 19, 909441) Actually, some Vaishnavas have earmarked their contributions for this purpose.
('23', 377, 1, 20, 909520) Moreover, though you may not like my views about Antyajas, you can surely give some money for the swadeshi movement, for famine relief and for schools.
('23', 377, 1, 21, 909672) I believe, though, that you would certainly not oppose improvement in the conditions of Antyajas, and, therefore, appeal to you that, as evidence of such regard for the principle of compassion, you earmark your contributions for activities intended for their uplift.

('23', 378, 0, 1, 909975) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 379
('23', 378, 1, 2, 910017) 175. HOW TO BOYCOTT FOREIGN GOODS 1
('23', 378, 2, 3, 910053) It is needless to say at this time of day that the proposed boycott of foreign cloth is not a vindictive process, but is as necessary for national existence as breath is to life.
('23', 378, 2, 4, 910232) The quicker therefore it can be brought about the better for the country.
('23', 378, 2, 5, 910306) Without it swaraj cannot be established or retained after establishment.
('23', 378, 2, 6, 910379) It is of the highest importance to know how it can be brought about even before the first day of August next.
('23', 378, 2, 7, 910489) To arrive at the boycott quickly it is necessary (1) for the mill owners to regularize their profits and to manufacture principally for the Indian market, (2) for importers to cease to buy foreign goods—a beginning has already been made by three principal merchants, (3) for the consumers to refuse to buy any foreign cloth and to buy khadi wherever possible, (4) for the consumers to wear only khadi cloth, mill cloth being retained for the poor who do not know the distinction between swadeshi and pardeshi 2, (5) for the consumers to use, till swaraj is established and khadi manufacture increased, khadi just enough for covering the body, (6) for the consumers to destroy pardeshi cloth as they would destroy intoxi cating liquors on taking the vow of abstinence or to sell it for use abroad or to wear it out for all dirty work or during private hours.
('23', 378, 2, 8, 911347) It is to be hoped that all the parties referred to in the foregoing clauses will respond well and simultaneously.
('23', 378, 2, 9, 911461) But, in the end, success depends upon the persistent determination of the consumer.
('23', 378, 2, 10, 911545) He has simply to decline to wear the badge of his slavery.
('23', 378, 3, 11, 911604) The Bombay Chronicle, 4 7 1921

('23', 379, 16, 27, 913076) Will they prove worthy of the trust?
