('23', 379, 17, 30, 913218) 1 This is not available.
('23', 380, 0, 1, 913243) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 381
('23', 380, 1, 2, 913285) replied that the officers of the Provincial Congress Committees are responsible and tried men.
('23', 380, 1, 3, 913380) If we do not account properly for every pie we receive and do not make a judicious use of the funds, we shall deserve to be blotted out of public life.
('23', 380, 1, 4, 913532) Let us remember that the poorest people have given of their best.
('23', 380, 1, 5, 913598) Many have given their all.
('23', 380, 1, 6, 913625) Washermen, carpenters, blacksmiths, Christians, Jews, Parsis, Sikhs, Jains, Mussulmans and Hindus have paid their mite.
('23', 380, 1, 7, 913745) On the 16th of June, when the collection commenced in Bombay, the whole amount collected throughout India stood at thirty lakhs, if even at that.
('23', 380, 1, 8, 913891) I had full faith that forty lakhs would be collected by the end of June by provinces other than Bombay.
('23', 380, 1, 9, 913995) All India, therefore, subscribed at the rate of more than five lakhs per day during the fourteen days of concentrated effort.
('23', 380, 1, 10, 914121) The provinces outside Bombay had subscribed up to the 30th June during the same period as Bombay, thirty eight lakhs—not a bad record.
('23', 380, 1, 11, 914256) How shall we retain this confidence?
('23', 380, 1, 12, 914293) We must keep accurate accounts, which even a child can see and understand.
('23', 380, 1, 13, 914368) The funds ought not to be used outside the purpose of non co operation, nor generally for any purpose outside (1) the spread of the charkha and khadi, (2) the removal of untouchability, and hence, the elevation of the suppressed classes, (3) the conduct of national schools, where spinning and weaving are a part of the training and (4) the advance of the liquor prohibition campaign.
('23', 380, 1, 14, 914753) These objects necessarily include the upkeep of the national service.
('23', 380, 1, 15, 914823) It will be through the instrumentality of that service that we shall be able to achieve the objects above named.
('23', 380, 1, 16, 914936) And to achieve the objects above named is to demonstrate our fitness and ability for attaining swaraj.
('23', 380, 1, 17, 915039) I would warn the different Committees against living on the interest of the funds.
('23', 380, 1, 18, 915122) To invest the money at interest and to use only the interest is to betray want of faith in the nation and in ourselves.
('23', 380, 1, 19, 915242) The nation’s trust must be our capital, and its response from time to time must constitute our interest.
('23', 380, 1, 20, 915347) If we claim to represent the nation, we must rely upon it to finance yearly institutions established and conducted for it.
('23', 380, 1, 21, 915470) Living on interest tends to make us irresponsible.
('23', 380, 1, 22, 915521) The hoards rotting in the name of religion in the various parts of India have made many of these religious institutions a sham, where they have not become hotbeds of corruption.
('23', 380, 1, 23, 915699) If, therefore, we would profit by our past experience, we would spend almost the whole amount collected by us during the remaining six months.
('23', 380, 1, 24, 915842) When I placed the financial programme before the All India Congress Committee in Bezwada, I did so because I knew that we had honest and able men enough to deal with national and provincial finance, and because we needed that amount for use during the year.
('23', 380, 1, 25, 916100) We cannot
('23', 381, 0, 1, 916110) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('23', 381, 2, 9, 917023) BOMBAY’S DECISION The Bombay Provincial Congress Committee has come to a decision on the question of the management of the big collection made by it in a most business like and becoming manner.
('23', 381, 2, 10, 917217) I quote from memory the effective part of its resolution :
('23', 381, 3, 11, 917276) Whereas the All India Tilak Memorial Fund collections made during the month of June were made not to meet provincial needs merely but in order to fulfil the obligation incurred at Bezwada and in order to meet the requirements of provinces in need of help, in the opinion of the Committee it is desirable to entrust a special Committee with the control and management of the collections.
('23', 381, 3, 12, 917663) Messrs Raghavji Purushottam, Velji Lakhamsi Napu, Revashankar Jagjivan Jhaveri, Umar Sobani, Jamnalal Bajaj, Ardeshar Barjorji Godrej, Shankarlal Banker and Lakshmidas Tairsi be appointed a Committee to control and manage the said funds, subject to the following conditions : (1) The non co operation expenses of the Provincial Congress Committee to be a first charge on the Fund.
('23', 381, 4, 13, 918044) (2) The other provinces to be helped on the advice of the All India Congress Committee in respect of the spread of the charkha and khadi, elevation of suppressed classes, national schools, famine relief and prohibition of liquor.
('23', 381, 4, 14, 918274) It is an act of self denial, for which the Bombay Committee deserves the warm congratulations of the country.
('23', 381, 4, 15, 918384) The one intention running through the resolution is to put the administration of the large funds beyond suspicion and on a sound footing.
('23', 381, 4, 16, 918522) RESIGNING FOR A MUSLIM BROTHER Another instance of self effacement is also furnished by Bombay.
('23', 381, 4, 17, 918618) The advice of the Working Committee regarding Muslim representation was given after the voting papers had been issued.
('23', 382, 0, 1, 918737) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 383
('23', 382, 1, 2, 918779) election results showed that only one Mussulman was elected, and that was Mr. Umar Sobani who could hardly be claimed specially to represent the Mussul man interest.
('23', 382, 1, 3, 918945) He is too well known as a public worker to be classed purely as a Mussulman representative.
('23', 382, 1, 4, 919037) Moreover, in Bombay it was necessary to have at least two Muslim members elected to the All India Congress Committee.
('23', 382, 1, 5, 919155) Mr. Vithaldas Jerajani has therefore vacated his seat for a Mussulman representative.
('23', 382, 1, 6, 919241) It is instances of such brotherly and public spirit make me feel that swaraj is hastening to us.
('23', 382, 1, 7, 919338) The only danger is that of our running away from it.

('23', 390, 3, 6, 937765) I have not, in either instance, put a wrong construction or shown myself prone to do so.

('23', 390, 3, 13, 938698) A person who is free from attachment finds time to reflect and puts a construction which will save the other party; if he is a truthful man, he will, as I have pointed out, correctly guess the correspondent’s meaning.

('23', 392, 5, 5, 942397) 183. OPEN LETTER TO CLOTH MERCHANTS
('23', 392, 6, 6, 942433) July 7, 1921
('23', 392, 7, 7, 942446) GENTLEMEN, Yesterday I invited the mill owners to help the foreign cloth boycott movement.
('23', 392, 7, 8, 942537) They may or may not help.
('23', 392, 7, 9, 942563) I shall hope that they will.
('23', 392, 7, 10, 942592) But you cannot possibly keep yourselves from it, because the majority of you are even convinced non co operators.
('23', 392, 7, 11, 942706) You have made possible the fulfilment of the Bezwada promise regarding the Tilak Memorial Swaraj Fund.
('23', 392, 7, 12, 942809) But you will say that whilst payment was a small matter to you, your trade is a matter of life and death.
('23', 392, 7, 13, 942915) It is just this hallu cination that is keeping swaraj away from us.
('23', 392, 7, 14, 942983) If your trade is a matter of life and death to you, is the country’s good less so?
('23', 392, 7, 15, 943066) Swaraj means that you and I put our country’s trade before ours.
('23', 392, 7, 16, 943131) The appeal to you to refrain from importing foreign cloth is in other words an appeal to subor dinate your individual gain to the country’s.
('23', 392, 7, 17, 943272) For every yard you import from England or Japan or America, you take away from the mouth of a fellow countryman at least three annas without giving him anything in return.
('23', 392, 7, 18, 943444) Let me explain.
('23', 392, 7, 19, 943460) India has enough labour lying idle in her villages.
('23', 392, 7, 20, 943512) Formerly this was utilized for manu facturing yarn and cloth.
('23', 392, 7, 21, 943574) Foreign imports made them compulsorily idle.
('23', 392, 7, 22, 943619) And for these long years the vast majority have found no other occu pation.
('23', 392, 7, 23, 943695) Hence, every drought sends a shiver through every pitying heart in India.
('23', 392, 7, 24, 943769) It need not be so.
('23', 392, 7, 25, 943788) A drought is not an unusual Indian pheno menon.
('23', 392, 7, 26, 943836) We feel its deadly effects, because we are living on the margin of starvation.
('23', 392, 7, 27, 943915) By prolonged idleness we have lost the power of sustenance.
('23', 392, 7, 28, 943975) Do not imagine that these cottagers can all flock to our dozen cities where labour is scarce and find a living.
('23', 392, 7, 29, 944087) They are burdened with land which they dare not leave even if they would.
('23', 392, 7, 30, 944161) And not all the cities of India can hold her millions.
('23', 392, 7, 31, 944216) Nothing but the restoration of hand spinning and hand weaving can possibly bring back lustre to the Indian eye.
('23', 392, 8, 32, 944328) 1 A reference to the Bhagavad Gita, ii, 38
('23', 393, 0, 1, 944371) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 393, 1, 2, 944413) would be false to you and to India if I do not tell you that the merchants more than the mill owners are responsible for India’s deep and distressing poverty.
('23', 393, 1, 3, 944572) The mill owners aggravate it, no doubt, when they charge heavy prices.
('23', 393, 1, 4, 944643) But you are so responsible that, if you stop the importation of foreign cloth, you can revive the ancient and honourable dharma (duty) of hand spinning and give an impetus to the industry of hand weaving.
('23', 393, 1, 5, 944848) Why, after all, should the abandonment of a trade that harms India be a matter of life and death to many of you?
('23', 393, 1, 6, 944961) Surely you are resourceful enough to find some other trade beneficial alike to you and the country.
('23', 393, 1, 7, 945061) The stopping of imports means a saving of sixty crores per year.
('23', 393, 1, 8, 945126) But it means operation on a much larger capital.
('23', 393, 1, 9, 945175) It means that all the processes on cotton will be gone throught in India.
('23', 393, 1, 10, 945249) That means business for you.
('23', 393, 1, 11, 945278) It means a healthy circulation of money as today it is a progressively exhausting drain of money from our dear country.
('23', 393, 1, 12, 945398) I ask you to disengage your great talents from an unhealthy channel and direct them into the healthy channels that open out to you.
('23', 393, 1, 13, 945530) You must organize hand spinning and hand weaving.
('23', 393, 1, 14, 945580) Then, you will not be satisfied with coarse khadi as I am.
('23', 393, 1, 15, 945639) You will insist on your spinners spinning the finest counts and weavers weaving the world famed Dacca muslin.
('23', 393, 1, 16, 945749) You will sink fortunes in it whereas I have only paid our sisters the few thousands you have given me as a charity.
('23', 393, 1, 17, 945865) For you to leave the unholy trade in foreign cloth is to organize the production and distribution of home spun.
('23', 393, 1, 18, 945977) It is an enterprise worthy of your patriotism.
('23', 393, 1, 19, 946024) You whisper to me that such organization may take a few years.
('23', 393, 1, 20, 946087) You have not built up your present trade in a moment.
('23', 393, 1, 21, 946141) If you are satisfied that it is a trade that has impoverished and enslaved India, you will not stop to think of the consequences of its destruction.
('23', 393, 1, 22, 946290) You will let it go at any cost.
('23', 393, 1, 23, 946322) And what is the cost?
('23', 393, 1, 24, 946344) Not much.
('23', 393, 1, 25, 946354) You have to stop all further orders for foreign cloth or yarn.
('23', 393, 1, 26, 946417) That costs nothing.
('23', 393, 1, 27, 946437) You have a stock of foreign cloth to get rid of.
('23', 393, 1, 28, 946486) The world’s market is open to you for its disposal.
('23', 393, 1, 29, 946538) There are many uses to which the Indian specialities can be put in, say, Mauritius, South Africa or East Africa.
('23', 393, 1, 30, 946651) You will but let me think out for you the best method of disposing of the stock of foreign cloth and yarn you have.
('23', 393, 1, 31, 946767) Some of you have developed an anxiety for the requirements of the consumer.
('23', 393, 1, 32, 946843) He will accommodate himself to the shortage,feel none the worse for it and will be better able to appreciate next year the plenty of beautiful khadi of every variety of width and thinness.
('23', 394, 0, 1, 947032) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 395
('23', 394, 1, 2, 947074) I ask you not to put an undue strain upon the consumer.
('23', 394, 1, 3, 947130) It is not right for you to put temptations in his or her way in the shape of flimsy Japanese dhotis or saris or starchy calico.
('23', 394, 1, 4, 947258) I urge you rather to cultivate in the consumer the taste to see art in khadi.
('23', 394, 1, 5, 947336) Evenness, even softness, is not necessarily an art.
('23', 394, 1, 6, 947388) The most exquisitely made rose flower from silks has no art in it.
('23', 394, 1, 7, 947455) For it has no life.
('23', 394, 1, 8, 947475) But the real flower from the garden with most petals gone is any day infinitely superior to the finished artificial product in a dressed window.
('23', 394, 1, 9, 947620) The former is instinct with life.
('23', 394, 1, 10, 947654) Would that the merchants of India, ceasing to be mercenary, will study the ancient art and make it their business to revive it.
('23', 394, 1, 11, 947782) There is money in it for you and the country.
('23', 394, 1, 12, 947828) The greatest art to be revived is swaraj.
('23', 394, 1, 13, 947870) There is no swaraj without swadeshi.
('23', 394, 1, 14, 947907) And swadeshi means for India a permanent boycott of foreign cloth.
('23', 394, 1, 15, 947974) I invite you to lead the way.
('23', 394, 1, 16, 948004) For you have the ability.
('23', 394, 1, 17, 948030) May God grant you the strength and wisdom to lead!
('23', 394, 3, 18, 948081) Gentlemen,
('23', 394, 4, 19, 948092) Your faithful friend,

('23', 396, 13, 19, 951013) 189. AUSPICIOUS HOUR
('23', 396, 14, 20, 951034) As the man who wishes to climb to the top of the Girnar 3 has not succeeded in his aim when he has reached as far as the track leading up, so we shall not reach our goal of swaraj if we pause and rest on any step in the ladder taking us up.
('23', 396, 14, 21, 951275) We shall have to keep climbing
('23', 396, 15, 22, 951306) 1 This telegram was sent after Gandhiji had received the following telegram from C. Vijayaraghavachariar from Kodaikanal on July 8 : “Willingly but fix date after Sunday 24th permit warmest grateful congratulations on phenomenal success swarajya fund wire date.” 2 For the incident referred to, vide “My Notes”, 17 7 1921.
('23', 396, 16, 23, 951629) 3 Mountain in Saurashtra
('23', 397, 0, 1, 951654) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 397, 1, 2, 951696) without pausing for rest.
('23', 397, 1, 3, 951722) It is certainly a matter for satisfaction that we have succeeded in collecting the money.
('23', 397, 1, 4, 951812) That has given us some confidence.
('23', 397, 1, 5, 951847) We have had some evidence of how many are with us and who they are, and have now the resources to spend on the tasks which need our attention.
('23', 397, 1, 6, 951990) The only programme, however, which will give us a distant vision of swaraj is swadeshi.
('23', 397, 1, 7, 952078) Spending thousands of rupees will not enable us to enter the temple of swaraj.
('23', 397, 1, 8, 952157) Swadeshi is the one condition we must fulfil for being able to do so.
('23', 397, 1, 9, 952227) The watchman at the templegate will not ask us how much money we have; he will look at us to see whether we are dressed in khadi and examine us to know whether we smell of liquor.
('23', 397, 1, 10, 952407) The man who follows the rule of swadeshi will himself feel that he is a free man.
('23', 397, 1, 11, 952489) Anyone who does not feel so will not be free simply by reason of another person declaring him to be so.
('23', 397, 1, 12, 952593) Every person should have the feeling of freedom in himself, and this will never come to one who has not renounced the use of foreign cloth.
('23', 397, 1, 13, 952733) Japanese saris, French satin and Manchester muslins are but so many forms of addiction.
('23', 397, 1, 14, 952821) A person in the grip of these addictions will never think of freedom, since by his dress he has become a foreigner who looks upon everything foreign as good, how can we expect such a man to have the spirit of swadeshi in him?
('23', 397, 1, 15, 953047) What does such a one know of self rule?
('23', 397, 1, 16, 953087) In what sense can a person who does not like India’s climate, Indian ways of dressing and Indian dishes look upon the country as his?
('23', 397, 1, 17, 953221) The crores of us have not yet come to dislike India’s climate and are happy enough with its wheat and millet roti, made with hand, but the cloth it offers fails to please us!
('23', 397, 1, 18, 953396) Foreign cloth has cast a spell over us.
('23', 397, 1, 19, 953436) Till we are free from that spell the country will remain enslaved, let there be no doubt about it.
('23', 397, 1, 20, 953535) Foreign cloth, even if anyone offered it free to us, can be of no benefit to us, in fact it will only harm us; for a man living on gifts becomes a beggar and a beggar is always a slave; he has sold his soul.
('23', 397, 1, 21, 953743) To be able to enter the temple of swaraj, what we need is swadeshi.
('23', 397, 1, 22, 953811) Swadeshi means boycott of foreign cloth.
('23', 397, 1, 23, 953852) The country has recognized the power of the spinning wheel.
('23', 397, 1, 24, 953912) There is not a single province which is a stranger to it.
('23', 397, 1, 25, 953970) Khadi is being woven in every province on some scale.
('23', 397, 1, 26, 954024) People have mastered this art.
('23', 397, 1, 27, 954055) However, the spell which foreign cloth has cast over us must break.
('23', 397, 1, 28, 954123) Until it has broken, the use of the spinning wheel will not be assured.
('23', 397, 1, 29, 954195) So long as the country has not recognized the magic power of the spinning wheel, it will have no strength in its arms and will
('23', 398, 0, 1, 954322) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 399
('23', 398, 1, 2, 954364) acquire no confidence in itself.
('23', 398, 1, 3, 954397) The auspicious hour when we should start such boycott has arrived.
('23', 398, 1, 4, 954464) I shall be put to shame if by October 1 we have not won swaraj and my faith in India will be proved to have been misplaced.
('23', 398, 1, 5, 954588) If we do not get it by December, India will have failed in her pledge, she will have lost face in the eyes of the world and the delegates who attended [the Congress] at Nagpur will be proved to have been no worthy delegates.
('23', 398, 1, 6, 954813) We cannot get swaraj unless we boycott foreign cloth.
('23', 398, 1, 7, 954867) Through such boycott we clean our bodies and, till we have cleaned ourselves so, we are not fit to chant the swaraj mantra.
('23', 398, 1, 8, 954991) If, therefore, we wish to enter the temple of swaraj this year, there should be no more delay in completing boycott [of foreign cloth], since, by adopting swadeshi, we shall come into possession of an unrivalled source of strength.
('23', 398, 1, 9, 955223) If those who have usurped the temple fail to understand our strength even then and refuse to give up possession, we shall have no choice but to give them a fight.
('23', 398, 1, 10, 955386) Some time is bound to elapse in this.
('23', 398, 1, 11, 955424) I am confident, however, that we shall not need to fight if we carry out complete boycott of foreign cloth, that we shall get possession of what is ours.
('23', 398, 1, 12, 955578) Nonetheless, we should allow for some time for the struggle.
('23', 398, 1, 13, 955639) If, therefore, we want to have swaraj in October, we should complete the boycott by August 31. We shall know on August 1 whether we shall succeed in doing so.
('23', 398, 1, 14, 955798) The death anniversary of Tilak Maharaj falls on that day.
('23', 398, 1, 15, 955856) We may celebrate the day with zest if we have completed our task by that time but, if we have failed to do our duty, we should in our shame stay indoors.
('23', 398, 1, 16, 956010) As it was during the last days of June that we worked best, so we can strive hard during the remaining days of this month and complete the boycott of foreign cloth.
('23', 398, 1, 17, 956175) Everyone who describes himself as a non co operator must wear khadi and nothing else, and should make do with the fewest clothes.
('23', 398, 1, 18, 956305) This is a period of transition, a difficult period.
('23', 398, 1, 19, 956357) Seeing that immediate boycott is bound to reduce our stock of cloth and result in shortage of cloth in the country, we should carry on with fewer clothes.
('23', 398, 1, 20, 956512) Moreover, everyone may not be in a position to buy new clothes and so we have no choice but to make do with fewer clothes.
('23', 398, 1, 21, 956635) We may either make a bonfire of foreign cloth in stock with us, or give it away to be sent to other countries or wear such garments when visiting the lavatory.
('23', 398, 1, 22, 956795) Should we be poor, we may use such cloth but, seeing that it is a symbol of our slavery, only it we can afford no other course.
('23', 399, 0, 1, 956923) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 399, 1, 2, 956965) To make things easy for the poor, we should maintain depots for receiving foreign cloth in exchange for khadi.
('23', 399, 1, 3, 957076) We should in this way think out a number of plans and, in so far, at any rate, as our own dress is concerned, we should totally discard the use of foreign cloth before August 1. All of us should resolve to buy no more foreign cloth and to spin a fixed quantity of yarn daily in our homes.
('23', 399, 1, 4, 957365) This will not be enough, however.
('23', 399, 1, 5, 957399) We should visit every cloth shop.
('23', 399, 1, 6, 957433) We should entreat dealers in foreign cloth to stop importing such cloth and try to see that they dispose of their existing stocks by sending them to other countries.
('23', 399, 1, 7, 957599) As the consumers and the merchants have their duties, so have the mill owners theirs.
('23', 399, 1, 8, 957685) We should appeal to them not to put up the prices of cloth in consequence of the boycott.
('23', 399, 1, 9, 957775) Even as it is, they charge such high prices that there is room for some reduction.
('23', 399, 1, 10, 957858) If, now, they seek to exploit the people’s need and put up the prices, they will themselves be acting as foreigners and as enemies of the country.
('23', 399, 1, 11, 958005) I think they will not go to that length.
('23', 399, 1, 12, 958046) We look upon this movement for swaraj as one of self purification.
('23', 399, 1, 13, 958113) We are being tested more and more as we climb higher.
('23', 399, 1, 14, 958167) If everyone of us has the spirit of patriotism and desires to keep it undefiled as he would his own home, I believe it would be the easiest thing to win swaraj during this year.
('23', 399, 1, 15, 958345) As the country demonstrated one miracle on June 30, we have full reason to hope that it will perform the other miracle of boycott too.
('23', 399, 1, 16, 958480) May God preserve our honour!
('23', 399, 1, 17, 958509) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 10 7 1921
('23', 399, 2, 18, 958546) 190. FIVE GREAT “YAJNAS”
('23', 399, 3, 19, 958571) There can be many ways of interpreting yajna.
('23', 399, 3, 20, 958617) For the Hindu householder, five yajnas are considered essential : the oven, the pestle, the quern, the pitcher and the spinning wheel.
('23', 399, 3, 21, 958752) The fewer there are of these the less substantial the household.
('23', 399, 3, 22, 958817) A glance at them, however, will show that the important sacrifices are the first and the last and the middle three are their offshoots.
('23', 399, 3, 23, 958953) The quern, the pitcher and the pestle presuppose the oven.
('23', 399, 3, 24, 959012) The oven would not work at its best in the absence of the quern or the pestle in a home, but still it can pull on.
('23', 399, 3, 25, 959127) But stop the spinning wheel and you are without a principal organ.
('23', 399, 3, 26, 959194) You have paralysis.
('23', 399, 3, 27, 959214) A man who does no yajna for his food and clothing has no right to either.
('23', 399, 3, 28, 959288) There should be a custom that he who
('23', 400, 0, 1, 959325) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 401
('23', 400, 1, 2, 959367) does not work at his stove must go without food, and he who does not ply his spinning wheel must go naked.
('23', 400, 1, 3, 959474) We have discarded the spinning wheel without discarding clothes.
('23', 400, 1, 4, 959539) He is a thief who wears clothes without doing any spinning, in the same way that he who consumes food without working for it is a thief.
('23', 400, 1, 5, 959676) Yajna means an offering, a sacrifice of the self, which is what physical labour is.
('23', 400, 1, 6, 959760) They who work at the oven and the wheel are engaged in an intelligent sacrifice.
('23', 400, 1, 7, 959841) Even those who are not engaged in such beneficial physical effort have to take some exercise to digest their food.
('23', 400, 1, 8, 959956) It will perhaps be clear now what a sin we have committed in giving up the spinning wheel.
('23', 400, 1, 9, 960047) India was a happy country, healthy and bright, when in the past millions of its women used to engage themselves in this light but beneficial labour.
('23', 400, 1, 10, 960196) Today, by giving it up, the country has become miserable, diseased and listless.
('23', 400, 1, 11, 960277) The oven, the spinning wheel, etc., are each of them a veritable grace of the home.
('23', 400, 1, 12, 960361) If millions of Indian homes are in ruins today, it is because we gave up the spinning wheel.
('23', 400, 1, 13, 960454) Let no one suppose that this is an exaggeration.
('23', 400, 1, 14, 960503) It is possible the reader’s own home is not in that condition.
('23', 400, 1, 15, 960566) But then a shortage of water does not mean that no one can get any water.
('23', 400, 1, 16, 960640) It means everyone has less than before, many have very little, while some have none at all.
('23', 400, 1, 17, 960732) Similarly, many families may be able to carry on without the spinning wheel, but some at least have been completely ruined.
('23', 400, 1, 18, 960856) Look at Orissa and Champaran.
('23', 400, 1, 19, 960886) A number of villages there are ruined.
('23', 400, 1, 20, 960925) What else would happen to a country whose people, 150 years ago, had some work or other all the year round, but 80 per cent of whom today are unemployed for four months in the year?
('23', 400, 1, 21, 961107) Work alone is real wealth, metal is a mere token for it.
('23', 400, 1, 22, 961164) When 80 per cent of a people are unemployed for four months, their earning capacity is reduced by one third.
('23', 400, 1, 23, 961273) Despite the capacity and willingness to earn Rs. 3, Indians have for years been working to earn no more than Rs. 2. They cannot find work for more than that.
('23', 400, 1, 24, 961431) How could such a country help being poor?
('23', 400, 1, 25, 961473) The only remedy for such a state of affairs is a vow to wear khadi made from yarn spun with our own hands.
('23', 400, 1, 26, 961580) Then we shall take to the spinning wheel, willy nilly, and realize finally that we had made a mistake in giving it up.
('23', 400, 1, 27, 961699) But, in the meantime we ought to undrtake a determined effort to popularize it.
('23', 400, 1, 28, 961779) We shall never be eager to introduce the spinning wheel, nor, after introducing it, shall we be keen to ply it, so long as we continue to be as fond of foreign cloth as we are.
('23', 400, 1, 29, 961956) A vow to discard foreign cloth will compel us to use the spinning wheel.
('23', 400, 1, 30, 962029) Thus the spinning wheel and boycott of foreign cloth are closely inter related.
('23', 400, 1, 31, 962109) We hardly care for a
('23', 401, 0, 1, 962130) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 401, 1, 2, 962172) thing that is not a necessity.
('23', 401, 1, 3, 962203) It is, therefore, our sacred duty to see that the spinning wheel becomes a necessity.
('23', 401, 1, 4, 962289) There is no other way of eradicating India’s poverty.
('23', 401, 1, 5, 962343) For the mistake of giving up so invaluable a thing, there can be no adequate atonement.
('23', 401, 1, 6, 962431) A small sacrifice may be enough if we make it on our own.
('23', 401, 1, 7, 962489) If we are to do things under compulsion, who can say what they will be?

('23', 403, 2, 3, 965498) July 10, 1921
('23', 403, 3, 4, 965512) I have been drawn here by the hope that many of you will take the pledge of boycotting foreign cloth.
('23', 403, 3, 5, 965614) I have given reasons why this should be done.
('23', 403, 3, 6, 965660) Whether or not millowners or foreign cloth dealers help us, the people of India can boycott foreign cloth if they so decide.
('23', 403, 3, 7, 965785) Boycotting foreign cloth means that the country should stop using cloth imported from foreign countries.
('23', 403, 3, 8, 965890) Your merely taking a pledge not to use foreign cloth hereafter will not satisfy me.
('23', 403, 3, 9, 965974) We ought not to use even the foreign cloth which is already with us.
('23', 403, 3, 10, 966043) I have considered three courses of which we may adopt any one for this purpose.
('23', 403, 3, 11, 966123) The best thing is to burn whatever foreign cloth we have.
('23', 403, 3, 12, 966181) Concerning this, many people ask me why we should not give this cloth to the large number of poor people in our country who wander about hungry and naked.
('23', 403, 3, 13, 966336) They say that burning the cloth will be an act of hatred.
('23', 403, 3, 14, 966394) My reply is that people’s hatred will be intensified only if I am actuated by hatred in asking them to burn foreign cloth.
('23', 403, 3, 15, 966517) If, however, we realize that we have committed a grave error in taking to the use of foreign cloth, then our deliverance from slavery lies in burning it.
('23', 403, 3, 16, 966671) The second course is to send such cloth to other countries.
('23', 403, 3, 17, 966731) In our own country, we cannot give it in charity even to the poorest of the poor or the most wretched.
('23', 403, 3, 18, 966834) I place liquor and foreign cloth in the same category.
('23', 403, 3, 19, 966889) I know that you find it difficult to cultivate dislike of foreign cloth.
('23', 403, 3, 20, 966962) I have been holding these views for a very long time and so I do not find the thing difficult, whereas you are called upon to change your ideas in a very short time.
('23', 403, 3, 21, 967128) If it is your view that foreign cloth should be disposed of only by sending it to other countries, you should send the entire stock to me.
('23', 403, 3, 22, 967267) It will be disposed of as desired by you.
('23', 403, 3, 23, 967309) If you believe that boycott of foreign cloth will not increase hatred but will strengthen our spirit, that it will strengthen India’s determination, then I should certainly like a bonfire to such cloth.
('23', 403, 3, 24, 967512) Arrangements are being made to give khadi in exchange for foreign cloth to those who are too poor to buy swadeshi cloth.
('23', 403, 3, 25, 967633) We have at present two varieties of swadeshi cloth, mill cloth and hand spun khadi.
('23', 403, 3, 26, 967717) For us the only cloth is khadi, mill cloth should be
('23', 404, 0, 1, 967770) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 405
('23', 404, 1, 2, 967812) reserved for the poor.
('23', 404, 1, 3, 967835) Some persons, being slaves to pleasure and comfort, do not like to wear khadi; they feel an aversion to it.
('23', 404, 1, 4, 967943) But till you are able to make this sacrifice, it will be impossible to end our slavery.
('23', 404, 1, 5, 968031) If you cannot bring yourself to wear khadi, use mill cloth.
('23', 404, 1, 6, 968091) If at all you take a pledge, it must be to wear khadi exclusively.
('23', 404, 1, 7, 968158) There is khadi worth Rs. 10, 000 in the Khadi Bhandar at Kalbadevi and it is selling.
('23', 404, 1, 8, 968244) I discussed the matter with Shri Narandas Purushottam today and, in a few days, khadi worth and less than Rs. 50, 000 will arrive.
('23', 404, 1, 9, 968375) Do not use more khadi than necessary.
('23', 404, 1, 10, 968413) The country is not in a position to supply as much as people may want.
('23', 404, 1, 11, 968484) Khadi should be used as economically as ghee and gold.
('23', 404, 1, 12, 968539) We should indulge in no ostentation so long as we do not have swaraj.
('23', 404, 1, 13, 968609) The men should have two long shirts and a dhoti each and the women, too, should make do with a few clothes.
('23', 404, 1, 14, 968717) A friend has said that we should be ready even for hanging, but you will not have to mount the gallows.
('23', 404, 1, 15, 968821) If the country gets ready for this, we should have swaraj right today.
('23', 404, 1, 16, 968892) When such a time comes, though, I shall not need to tell you to boycott foreign cloth.
('23', 404, 1, 17, 968979) At present there is no strength left in us.
('23', 404, 1, 18, 969023) Some sisters complain that they find it difficult to part with Japanese saris and French silks and to start wearing khadi.

('23', 404, 1, 21, 969329) This too you can disprove by giving up foreign cloth.

('23', 406, 11, 20, 972337) 196. SPEECH AT MEETING OF LIQUOR CONTRACTORS, BOMBAY 1
('23', 406, 12, 21, 972392) July 12, 1921
('23', 406, 13, 22, 972406) Mahatma Gandhi said, since he had returned to Bombay, he had realized the position of liquor contractors and he had been thinking what he should advise the Provincial Congress Committee and also the liquor merchants.
('23', 406, 13, 23, 972623) He had been thinking
('23', 406, 14, 24, 972644) 1 Under the auspices of the Parsi Rajkiya Sabha, Gandhiji addressed the liquor traders of Bombay at the Marwari Vidyalaya Hall on Tuesday morning.
('23', 407, 0, 1, 972791) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 407, 1, 2, 972833) deeply over these things and he felt much for the liquor merchants who were earning their livelihood by means of selling liquor to the people.
('23', 407, 1, 3, 972976) Mr. B. F. Bharucha had supplied him with facts and figures in this regard and many Parsi brethren had also written to him both anonymously and in their own names; he knew from all these what the actual position in the city was with regard to this trade.
('23', 407, 1, 4, 973230) He wished to tell them that, even if there were only a dozen or so bad men among the small Parsi community of 80,000, they would hurt it while, even if there were five or seven lakhs among the Hindus and Muslims they would not be so glaringly prominent.
('23', 407, 1, 5, 973484) That was always the case in the world.
('23', 407, 1, 6, 973523) So, while the few Parsi liquor shop keepers had come into notoriety, others were forgotton; the example of the Parsi liquor dealers was very prominently before the country.
('23', 407, 1, 7, 973696) At the Excelsior Theatre he had told his Parsi friends that they would be able to set an example to the whole country by their noble conduct.
('23', 407, 1, 8, 973838) Therefore, he was deeply sorry that so many people among the Parsis were earning their livelihood by selling liquor to the public and he thought it was a great discredit to them.
('23', 407, 1, 9, 974017) He was also sorry that so many widows had to maintain themselves by selling liquor.
('23', 407, 1, 10, 974101) In his opinion it was better for these women to break stones or even beg their food than to sell liquor to the people.
('23', 407, 2, 11, 974220) If he had the means of a Petit or a Tata, he would have fallen at the feel of these Parsi widows and begged of them to give up this trade and take as much money as they liked.
('23', 407, 2, 12, 974396) He would have been too glad to look after them.
('23', 407, 2, 13, 974444) If he had any money at his disposal the first use he would make of it would be to offer it to his Parsi sisters and brothers and ask them to give up this liquor trade.
('23', 407, 2, 14, 974612) Some of his Parsi friends had told him that they could not give up their daily glass of liquor; some had told him that the Parsi religion prohibited drinking, while others had told him that the Parsi religion permitted them to drink liquor.
('23', 407, 2, 15, 974853) His heart, however, was full of sorrow for his Parsi sisters whether their religion permitted drinking or not.
('23', 407, 2, 16, 974964) If the poison of liquor selling continued long, it was enough to destroy a small community like theirs.
('23', 407, 3, 17, 975068) His Parsi friends must have heard of Shri Krishna and His prophecy in regard to the Yadavas, who numbered lakhs and even more.
('23', 407, 3, 18, 975195) Shri Krishna had told them that if they drank and committed adultery, the whole tribe would disappear for ever from the face of the earth.
('23', 407, 3, 19, 975334) And what was there left now of the powerful Yadavas?
('23', 407, 3, 20, 975387) Was not adultery a handy companion of drink?
('23', 407, 3, 21, 975432) He knew from his experience in South Africa what sort of people these liquor sellers and buyers were.
('23', 407, 3, 22, 975534) Those who sold liquor had to descend to the level of the drunkards and then be on the same level of mentality.
('23', 407, 3, 23, 975645) He had much experience of these things and he was only telling them what he had actually seen all over the country.
('23', 407, 3, 24, 975761) He was also of opinion that those who sold liquor could not be honest.
('23', 407, 3, 25, 975832) He was not only addressing his Parsi brethren, but also Bhandaris who had written to him that they were ruined and that they would give up
('23', 407, 4, 26, 975971) the trade gradually in about 20 or 25 years.
('23', 407, 4, 27, 976016) Was it possible for this country to wait till then?
('23', 407, 4, 28, 976068) What did it avail to the country for a thief or an adulterer to say that he
('23', 408, 0, 1, 976144) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 409
('23', 408, 1, 2, 976186) would give up his vice in a few days?
('23', 408, 1, 3, 976224) If the Parsis did not give up this traffic at once, they would injure their community and their country.
('23', 408, 1, 4, 976329) They must not take into consideration the apparent prosperity and which they had gained by following the liquor trade.
('23', 408, 1, 5, 976448) He would appeal to his Parsi friends to look after the Parsi widows whatever it might.
('23', 408, 1, 6, 976535) Cost them, or however great sacrifice it might entail.
('23', 408, 1, 7, 976590) It was better for them to do any honest think than get rich at the expense of the vast majority of the people.
('23', 408, 2, 8, 976701) As for picketing, he never thought it could be permanently stopped.

('23', 408, 3, 18, 977641) Not a single soul was allowed to go unchallenged to the registration office to register himself.

('23', 408, 6, 30, 979065) He expected greater things from the Parsi community on account of their nobility, their knowledge and their courage.

('23', 409, 1, 5, 979509) What they had given to Government they could easily get back from them.

('23', 410, 2, 3, 982257) FRONTIER FRIENDS
('23', 410, 3, 4, 982274) Mr. Mahomed Nawezkhan, B. A., LL.B., of Bannu, writes a long letter on my appeal to the Frontier friends.
('23', 410, 3, 5, 982380) I propose to give a brief summary of it instead of reproducing the whole letter, which is too discursive for the columns of Young India.
('23', 410, 3, 6, 982517) He thinks that the tribesmen who learn the message will gladly respond.
('23', 410, 3, 7, 982589) He traces the history of the annexation of the territory of the tribesmen, and proves that, before these territories were annexed, there were practically no raids.
('23', 410, 3, 8, 982753) Moreover, all were equally armed and, therefore, the raided parties were well able to take care of themselves.
('23', 410, 3, 9, 982864) But after annexation, the tribesmen who were wantonly robbed of their lands treated both the Hindu and the Mussul man inhabitants of the annexed territories as their enemies, the more so as the latter helped the Government in subduing the tribesmen.
('23', 410, 3, 10, 983114) The writer, who claims an intimate acquain tance with the situation, is of opinion that the tribesmen have been no respecters of religions, and have subjected to their depredations the Hindus and the Mussulmans alike, and that Mussulmans have never been known to assist the Hindus against the raiders.
('23', 410, 3, 11, 983416) In proof of impartiality, the writer instance the cordial treatment meted out to the Hindus in the independent territory of the Frontier tribes.
('23', 410, 3, 12, 983561) He states that the Hindus living there have greater freedom of worship than even in the British territory.
('23', 410, 3, 13, 983668) Their social status is any day better than under the British Government, and the Maliks 1 are ever ready with all their might to defend their Hindu friends living within their jurisdic tion.
('23', 410, 3, 14, 983859) The writer gives it as his judgment that the British Government in the Frontier Province has sinfully abdicated its function of protecting the inhabitants, who have unfortunately come under the so called protecting wing of the British Empire.
('23', 410, 3, 15, 984102) He winds up his letter by saying that the Frontier regulations are worth studying, the procedure there is most arbitrary, and the life and property of the people are at the mercy of military officers who are incapable of giving judicial decisions.
('23', 410, 3, 16, 984350) Extra Assistant Commissioners, he says, in effect disgrace their commi ssions and become instruments of injustice and oppre ssion.

('23', 411, 2, 3, 984695) AN INDIAN REPUBLIC?
('23', 411, 2, 4, 984715) An esteemed correspondent writes?
('23', 411, 3, 5, 984749) Your attention must have been drawn to statements made by Maulanas Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali that, if no settlement is arrived at before Christmas regarding our campaign, an Indian republic will be declared at the Ahmedabad session of the Congress.
('23', 411, 3, 6, 985000) Special importance attaches to this statement as it is not made by an irresponsible person but by responsible leaders like the Maulanas.
('23', 411, 3, 7, 985137) It is felt, however, that the statement is both unfortunate and premature, and is likely to come in the way of the programme laid down for the country by the Congress.
('23', 411, 3, 8, 985305) The country as a whole has responded magnificenlty to the appeal of the Congress, and is prepared, excepting certain sections, to work for the attainment of swaraj.
('23', 411, 3, 9, 985470) I would ask you to give your views regarding the Maulanas’ statement, and to assure the public that no departure from the policy of non violent non co operation accepted by the Congress will be made.

('23', 411, 4, 11, 985987) Nor do I entertain the slightest fear of any departure from that policy on the part of the Brothers.

('23', 415, 1, 3, 995115) CO OPERATION AND NON CO OPERATION DEFINED It is no small thing for the country that Dwijendranath Tagore, fondly known as Bada Dada by his friends, follows with keen attention even in his old age and in his seclusion at Shantiniketan all that is going on in the country.
('23', 415, 1, 4, 995386) Mr. Andrews has circulated a free translation of his latest thoughts on non co operation.
('23', 415, 1, 5, 995476) Although the whole of it is publi shed in the daily Press, I cannot resist reproducing his defini tions of co operation and non co operation; they are so true and telling.
('23', 415, 1, 6, 995648) Writing of the former he says:
('23', 415, 2, 7, 995679) Our rulers, in order to hide their despotic measures from the world’s eye, dressed up a puppet show in the form of Legislative Councils, in which a few platform orators have been invited to co operate.
('23', 415, 2, 8, 995881) Our rulers believe that by doing so they have placed us under an eternal debt of gratitude, but in reality they have only added insult to injury.
('23', 415, 2, 9, 996027) These Councils cling to us now, and threaten to choke us like the old man in the story of Sindbad the Sailor.
('23', 415, 2, 10, 996137) If this is the meaning of co operation, according to our English rulers, then it is no very difficult matter to understand what non co operation means to us.
('23', 415, 2, 11, 996295) We small never accept, even if it costs us our lives to refuse it, anything that will bring evil upon our country.
('23', 415, 2, 12, 996410) That is non co operation.
('23', 415, 2, 13, 996436) WORTHY OF IMITATION Mr. Vithalbhai Patel is never so happy as when he is fighting Municipal or Legislative Councils.
('23', 415, 2, 14, 996553) He was therefore in his element on the sixth instant, when he moved and carried in the Thana District Board the following resolutions:
('23', 415, 3, 15, 996688) 1. This Board expresses its sorrow to find that the sale of liquor is
('23', 415, 4, 16, 996758) one the increase, resulting in the loss of public morals, health and wealth.
('23', 415, 5, 17, 996835) 2. This Board welcomes the popular movement for removing the evil, and congratulates the organizers upon this exhibition of a spirit of public service.
('23', 415, 6, 18, 996987) 3. This Board notes with regret the absence of any power of prohibiting the sale of liquor within its jurisdiction.
('23', 415, 6, 19, 997103) Therefore, the Board is of opinion that it should take advantage of all the powers it possesses of undertaking picketing on its responsibility, of helping Congress Committees and of compensating those liquor dealers who may voluntarily undertake to close their shops.
('23', 415, 7, 20, 997371) 4. For the purposes aforesaid, the Board hereby appoints a Committee consisting of the Chairman, the Vice chairman—the mover—and Mr. Acharya
('23', 416, 0, 1, 997512) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 417
('23', 416, 1, 2, 997554) with powers to conduct or control picketing and to bring about total prohi bition.

('23', 416, 3, 4, 997815) This is distinctly a courageous step.

('23', 416, 3, 6, 998111) I hope that Mr. Patel’s initiative will be copied by other members and councillors throughout India.

('23', 416, 3, 8, 998544) THE ARMS ACT The refusal of the Magistrate of Bijnor District of renew the fire arms licence in favour of the Assistant Governor of Kangri Gurukul, brought to light by Swami Shraddhanand, is an eloquent demons tration of the utter futility of the Reforms.
('23', 416, 3, 9, 998800) If Swami Shraddhanand’s guess that the refusal is due to his having been prominently identified with non co operation turns out to be true, it will show that, in things affecting the daily life of the people, there is absolutely no change in the methods of administration or the conduct of officials except such as has been compelled by the pressure of non co operation.

('23', 418, 1, 2, 1002631) BLASPHEMY A correspondent writes:
('23', 418, 2, 3, 1002665) I regret very much to inform you that one constantly sees pictures in which you and other leaders have been represented as Shri Krishna and Pandavas, respectively.
('23', 418, 2, 4, 1002829) Will you not use your influence to stop this, as it must hurt religious feelings of many like myself, who consider Shri Krishna to have been not merely a great man but God incarnate?
('23', 418, 2, 5, 1003012) The correspondent has my fullest sympathy.
('23', 418, 2, 6, 1003055) I have not seen the pictures, but I hold it to be a blasphemy to represent me as Shri Krishna.
('23', 418, 2, 7, 1003150) I claim to be a humble worker and no more among many in a great cause, which can only be injured rather than advanced by glorification of its leaders.
('23', 418, 2, 8, 1003301) A cause has the best chance of success when it is examined and followed on its own merits.
('23', 418, 2, 9, 1003392) Measures must always in a progressive society be held superior to men, who are after all imperfect instruments, working for their fulfilment.
('23', 418, 2, 10, 1003534) I would there fore urge, with all the strength at my command, enthusiasts or enter prising business men to observe some sense of proportion and with draw all such pictures, which, like the one under notice, are undoub tedly calculated to wound deep religious susceptibilities.
('23', 418, 2, 11, 1003811) KARACHI SCHOOLS I owe an apology to Mr. Jagtiani for not publishing earlier his important explanation regarding his school.
('23', 418, 2, 12, 1003935) The fact is that, during my incessant travelling, I have no been able to cope with all my corres pondence.Having got breathing time in Bombay, I am endea vouring to overtake arrears, and I have only just come across his letter.
('23', 418, 2, 13, 1004163) Here is the relevant part of it.
('23', 418, 3, 14, 1004196) A letter on the subject of suspicious finance of schools has already appeared in Young India.
('23', 418, 3, 15, 1004290) I agree with the writer.
('23', 418, 3, 16, 1004315) I am Principal of the
('23', 418, 4, 17, 1004337) “Tilakalaya”, about which rumours seem to have been set afloat by some of my opponents.
('23', 418, 4, 18, 1004425) The school was started by me in November last, one month after I had non co operated.
('23', 418, 4, 19, 1004511) Not being able to secure assistance from the Khilafat Committee, I depended upon individual support.
('23', 418, 4, 20, 1004612) A new school wants some time to put itself on its on its legs.
('23', 418, 4, 21, 1004675) But in the case of my school, I began at the very start to hear rumours about my “fat salary”, although the plain fact is, not only that I have drawn no salary as yet, but that there is a deficit of about Rs. 1,200 up to the 31st of May, 1921. As regards finance, the school has a financial board with Mr. Durgadas B. Advani as Chairman.
('23', 418, 4, 22, 1005013) The board met, and the accounts, duly audited by a professional accountant appointed by the Committee, have been passed and a statement of accounts will be published in

('23', 419, 1, 2, 1005224) the report.
('23', 419, 1, 3, 1005236) This is the usual procedure which was to be followed.

('23', 419, 1, 5, 1005413) You will thus see the injustice of the reports that have occasioned your writing; the reports are apparently the result of personal grudge.

('23', 419, 1, 9, 1005838) IN LORD SINHA’S LAND Orissa is the poorest province, perhaps, in all India.
('23', 419, 1, 10, 1005914) Its people are the most inoffensive.
('23', 419, 1, 11, 1005951) The Samaj is an Utkal newspaper.
('23', 419, 1, 12, 1005984) A corres pondent describing the official lawlessness in a small State called Keonjhar writes to the Samaj:
('23', 419, 2, 13, 1006091) You are doubtless getting certain information regarding the affairs in Keonjhar.
('23', 419, 2, 14, 1006172) But the internal conditions are not probably known to you.
('23', 419, 2, 15, 1006231) These internal conditions the State authorites are trying their best to suppress, and thereby reduce the people to utter helplessness.
('23', 419, 2, 16, 1006366) The post offices are closed, so to say.
('23', 419, 2, 17, 1006406) No one gets a newspaper to read.
('23', 419, 2, 18, 1006439) Letters are neither despatched nor delivered.
('23', 419, 2, 19, 1006485) They are first taken to the authorities for perusal, after which they are dealt with according to their contents.
('23', 419, 2, 20, 1006599) The Samaj has been prohibited by
('23', 419, 3, 21, 1006632) circular.
('23', 419, 3, 22, 1006642) So it is not found here.
('23', 419, 3, 23, 1006667) Secondly, no one is allowed to go from one place to another.
('23', 419, 3, 24, 1006728) The roads are guarded by regular watches.
('23', 419, 3, 25, 1006770) The wayfarers are searched on the suspicion of their being in possession of information, and whoever is suspected is prohibited from going further.
('23', 419, 3, 26, 1006918) In this way no stone is left unturned in the attempt to oppress the people who are utterly helpless.
('23', 419, 3, 27, 1007019) One Nishakar Mishra, from among the people who had been beaten, is reported to have died of it.
('23', 419, 3, 28, 1007115) This news has been suppressed.
('23', 419, 3, 29, 1007146) Another, by name Jagadbandhu Chakravarti, is on the point of death, and hardly expected to live.
('23', 419, 3, 30, 1007243) They say that he is in solitary confinement.
('23', 419, 3, 31, 1007288) But no one knows where he is.
('23', 419, 3, 32, 1007318) People strongly believe that the authorities are doing their best to suppress the news of deaths.
('23', 419, 3, 33, 1007416) I have more corroborative correspondence too on the point.
('23', 419, 3, 34, 1007475) The reader must not confound this State with the States of Western India.
('23', 419, 3, 35, 1007549) In the Utkal States, the English political agent is the supreme master and acts just as he pleases.
('23', 419, 3, 36, 1007649) The zoolum described above is going on, because the people countenanced non co operation workers.
('23', 419, 3, 37, 1007747) The only comfort I can send them that they should suffer whilst India’ chains remain fastened to her.

('23', 420, 2, 8, 1008450) 198. A RUNNING SORE
('23', 420, 3, 9, 1008470) His Excellency the Viceroy in his reply to the Liberal League Deputation from the United Provinces delivered and address which was more cautious than his reply to the Ahmadiyya Deputation.
('23', 420, 3, 10, 1008659) Never theless, it is necessary to remind His Excellency that in it he has asked India to do the impossible.
('23', 420, 3, 11, 1008767) Liberals and Nationalists, co ope rators and non co operators, Hindus, Mussulmans, Sikhs, Jains, Parsis, Christians, Jews and all who call themselves Indians insist, each in his own way, upon the Punjab and the Khilafat wrongs being righted.
('23', 420, 3, 12, 1009009) His Excellency is still pressing the Khilafat claim.
('23', 420, 3, 13, 1009062) That is hopeful, in that he does not ask the Mussulmans of India and their Hindu and other countrymen to forget the Khilafat wrong.
('23', 420, 3, 14, 1009194) But he clearly asks us to forget the Punjab wrong.
('23', 420, 3, 15, 1009245) The task is as impossible as it would be for a physician to make a patient forget—except under the temporary influence of some stupefying drug—his painful disease.
('23', 420, 3, 16, 1009409) The Punjab wrong is like a running sore, and even as a running sore cannot be healed unless the whole of the poison is removed, so can the Punjab wrong not be forgotten and forgiven unless and until the poison in the shape of pensions to and continued employment of unrepentant and faithless servants has been removed.
('23', 420, 3, 17, 1009728) Does Lord Reading imagine that India is reconciled to the translation of Mr. Thomson to a higher post?
('23', 420, 3, 18, 1009831) He asks us to give him and his Government credit for sincerity and honesty of purpose.
('23', 420, 3, 19, 1009918) He may have that credit, but there arises immediately upon the grant of that credit the belief that there is a fundamental difference between the Govern ment’s and the people’s outlook upon vital matters.
('23', 420, 3, 20, 1010123) And so long as Lord Reading and his Government continue, be it ever so sincerely, to ask India to be recon ciled to the retention on the pension list or on the service list of the names of those who have, from an Indian standpoint, proved
('23', 421, 0, 1, 1010362) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 421, 1, 2, 1010404) unworthy of the trust reposed in them, so long there can be no meet ing ground between the Government and the people.
('23', 421, 1, 3, 1010522) If we have even a semblance of respons ibility given to us, surely we must have the right to dismiss from service those who have atrociously wronged us.
('23', 421, 1, 4, 1010675) To me it is a supreme test of responsibility—the righting of the two wrongs.
('23', 421, 1, 5, 1010752) The injustice of the Khilafat wrong is admitted.
('23', 421, 1, 6, 1010801) The atrocity in the Punjab is written in letters of blood.
('23', 421, 1, 7, 1010860) We admit that we did wrong in Amritsar, in Kasur, in Jallian wala and in Gujaranwala.
('23', 421, 1, 8, 1010946) We have been made to pay for it heavily.
('23', 421, 1, 9, 1010987) We have been humiliated, kicked.
('23', 421, 1, 10, 1011020) Both the innocent and the guilty have been hanged.
('23', 421, 1, 11, 1011071) We have ourselves made a frank, free and open confession from many a platform.
('23', 421, 1, 12, 1011150) We ask for no humiliation of official wrongdoers.
('23', 421, 1, 13, 1011200) All we ask is that they may not be imposed upon us as masters.
('23', 421, 1, 14, 1011263) And English official once frankly told me that rather than be party, by remaining in the service, to the removal from the pension list of Sir Michael O’Dwyer or General Dyer, he would resign.
('23', 421, 1, 15, 1011455) I told him that, whilst I could see my way to sympathize with such an attitude, he must not expect me to agree with him.
('23', 421, 1, 16, 1011576) Nor did he.
('23', 421, 1, 17, 1011588) Hundreds, if not thousands, of English men and Englishwomen consider Sir Michael O’Dwyer and General Dyer as sav iours of the Empire and the honour of their kind.
('23', 421, 1, 18, 1011751) It is highly likely that, if I were an Englishman intent upon holding India at any cost, I would feel even as they.
('23', 421, 1, 19, 1011867) But I hold that, so long as attitude is retained, so long must co operation between the Govern ment and the people be impossible.
('23', 421, 1, 20, 1011997) Non co operation alone can open the eyes of Englishmen to the fact that co operation with them in the Government of the country involves an acceptance of their attitude.
('23', 421, 1, 21, 1012167) But it is inconsistent with their position as friends and associates.
('23', 421, 1, 22, 1012237) They may not remain in India on the Strength of their bayonets.
('23', 421, 1, 23, 1012301) They can remain only on the strength of our goodwill.
('23', 421, 1, 24, 1012355) That and that alone must be the binding force between them and us.
('23', 421, 1, 25, 1012422) Let them not mock us by professing equality on the lips and by maintaining behind their entrenchments an unassailable superiority.
('23', 421, 1, 26, 1012553) As a shrewd man of the world, Lord Reading, I hope, will soon recognize the impossibility of reconciling two opposite attitudes.
('23', 421, 1, 27, 1012682) Had there been a middle course, non co operators would have adopted it long ago.
('23', 421, 1, 28, 1012763) It is not a question of hatred or ill will on the part of the vast mass of people.
('23', 421, 1, 29, 1012846) I invite him to drive the probe deep enough, and he would find that weak as we are, we can no longer tolerate the cult of white superiority.
('23', 421, 1, 30, 1012987) Lip professions, well meaning and sincere though they may be, can serve no useful purpose.
('23', 421, 1, 31, 1013078) We are idolatrous enough to demand ocular proof

('23', 422, 1, 2, 1013168) of equality.
('23', 422, 1, 3, 1013181) Does he not see that the existence of white soldiers may be a necessity for the safety of Englishmen, never for the safety of the Indian Border?
('23', 422, 1, 4, 1013326) Englishmen must be prepared to live in India precisely on the same terms as the Parsis.
('23', 422, 1, 5, 1013414) A mere handful of the latter have remained for the last thousand years as honoured friends and partners.
('23', 422, 1, 6, 1013519) They have needed no special protection, no fort to retire to in times of danger from enraged Hindus or Mussulmans.
('23', 422, 1, 7, 1013634) Have not the followers of Moses and Jesus the faith of those of Zoroaster?

('23', 422, 1, 9, 1013839) The latter are not prepared to give the former any advantageous position by reagon of their controlling all the most destructive appliances that human ingenuity has ever invented.
('23', 422, 1, 10, 1014019) There is no choice before the latter but that of making a supreme effort to neutralize the effect of all those appliances by ceasing to fear them, i.e., by non resistance.
('23', 422, 1, 11, 1014191) This may all appear to be arrogant or visionary.
('23', 422, 1, 12, 1014240) I hope, however, that Lord Reading at any rate will soon find that I have spoken the real mind of India.
('23', 422, 1, 13, 1014345) And the sooner this fundamental truth is realized, the sooner will there be real hearty co operation between Englishmen and Indians.
('23', 422, 1, 14, 1014478) I am longing for such co operation, and it is this very longing which deters me from accepting any apology, no matter how tempting, for co operation.
('23', 422, 1, 15, 1014628) Non co operation is not born of igno rance and ill will, but it is the only effective step towards co operation, and therefore it rises from knowledge and love.

('23', 423, 1, 2, 1014854) 199. TO EVERY ENGLISHMAN IN INDIA
('23', 423, 2, 3, 1014888) DEAR FRIEND, This is the second time I venture to address you.
('23', 423, 2, 4, 1014951) 1 I know that most of you detest non co operation.
('23', 423, 2, 5, 1015002) But I would invite you to isolate two of my activities from the rest, if you can give me credit for honesty.
('23', 423, 2, 6, 1015111) I cannot prove my honesty, if you do not feel it.
('23', 423, 2, 7, 1015161) Some of my Indian friends charge me with camouflage when I say we need not hate Englishmen whilst we may hate the system they have established.
('23', 423, 2, 8, 1015305) I am trying to show them that one may detest the wickedness of a brother without hating him.
('23', 423, 2, 9, 1015398) Jesus denounced the wickedness of the Scribes and the Pharises, but he did not hate them.
('23', 423, 2, 10, 1015488) He did not enunciate this law of love for the man and hate for the evil in him for himself only, but he taught the doctrine for universal practice.
('23', 423, 2, 11, 1015636) Indeed, I find it in all the scriptures of the world.
('23', 423, 2, 12, 1015690) I claim to be a fairly accurate student of human nature and vivisector of my own failings.
('23', 423, 2, 13, 1015781) I have discovered than man is superior to the system he propounds.
('23', 423, 2, 14, 1015848) And so I feel that you as an individual are infinitely better than the system you have evolved as a corporation.
('23', 423, 2, 15, 1015961) Each one of my countrymen in Amritsar on that fateful 10th of April was better than the crowd of which he was a member.
('23', 423, 2, 16, 1016081) He, as a man, would have declined to kill those innocent English bank managers.
('23', 423, 2, 17, 1016161) But in that crowd, many a man forgot himself.
('23', 423, 2, 18, 1016207) Hence it is that an Englishman in office is different from an Englishman outside.
('23', 423, 2, 19, 1016289) Similarly, an Englishman in India is different from an Englishman in England.
('23', 423, 2, 20, 1016367) Here in India, you belong to a system that is vile beyond description.
('23', 423, 2, 21, 1016438) It is possible, therefore, for me to condemn the system in the strongest terms, without considering you to be bad and without imputing bad motives to every Englishman.
('23', 423, 2, 22, 1016606) You are as much slaves of the system as we are.
('23', 423, 2, 23, 1016654) I want you, therefore, to reciprocate, and not impute to me motives which you cannot read in the written word.
('23', 423, 2, 24, 1016765) I give you the whole of my motive when I tell you that I am impatient to end or mend a system, which has made India subservient to a handful of you and which has made Englishmen feel secure only in the shadow of the forts and the guns that obtrude themselves on one’s
('23', 423, 3, 25, 1017033) 1 Earlier Gandhiji had addressed an open letter to the Englishmen on October 27, 1920.
('23', 424, 0, 1, 1017120) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 425
('23', 424, 1, 2, 1017162) notice in India.
('23', 424, 1, 3, 1017179) It is a degrading spectacle for you and for us.
('23', 424, 1, 4, 1017227) Our corporate life is based on mutual distrust and fear.
('23', 424, 1, 5, 1017284) This, you will admit, is unmanly.
('23', 424, 1, 6, 1017318) A system that is responsible for such a state of things is necessarily Satanic.
('23', 424, 1, 7, 1017398) You should be able to life in India as an integral part of its people and not always as foreign exploiters.
('23', 424, 1, 8, 1017506) One thousand Indian lives against one English life is a doctrine of dark despair, and yet, believe me, it was enunciated in 1919 by the highest of you in the land.
('23', 424, 1, 9, 1017670) I almost feel tempted to invite you to join me in destroying a system that has dragged both you and us down.
('23', 424, 1, 10, 1017779) But I feel I cannot as yet do so.
('23', 424, 1, 11, 1017813) We have not shown ourselves earnest, self sacrificing and self restrained enough for that consummation.
('23', 424, 1, 12, 1017917) But I do ask you to help us in the boycott of foreign cloth and in the anti drink campaign.
('23', 424, 1, 13, 1018009) The Lancashire cloth, as English historians have shown, was forced upon India, and her own world famed manufactures were delib erately and systematically ruined.
('23', 424, 1, 14, 1018171) India is, therefore, at the mercy not only of Lanca shire but also of Japan, France and America.
('23', 424, 1, 15, 1018268) Just see what this has meant to India.
('23', 424, 1, 16, 1018307) We send out of India every year sixty crores (more or less) of rupees for cloth.
('23', 424, 1, 17, 1018388) We grow enough cotton for our own cloth.
('23', 424, 1, 18, 1018429) Is it no mad ness to send cotton outside India, and have it manufactured into cloth there and shipped to us?
('23', 424, 1, 19, 1018538) Was it right to reduce India to such a helpless state?
('23', 424, 1, 20, 1018593) A hundred and fifty years ago, we manufactured all our cloth.
('23', 424, 1, 21, 1018655) Our women spun fine yarn in their own cottages, and supplemented the earnings of their husbands.
('23', 424, 1, 22, 1018752) The village weavers wove that yarn.
('23', 424, 1, 23, 1018788) It was an indispensable part of national economy in a vast agricultural country like ours.
('23', 424, 1, 24, 1018879) It enabled us in a most natural manner to utilize our leisure.
('23', 424, 1, 25, 1018942) Today our women have lost the cunning of their hands, and the enforced idleness of millions has impoverished the land.
('23', 424, 1, 26, 1019061) Many weavers have become sweepers.
('23', 424, 1, 27, 1019096) Some have taken to the profession of hired soldiers.
('23', 424, 1, 28, 1019149) Half the race of artistic weavers has died out, and the other half is weaving imported foreign yarn for want of finer hand spun yarn.
('23', 424, 1, 29, 1019283) You will perhaps now understand what boycott of foreign cloth means to India.
('23', 424, 1, 30, 1019361) It is not devised as a punishment.
('23', 424, 1, 31, 1019396) If the Government were today to redress the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and consent to India attaining immediate swaraj, the boycott movement must still continue.
('23', 424, 1, 32, 1019562) Swaraj means at least the power to conserve Indian indus tries that are vital to the economic existence of the nation, and to

('23', 425, 1, 4, 1019861) They must be protected against consumption at any cost.
('23', 425, 1, 5, 1019917) This matter does not admit of any waiting.
('23', 425, 1, 6, 1019960) The interests of the foreign manufacturers and the Indian importers cannot be considered when the whole nation is starving for want of a large productive occupation ancillary to agriculture.
('23', 425, 1, 7, 1020151) You will not mistake this for a movement of general boycott of foreign goods.

('23', 425, 1, 21, 1021233) You can assist the growth of the everrising agitation by throwing in the weight of your influence on the side of the nation.

('23', 425, 4, 23, 1021416) 200. A CONFESSION OF FAITH
('23', 425, 5, 24, 1021443) A strange anonymous letter has been received by me, admiring me for having taken up a cause that was dearest Lokamanya’s heart, and telling me that his spirit was residing in me and that I must prove a worthy follower of his.
('23', 425, 5, 25, 1021669) The letter, moreover, admonishes me not to lose heart in the prosecution of the swaraj programme, and finishes off by accusing me of imposture in claiming to be politically a disciple of Gokhale.
('23', 425, 5, 26, 1021865) I wish correspondents will throw off the slavish
('23', 426, 0, 1, 1021914) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 427
('23', 426, 1, 2, 1021956) habit of writing anonymously.
('23', 426, 1, 3, 1021986) We who are developing the swaraj spirit must cultivate the courage of fearlessly speaking out our mind.
('23', 426, 1, 4, 1022090) The subject matter of the letter, however, being of public importance, demands a reply.
('23', 426, 1, 5, 1022178) I cannot claim the honour of being a follower of the late Lokamanya.
('23', 426, 1, 6, 1022247) I admire him like millions of his countrymen for his indomitable will, his vast learning, his love of country, and above all, the purity of his private life and great sacrifice.
('23', 426, 1, 7, 1022425) Of all the men of modern times, he captivated most the imagination of his people.
('23', 426, 1, 8, 1022507) He breathed into us the spirit of swaraj.
('23', 426, 1, 9, 1022549) No one perhaps realized the evil of the existing system of Government as Mr. Tilak did.
('23', 426, 1, 10, 1022637) And, in all humility, I claim to deliver his message to the country as truly as the best of his disciples.
('23', 426, 1, 11, 1022744) But I am conscious that my method is not Mr. Tilak’s method.
('23', 426, 1, 12, 1022805) And that is why I have still difficulty with some of the Maharashtra leaders.
('23', 426, 1, 13, 1022883) But I sincerely think that Mr. Tilak did not disbelieve in my method.
('23', 426, 1, 14, 1022953) I enjoyed the privilege of his confidence.
('23', 426, 1, 15, 1022996) And his last word to me in the presence of several friends was, just a fortnight before his death that mine was an excellent method if the people could be persuaded to take to it.
('23', 426, 1, 16, 1023176) But he said he had doubts.
('23', 426, 1, 17, 1023203) I know no other method.
('23', 426, 1, 18, 1023227) I can only hope that, when the final test comes, the country will be proved to have assimilated the method of non violent non co operation.
('23', 426, 1, 19, 1023367) Nor am I unaware of my other limitations.
('23', 426, 1, 20, 1023409) I can lay no claim to scholarship.

('23', 434, 2, 3, 1037410) July 16, 1921
('23', 434, 3, 4, 1037424) Mr. Gandhi said one of the great duties they had taken in hand was now accomplised, but a greater and more difficult task lay before them to achieve before realizing swaraj.
('23', 434, 3, 5, 1037598) People who wanted to amass a crore of rupees could only do so by incessant efforts and work, and without these it was not possible to get anything in this world.
('23', 434, 3, 6, 1037760) The work they had undertaken to do was one of greatest difficulty and required greater sacrifices on their part than the mere earning of money.
('23', 434, 3, 7, 1037904) If they wanted to get swaraj, if they wanted their Khilafat and Punjab wrongs—which even the Viceroy was asking them to forget and forgive—redressed, then they had no other course but to make this sacrifice for their country.
('23', 434, 3, 8, 1038130) They wanted swaraj within the shortest possible time.
('23', 434, 3, 9, 1038184) It could not be done without serious effort.
('23', 434, 3, 10, 1038229) If he were convinced that they had not the necessary strength of purpose to do their duty, he would never have spoken to them of swaraj.
('23', 434, 3, 11, 1038366) There was strength latent in them; they had only to realize it.
('23', 434, 3, 12, 1038430) A sister out of the nobility of her heart had sent a sari to him worth about Rs. 900 for the fund.
('23', 434, 3, 13, 1038529) It weighed perhaps 12 to 15 lbs., and he was surprised to find that she could wear such a heavy sari.
('23', 434, 3, 14, 1038631) It was richly embroidered.
('23', 434, 3, 15, 1038658) He had no doubt that she could not have parted with it without a pang.
('23', 434, 3, 16, 1038729) She must have worn that heavy sari with pleasure.
('23', 434, 3, 17, 1038779) He asked the sisters present to wear khaddar saris which were not half as heavy for the sake of their country.
('23', 434, 4, 18, 1038890) They had willingly parted with their money and their ornaments.

('23', 434, 4, 20, 1039027) But he expected them to make that sacrifice if they wished to contribute their full share to the national effort.

('23', 434, 4, 22, 1039259) Boycott of foreign cloth required a sacrifice of their convenience and even their taste.
('23', 434, 4, 23, 1039348) Both men and women were called upon to make that sacrifice.
('23', 434, 4, 24, 1039408) He had a visit that day from two young Indians, recent arrivals from London—one a Bengali and the other a Parsi.

('23', 436, 1, 2, 1043229) 211. REPORT OF THE NON CO OPERATION COMMITTEE 1
('23', 436, 2, 3, 1043277) In view of the threatening situation regarding the Turkish Government in Angora, we have been asked by the Central Khilafat Committee to report upon the best way of meeting it.
('23', 436, 2, 4, 1043454) As a committee appointed to deal with non co operation matters only, we have no authority to consider any means outside non co opera tion.
('23', 436, 2, 5, 1043593) But the success already achieved by the non violent non co operation movement makes it unnecessary, in our opinion, to consider any means outside it.
('23', 436, 2, 6, 1043743) When, at the end of this month the results of the pursuits of the Bezwada programme of the Congress are tabulated, we shall be in a still better position to gause the success of non co operation, and to take, in consultation with the All India Congress Committee, which meets at Lucknow on 22nd July, such steps as the situation may warrant.
('23', 436, 3, 7, 1044085) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE In so far as non co operation is concerned, it is obvious that every further step to be taken must be determined by the condition of the people of India.
('23', 436, 3, 8, 1044258) It has already been suggested that the progress made in the last three months justifies the advisability of having recourse to civil disobedience, The disregard of Muslim and Indian opinion once more displayed by the Government of Britain in the matter of their attitude towards the Turks coupled with the gross misuse of law in India in order to suppress the non co operation movement in spite of its non violence may force us to adopt civil disobedience at an early date.
('23', 436, 3, 9, 1044732) However, since the All India Congress Committee is to consider this proposal in its meeting at Lucknow, it is advisable to await its decision.
('23', 436, 3, 10, 1044875) Nevertheless we desire to point out that the situation in Europe ought to stimulate the people, and particularly the Mussulmans, to great exertion in regard to the programme already before the country, i.e., in respect of titles, councils, schools and colleges, law courts and recruiting.
('23', 436, 3, 11, 1045164) We hold that it is high time the soldier class refrained in a higher measure than it has hitherto done from joining the army.
('23', 436, 3, 12, 1045290) We consider it to be the duty of the Indian soldiers to refuse to assist the British Government, should it require them to fight against the Turks.

('23', 453, 7, 15, 1086067) July 19, 1921
('23', 453, 8, 16, 1086081) Mahatma Gandhi rose to address the meeting.
('23', 453, 8, 17, 1086125) He said that he had long connections with Mussulmans and that the gentleman who took him to Africa for the first time was a Muslim friend.
('23', 453, 8, 18, 1086264) He regarded all these present to be his sisters.
('23', 453, 8, 19, 1086313) All their efforts for the attainment of swaraj were meant for safeguarding their religion and there was no distinction whatsoever in his mind between the Hindus and the Muslims.
('23', 453, 9, 20, 1086491) The Mahatma said that, in his opinion, all religions were good.
('23', 453, 9, 21, 1086555) Sometimes mistakes crept into religion at the instance of some misguided followers.
('23', 453, 9, 22, 1086639) Whatever was written in the holy Koran was all good, and there was truth in all religions.
('23', 453, 9, 23, 1086730) They all stood up for the cause of Islam and they did not want at all a Satanic raj in the world.
('23', 453, 9, 24, 1086828) In the Satanic raj he could not do any good.

('23', 454, 1, 2, 1087155) Aligarh that afternoon intimating him that Mr. Sherwani had been sent to jail not withstanding the fact that he was working for peace.
('23', 454, 1, 3, 1087290) There might arise an occasion when all good men might be sent to jail, and everybody should be ready for that occasion.
('23', 454, 1, 4, 1087410) In Africa, Hindus and Muslims, regardless of sex, went to jail and preserved the honour of their country.

('23', 454, 3, 16, 1088910) Continuing, the Mahatma said that they could manufacture the best Dacca muslin formerly, but owing to the present Government, their weavers were in a sorry plight and were quite unable to do their professional work.

('23', 454, 3, 25, 1089798) They should all pray for the success of Hindus and Muslims, but their prayers would be effective when they had pure hearts and bodies covered with swadeshi cloth.
