('23', 455, 2, 5, 1090332) 219. SPEECH AT MEETING OF LIQUOR CONTRACTORS, BOMBAY 1
('23', 455, 3, 6, 1090387) July 19, 1921
('23', 455, 4, 7, 1090401) Mr. Gandhi said he had told them on the last occasion that picketing was in the hands of the Congress Committee and that he could but advise them what they should do.
('23', 455, 4, 8, 1090568) They, however, knew the result of his advice.
('23', 455, 4, 9, 1090614) Some of the contractors had already seen the petition which was intended to be sent to the Government and, as they were not non co operators, there was not the least objection in their doing so.
('23', 455, 4, 10, 1090809) If they were non co operators they would not have liquor shops.
('23', 455, 4, 11, 1090873) The contractors had a perfect right to petition the Government.
('23', 455, 4, 12, 1090937) It was suggested that they were servants.
('23', 455, 4, 13, 1090979) Even if they were, there was still nothing wrong about their asking the Government for a refund of the fees they had paid to it.
('23', 455, 4, 14, 1091108) It was impossible for Government forcibly to close their shops.
('23', 455, 4, 15, 1091172) For that they would have to pass a new law.
('23', 455, 4, 16, 1091216) But the contractors could so on receiving a refund of their fees.
('23', 455, 5, 17, 1091282) They knew about the Dharwar and Aligarh tragedies and he wanted to tell them that the liquor shops were most responsible for the deaths of so many people.
('23', 455, 5, 18, 1091437) Mr. Sherwani of Aligarh was one of the mostly well known and respectable persons of that place; he belonged to the Muslim nobility and was a Cambridge graduate.
('23', 455, 5, 19, 1091598) He had received a telegram from Aligarh that Mr. Sherwani had also been arrested yesterday.
('23', 455, 5, 20, 1091690) Mr. Sherwani had done his best to pacify the crowd; he had done his best to keep them peaceful; but he had refused to ‘rub the nose’.
('23', 455, 5, 21, 1091824) He had kept up the spirits of the people and he was arrested.
('23', 455, 5, 22, 1091886) Who has responsible for all this trouble?
('23', 455, 5, 23, 1091928) The whole trouble began with picketing.
('23', 455, 5, 24, 1091968) Mr. Gangadharrao Deshpande has sent him a telegram from Belgaum that he and other friends had been ordered not to picket the shops in the Cantonment there and Mr. Deshpande had asked his advice whether they should disobey this order.
('23', 455, 5, 25, 1092202) His advice to Mr. Deshpande was that, although the order was illegal, he must obey it and that restraint would fit them for civil disobedience.
('23', 455, 5, 26, 1092346) He thought it was the duty of the liquor vendors to bow to the wishes of crores of their countrymen.
('23', 455, 5, 27, 1092447) By closing their shops they would benefit their country, and what was good for their country was also good for them.
('23', 455, 5, 28, 1092564) He knew it for a fact that some of the contractors were in a bad financial condition and it was the duty of the community to
('23', 455, 6, 29, 1092689) 1 Held under the auspices of the Parsi Rajkiya Sabha at the Marwadi Vidyalaya Hall
('23', 456, 0, 1, 1092772) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 457
('23', 456, 1, 2, 1092814) see what they could do for these people.
('23', 456, 1, 3, 1092855) But they must admit that, by keeping their shops open, the vendors were doing a disservice to their country.
('23', 456, 2, 4, 1092964) Mr. Gandhi warned the contractors that if nothing was done at the end of August there would be great trouble.
('23', 456, 2, 5, 1093074) When picketing was resumed it would be taken up seriously, The picketers would welcome imprisonment and even be shot rather than give up their adopted task.
('23', 456, 2, 6, 1093231) He felt that the shops must be closed even if there were rivers of blood by reason of the picketers not stopping at the Government’s bidding.
('23', 456, 2, 7, 1093373) He could not promise the contractors that picketing would not begin afresh in the month of August, for what they had undertaken to do they must successfully accomplish, at whatever cost it might be.
('23', 456, 2, 8, 1093572) He had already received letters complaining that he had not done right in stopping picketing.
('23', 456, 2, 9, 1093666) He was blemed for giving weak advice to the Ali Brothers, he was blamed for stopping the satyagraha movement and now he was blamed for stopping picketing.
('23', 456, 2, 10, 1093821) Whatever advice he had given to the Ali Brothers it was not weakness, but of strength, and so it was regarding satyagraha and picketing.
('23', 456, 2, 11, 1093958) He therefore, beseeched the liquor dealers to listen to the nation’s cry and prevent the impending sacrifice.
('23', 456, 2, 12, 1094068) He would welcome death in the act of picketing rather than from disease.
('23', 456, 2, 13, 1094141) And he had no doubt there were many who have prepared to do likewise.
('23', 456, 3, 14, 1094211) At the end of his speech he invited the contractors to ask him any questions they liked and appealed to them to do their duty by the country at this moment.
('23', 456, 4, 15, 1094368) Mr. Maneckji Baria said there was dishonesty in every profession and not among the liqour sellers only.
('23', 456, 4, 16, 1094472) The question before them was who was to close the shops and when?
('23', 456, 4, 17, 1094538) The liquor business had been going on for thousands of years and it was not possible to stop it all at once.
('23', 456, 4, 18, 1094647) They should close the shops gradually.
('23', 456, 4, 19, 1094686) There was no shame or dishonesty in any profession, if it were but followed honestly.
('23', 456, 4, 20, 1094772) Everybody had to look after his own interests, and even Mr. Gandhi who was the soul of swadeshism would not prefer a country cart, if he had to go to Colaba, but a fast foreign victoria.
('23', 456, 4, 21, 1094959) They could only stop drinking by inducing the people to give up the habit and by no other means.
('23', 456, 4, 22, 1095056) They had already applied to Government for a refund and as soon as they got it they would stop their shops.
('23', 456, 4, 23, 1095164) Government could only assess their losses on the total sales of the whole year and not of a part of it.
('23', 456, 4, 24, 1095268) He would ask Mr. Gandhi this question: he had said he would get swaraj by the end of September and in that case, could they not pass a law and stop the sale of liquor?
('23', 456, 4, 25, 1095436) From what date did Mr. Gandhi want shops to be stopped?
('23', 456, 4, 26, 1095492) MR. GANDHI: From today (Laughter and cheers.)
('23', 456, 5, 27, 1095538) Mr. Baria said if Mr. Gandhi wanted to stop the trade from today he should be a God!

('23', 460, 1, 2, 1101981) 224. NOTES
('23', 460, 2, 3, 1101992) SOME IFS If you are a weaver feeling for the country, the Khilafat and the Punjab : (1) You should weave only hand spun yarn, and charge so as to give you a living.
('23', 460, 2, 4, 1102157) You should overcome all the difficulties of sizing and adjusting your loom to the requirements of coarse yarn.
('23', 460, 2, 5, 1102268) (2) If you cannot possibly tackle hand spun yarn for warp, you must use Indian mill spun yarn for it and use hand spun for woof.
('23', 460, 2, 6, 1102397) (3) Where even the second alternative is not possible, you should use mill spun yarn for both warp and woof.
('23', 460, 2, 7, 1102506) But you should henceforth cease to use any foreign yarn, whether it is silk or cotton.
('23', 460, 2, 8, 1102593) If you are a Congress official or worker, you should get hold of the weavers within your jurisdiction, and place the foregoing propositions before them for acceptance and help them to the best of your ability.
('23', 460, 2, 9, 1102803) If you are a buyer, insist upon the first class of cloth, but if you have not the sense or the courage to do so, take up the second or the third, but on no account purchase foreign cloth or cloth woven in India but made of foreign yarn.
('23', 460, 2, 10, 1103040) If you are a householder : (1) You should make a fixed determination henceforth not to buy any foreign cloth.
('23', 460, 2, 11, 1103150) (2) You should interview the weaver in your neighbourhood and get him to weave for you enough khadi out of homespun and, failing that, to weave out of Indian mill spun yarn.
('23', 460, 2, 12, 1103324) (3) You should deliver to the Congress Committee all your foreign cloth for destruction or sending to Smyrna or elsewhere outside India.
('23', 460, 2, 13, 1103461) (4) If you have not the courage to give up your foreign cloth, you may wear it out at home for all dirty work, but never go out in foreign cloth.
('23', 460, 2, 14, 1103607) (5) If you have any leisure, you should devote it to learning the art of spinning even, properly twisted yarn for the sake of the
('23', 461, 0, 1, 1103737) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 461, 1, 2, 1103779) nation.
('23', 461, 1, 3, 1103787) If you are a schoolboy or schoolgirl, you should consider it a sin to receive literary training before you have spun, carded or woven for the nation for at least four hours per day till the establishment of swaraj.
('23', 461, 2, 4, 1104002) CONGRESS COMMITTEES People are asking me whether one crore members have been placed on the Congress register.
('23', 461, 2, 5, 1104112) I have not the accurate figures before me, but I do know that we have nearly reached the figure, if we can be satisfied with the mere mechanical registration.
('23', 461, 2, 6, 1104271) Let us however, understand the implication.
('23', 461, 2, 7, 1104315) It is that we have one crore men and women who believe in and wish to work for the Congress creed.
('23', 461, 2, 8, 1104414) Boycott of foreign cloth is the acid test.
('23', 461, 2, 9, 1104457) If we have one crore of men and women of one mind in India, we must have an ocular proof of it in our streets and villages.
('23', 461, 2, 10, 1104581) Do we see as we walk about that one out of every thirty men and women is dressed in khadi or at least swadeshi?
('23', 461, 2, 11, 1104693) Do the majority of those who make our audiences present the appearance of swadeshi?

('23', 478, 7, 11, 1143183) APPENDIX II
('23', 478, 8, 12, 1143195) SPINNING AS FAMINE RELIEF
('23', 478, 9, 13, 1143221) In the month of August 1920, when the severity of the famine was being felt, the idea of introducing spinning as a famine relief to respectable middle class people was started and Miss Latham kindly gave a spinning wheel to introduce the work.
('23', 478, 9, 14, 1143465) Attempts were made to introduce the work especially among the Dhangars who were
('23', 478, 10, 15, 1143545) used to spinning wool but they proved futile.
('23', 478, 10, 16, 1143591) Spinning a thin thread of cotton was thought an impossibility in a village which did not know anything about it.
('23', 478, 10, 17, 1143704) Doubts were also entertained as to whether the work, if taken up, would be paying or at least helpful.
('23', 478, 10, 18, 1143807) In such different difficulties and objections, the wheel remained idle for nearly three months, and in spite of vigorous efforts nobody seemed willing to take up the work.
('23', 478, 10, 19, 1143979) In December 1920, Miss Latham again sent four more wheels, through the kindness of Mrs. J. Petit, and some cotton.
('23', 478, 10, 20, 1144094) They were given for trial to different persons.
('23', 478, 10, 21, 1144142) Signs now seemed a little hopeful and at last one Ramoshi woman was
('23', 478, 11, 22, 1144210) prevailed upon to take up the work seriously.
('23', 478, 11, 23, 1144256) This was about the 20th of January 1921, since when the work has assumed a different shape.
('23', 478, 11, 24, 1144348) The example of this woman was copied by two more who undertook to take up the work.
('23', 478, 11, 25, 1144432) Through great perseverance 4 lbs.
('23', 478, 11, 26, 1144466) of yarn were prepared by these three spinners and it was sent for sale.
('23', 478, 11, 27, 1144538) In the meantime many women began to make inquiries and expressed a desire to take it up if it helped them financially in some way.
('23', 478, 11, 28, 1144669) A rate of spinning @ 6 as.
('23', 478, 11, 29, 1144696) was therefore fixed and it helped other spinners to join the work.
('23', 478, 12, 30, 1144763) Here another difficulty, viz., that of funds, came in the way.
('23', 478, 12, 31, 1144826) All the five wheels were engaged, and five more prepared locally were also engaged.
('23', 478, 12, 32, 1144910) The stock of cotton was also exhausted.
('23', 478, 12, 33, 1144950) It seemed that the work would suffer for want of funds to prepare wheels, purchase cotton, and pay the workers.
('23', 478, 12, 34, 1145062) Rao Bahadur Chitale perso nally saw this difficulty and helped the work with a grant of Rs. 100. Miss Latham, when she knew of this difficulty, kindly sent another hundred.
('23', 478, 12, 35, 1145235) These two grants came at the right time and gave a stimulus to the work.
('23', 478, 12, 36, 1145308) Local gentlemen helped with their

('23', 481, 4, 11, 1152220) APPENDIX III
('23', 481, 5, 12, 1152233) INTERVIEW CUM APOLOGY
('23', 481, 6, 13, 1152255) His Excellency’s attention has been directed, and notably by Mr. Gandhi, to various statements that have appeared, and to inferences that have been drawn in the public press, relating to the conversations between His Excellency and Mr. Gandhi concerning Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali, which in some respects do not correctly represent the purport of those communications.
('23', 481, 7, 14, 1152633) The interviews between the Viceroy and Mr. Gandhi resulted from a conversation between the Viceroy and Pandit Malaviya relating to the conditions generally prevailing in India.
('23', 481, 7, 15, 1152810) His Excellency informed Pandit Malaviya of the Government’s decision to commence criminal proceedings against Mr. Shaukat Ali for having made speeches inciting to violence and the discussion turned upon the disturbances that might possibly ensue.
('23', 481, 7, 16, 1153057) Pandit Malaviya expressed the opinion that it would be of advantage for His Excellency to meet Mr. Gandhi.
('23', 481, 7, 17, 1153164) His Excellency replied that he would be gald to meet Mr. Gandhi and hear his views if he applied for an interview.
('23', 481, 7, 18, 1153279) On the next day, Mr. Andrews saw His Excellency and suggested that he should see Mr. Gandhi.
('23', 481, 7, 19, 1153372) It should be observed that various important matters were discussed during these conversations and that the proposed interview between His Excellency and Mr. Gandhi was intended to have reference to the situation generally.
('23', 481, 7, 20, 1153596) His Excellency is, however, aware that Pandit Malaviya in inviting Mr. Gandhi to Simla did not refer to the contemplated proceedings against Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali.
('23', 481, 8, 21, 1153774) In due course Mr. Gandhi came to Simla, at the request of Pandit Malaviya and
('23', 482, 0, 1, 1153852) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 483
('23', 482, 1, 2, 1153894) Mr. Andrews, and asked for an interview with His Excellency, which was immediately arranged.
('23', 482, 1, 3, 1153987) At the first interview no mention was made of the proposed prosecutions.
('23', 482, 1, 4, 1154060) The conversation related to the causes of discontent in India.
('23', 482, 1, 5, 1154123) Upon the next occasion His Excellency stated that, according to the Government reports, responsible non co operators had made speeches inciting to violence contrary to the doctrine advocated by Mr. Gandhi.
('23', 482, 1, 6, 1154329) Mr. Gandhi repudiated incitement to violence on the part of any of the responsible non co operators and said that if he was satisfied that any of them had incited to violence, he would publicly repudiate them and their teachings unless they withdrew their statements that amounted to incitement to violence.
('23', 482, 1, 7, 1154637) His Excellency mentioned the names of the Ali brothers and promised to show Mr. Gandhi passages in their speeches which, in his opinion, were calculated to incite to violence, and when the passages were actually read to Mr. Gandhi he admitted that they were capable of bearing the interpretation His Excellency put upon them.
('23', 482, 1, 8, 1154963) He, however, asserted that he was convinced that it was not intended by Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali to incite the audience to violence.
('23', 482, 1, 9, 1155107) Mr. Gandhi added that he would see them as soon as he left Simla and advise them to express publicly their regret for the unintentional incitement contained in the passages.
('23', 482, 1, 10, 1155281) His Excellency, thereupon, asked whether, in view of the importance of the document, Mr. Gandhi would show him the draft of the statement he intended to advise Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali to publish.
('23', 482, 1, 11, 1155489) It was at this stage that the Viceroy said that it was proposed to institute criminal proceedings against Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali in respect of these passages and that, if Mr. Gandhi showed him the statement and it satisfied him
('23', 482, 2, 12, 1155730) from the standpoint of his Government, he would use his influence to prevent the institution of prosecution, for, the Viceroy said, the object of the Government would be attained if the making of speeches of a violent character was in future prevented.
('23', 482, 2, 13, 1155983) Mr. Gandhi readily agreed to show the statement.
('23', 482, 2, 14, 1156032) The draft statement was duly shown by Mr. Gandhi to His Excellency, who pointed out that the introduction of certain paragraphs gave the statement the appearance of a manifesto including that of the religious creed of Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali.
('23', 482, 2, 15, 1156287) The Viceroy observed further that the statement was incomplete so far as it did not contain a promise to refrain in the future from the speeches inciting to violence and added that after, publication of the statement Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali could give any explanation by means of speeches provided they did not infringe the law.
('23', 482, 2, 16, 1156628) Mr. Gandhi agreed to delete the paragraphs in question and to add a passage to cover promises of future conduct.
('23', 482, 2, 17, 1156741) His Excellency then informed Mr. Gandhi that if Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali signed the statement as then altered by Mr. Gandhi, with the addition of the promise as to the future conduct, steps would be taken to suspend the institution of proceedings and that no prosecution would take place so long as the promises given in the published
('23', 483, 0, 1, 1157087) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 483, 1, 2, 1157129) statement were observed.
('23', 483, 1, 3, 1157154) The Government remained free to take up prosecutions for the past speeches.
('23', 483, 1, 4, 1157230) The Viceroy added that, in the event of the publication of the statement by Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali and of the Government refraining in consequence from the prosecutions it would be necessary to issue a communique
('23', 483, 2, 5, 1157456) explaining the attitude of the Government.
('23', 483, 2, 6, 1157499) There was however no desire to bargain.
('23', 483, 2, 7, 1157539) Mr. Gandhi even said that, whether the prosecutions took place or not, he would be bound, after having shown the extracts to his friends for their own honour and that of the cause to advise them to express publicly their regret.
('23', 483, 3, 8, 1157768) During the whole discussion His Excellency and Mr. Gandhi were actuated by
('23', 483, 4, 9, 1157843) the desire to prevent any untoward events that might result from the prosecutions, as
('23', 483, 5, 10, 1157929) also to prevent speeches inciting to violence.
('23', 483, 5, 11, 1157976) The Viceroy informed Mr. Gandhi that
('23', 483, 6, 12, 1158013) he might not be able to prevent the commencement of proceedings if the statement
('23', 483, 7, 13, 1158094) was not published with the least possible delay.
('23', 483, 7, 14, 1158143) There was already much discussion
('23', 483, 8, 15, 1158177) of the speeches not only in India but also in the United Kingdom.
('23', 483, 8, 16, 1158243) Mr. Gandhi agreed
('23', 483, 9, 17, 1158261) that the statement should be published without delay.

('23', 483, 12, 21, 1158509) Press for publication.
('23', 483, 12, 22, 1158532) The alteration was as follows:– For the passage in Mr.
('23', 483, 13, 23, 1158587) Gandhi’s draft statement “We desire to state that we never intended to incite to
('23', 483, 14, 24, 1158668) violence but we recognize that certain passages in our speeches are capable of bearing
('23', 483, 15, 25, 1158755) the interpretation put upon them,” Mr. Shaukat Ali and Mr. Mahomed Ali put, “We

('23', 483, 17, 27, 1158924) any passages in our speeches were capable of bearing the interpretation put upon
('23', 483, 18, 28, 1159005) them, but we recognize the force of our friends’argument and interpretation.”
('23', 483, 19, 29, 1159083) After the publication of the statement an official communique was issued by the Government.
('23', 483, 19, 30, 1159175) The terms of the communique were not actually settled until just
('23', 483, 20, 31, 1159240) before its issue and Mr. Gandhi never saw it although the substance of it as already indicated had been communicated to him.
('23', 483, 20, 32, 1159365) The main part of the interviews between His Excellency and Mr. Gandhi consisted of conversations which ranged over the various causes of discontent in India including the Punjab disturbances, the Khilafat agitation, the Treaty of Sevres and the general conditions of the people.
('23', 483, 20, 33, 1159644) Mr. Gandhi did not submit any scheme of swaraj to His Excellency, nor was a scheme of swaraj discussed at the interviews.

('23', 484, 1, 2, 1159830) APPENDIX IV
('23', 484, 2, 3, 1159842) TAGORE’S CRITICISM OF NON CO OPERATION
('23', 484, 4, 4, 1159881) March 2, 1921
('23', 484, 5, 5, 1159895) It is in the fitness of things that Mahatma Gandhi, frail in body and devoid of material resources, should call up the immense power of the meek, that has been lying waiting in the heart of the destitute and insulted humanity of India.
('23', 484, 5, 6, 1160131) The destiny of India has chosen for its ally, Narayana, and not Narayanasena, .
('23', 484, 5, 7, 1160211) the power of soul and not that of muscle.
('23', 484, 5, 8, 1160253) And she is to raise the history of man, from the muddy level of physical conflict to the higher moral altitude.
('23', 484, 5, 9, 1160365) What is swaraj?
('23', 484, 5, 10, 1160381) It is maya.
('23', 484, 6, 11, 1160393) like a mist, that will vanish, leaving no stain on the radiance of the Eternal.
('23', 484, 6, 12, 1160473) However we may delude ourselves with the phrases learnt from the West, swaraj is not our objective.
('23', 484, 6, 13, 1160573) Our fight is a spiritual fight, .
('23', 484, 6, 14, 1160607) it is for Man.
('23', 484, 6, 15, 1160622) We are to emancipate Man from the meshes that he himself has woven round him, .
('23', 484, 6, 16, 1160702) these organization of National Egoism.
('23', 484, 6, 17, 1160741) The butterfly will have to be persuaded that the freedom of the sky is of higher value than the shelter of the cocoon.
('23', 484, 6, 18, 1160860) If we can defy the strong, the armed, the wealthy, .
('23', 484, 6, 19, 1160913) revealing to the world the power of the immortal spirit, the whole castle of the Great Flesh will vanish in the void.
('23', 484, 6, 20, 1161031) And then Man will find his swaraj.
('23', 484, 6, 21, 1161066) We, the famished, ragamuffins of the East, are to win freedom for all Humanity.
('23', 484, 6, 22, 1161146) We have no word for ‘Nation’ in our language.
('23', 484, 6, 23, 1161192) When we borrow this word from other people, it never fits us.
('23', 484, 6, 24, 1161254) For we are to make our league with Narayana, and our victory will not give us anything but victory itself; victory for God’s world.
('23', 484, 6, 25, 1161386) I have seen the West; I covet not the unholy feast, in which she revels every moment, growing more and more bloated and red and dangerously delirious.
('23', 484, 6, 26, 1161537) Not for us is the mad orgy of midnight, with lighted torches, but awakenment in the serene light of morning.
('23', 484, 7, 27, 1161646) March 5, 1921
('23', 484, 8, 28, 1161660) The idea of non co operation is political asceticism.
('23', 484, 8, 29, 1161714) Our students are bringing their offering of sacrifices to what?
('23', 484, 8, 30, 1161778) Not to a fuller education but to non education.
('23', 484, 8, 31, 1161826) It has at its back a fierce joy of annihilation which at its best is asceticism, and at its worst is that orgy of frightfulness in which the human nature, losing faith in the basic reality of normal life, finds a disinterested delight in an unmeaning devastation, as has been shown in the late War and on other occasions which came nearer to us.
('23', 484, 8, 32, 1162172) No in its passive moral form is asceticism and in its active moral form is violence.
('23', 484, 8, 33, 1162257) The desert is as much a form of himsa (negligence) as is the
('23', 484, 9, 34, 1162318) raging sea in storm; they both are against life.
('23', 484, 10, 35, 1162367) I remember the day, during the swadeshi movement in Bengal, when a crowd of young students came to see me in the first floor hall of our Vichitra house.
('23', 484, 10, 36, 1162520) They said
('23', 485, 0, 1, 1162530) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('23', 485, 1, 2, 1162572) to me that if I would order them to leave their schools and colleges they would instan tly oblige.
('23', 485, 1, 3, 1162671) I was emphatic in my refusal to do so, and they went away angry, doubt ing the sincerity of my love for my motherland.
('23', 485, 1, 4, 1162790) And yet long before this popular ebullition of excitement I myself had given a thousand rupees, when I had not five rupees to call my own, to open a swadeshi store and courted banter and bankruptcy.
('23', 485, 1, 5, 1162989) The reason of my refusing to advise those students to leave their schools was because the anarchy of a mere emptiness never tempts me, even when it is resorted to as a temporary measure.
('23', 485, 1, 6, 1163176) I am frightened of an abstraction which is ready to ignore living reality.
('23', 485, 1, 7, 1163251) You know that I do not believe in the material civilization of the West just as I do not believe in the physical body to be the highest truth in man.
('23', 485, 1, 8, 1163401) But I still less believe in the destruction of the physical body, and the ignoring of the material necessities of life.
('23', 485, 1, 9, 1163521) What is needed is establishment of harmony between the physical and spiritual nature of man, maintaining of balance between the foundation and superstructure.
('23', 485, 1, 10, 1163680) I believe in the true meeting of the East and the West.
('23', 485, 1, 11, 1163736) Love is the ultimate truth of soul.
('23', 485, 1, 12, 1163772) We should do all we can not to outrage that truth, to carry its banner against all opposition.
('23', 485, 1, 13, 1163867) The idea of non co operation unnecessarily hurts that truth.
('23', 485, 1, 14, 1163928) It is not our hearth fire, but the fire that burns out our hearth and home.
('23', 485, 2, 15, 1164004) March 13, 1921
('23', 485, 3, 16, 1164019) Today, at this critical moment of the world’s history, cannot India rise above her limitations and offer the great ideal to the world that will work towards harmony in co operation between the different peoples of the earth?
('23', 485, 3, 17, 1164244) Men of faith will say that India requires to be strong and rich before she can raise her voice for the sake of the whole world.
('23', 485, 3, 18, 1164372) But I refuse to believe it.
('23', 485, 3, 19, 1164400) That the measure of man’s greatness is in his material resources is a gigantic illusion casting its shadow over the present day world—it is an insult to man.
('23', 485, 3, 20, 1164558) It lies in the power of the materially weak to save the world from this illusion and India in spite of her penury and humiliation, can afford to come to the rescue of humanity.
('23', 485, 4, 21, 1164735) The ideal of India is against the intense consciousness of the separa teness of one’s own people from others, and which inevitably leads to ceaseless conflicts.
('23', 485, 4, 22, 1164896) Therefore my one prayer is, let India stand for co operation of all peoples of the world.
('23', 485, 4, 23, 1164986) The spirit of rejection finds its support in the consciousness of separation, the spirit of acceptance in the consciousness of unity.
('23', 485, 4, 24, 1165120) India has ever declared that unity is Truth, and separateness is maya.
('23', 485, 4, 25, 1165191) This unity is not a zero, it is
('23', 485, 5, 26, 1165223) that which comprehends all and therefore can never be reached through the path of negation.
('23', 485, 5, 27, 1165315) Our present struggle to alienate our heart and mind from those of the West is an attempt at spiritual suicide.
('23', 485, 5, 28, 1165426) If in the spirit of national vaingloriousness we shout from our house tops that the West has produced nothing that has an infinite value for man, then we but create a serious cause of doubt about the worth of any
('23', 486, 0, 1, 1165639) VOL. 23 : 6 APRIL, 1921 21 JULY, 1921 487
('23', 486, 1, 2, 1165681) product of the Eastern mind.
('23', 486, 1, 3, 1165710) For it is the mind of man in the East and West which is ever approaching Truth in her different aspects from different angles of vision; and if it can be true that the strength of West has betrayed it into an utter misdirection, then we can never be sure of the standpoint of the East.
('23', 486, 1, 4, 1165996) Let us be rid of all false pride and rejoice at any lamp being lit at any corner of the world, knowing that it is a part of the common illumination of our house.
('23', 486, 2, 5, 1166158) The West has misunderstood the East which is at the root of the disharmony that prevails between them.
('23', 486, 2, 6, 1166261) But will it mend the matter if the East in her turn tries to misunderstand the West?
('23', 486, 2, 7, 1166346) The present age has powerfully been possessed by the West; it has only become possible because to her is given some great mission for man.
('23', 486, 2, 8, 1166485) We from the East have to come to her to learn whatever she has to teach us; for by doing so we hasten the fulfilment of this age.
('23', 486, 2, 9, 1166615) We know that the East also has her lessons to give, and she has her own responsibility of not allowing her light to be extinguished, and the time will come when the West will find leisure to realize that she has a home of hers in the East where her food is and her rest.

('23', 487, 2, 7, 1169128) A pagan world might have celebrated such an event, and settled down to this job of “assimilating” its victims, but not a community of Christian peoples, each of them enjoined by its religion to cherish the other.

('23', 487, 2, 9, 1169414) But now that their eyes are opened, they must see that what their rulers sowed for their enemies, they have reaped, and that on the principles and the policy of the war no nation can live.
('23', 487, 2, 10, 1169603) Once that discovery is made and applied, there is no reason for despair, but, on the contrary, every hope of the amendment of civilization.

('23', 487, 2, 21, 1170972) The smaller nations, strengthened by their abstinence from war, begin to refuse submission to the tyranny of the great, and if they are threatened again, will form protective leagues of their own.
('23', 487, 2, 22, 1171169) Met with force, they will resort to the equalizing aid of science, or counter the Empires on the ground of spiritual power in which they excel.
